MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

HAY LAKES RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

On the 12th of December, Bishop Routhier visited this Branch and advised that the following was a statement of expenditure to date and estimated amounts required in the future for the construction of this residential school:

"On Oct. 31st we had spent $142,670.04
Remained of amount approved by Order in Council 32,329.96

Approximate amount of remaining cost

Linoleum - transportation $8,000.00
Electric Plant, batteries installation $8,000.00
Frigidaire, milk cover, installation $2,000.00
Labor and water system $15,000.00
Lumber and cement, transportation $6,000.00
Installation plumbing and heating $25,000.00
Other transportation $18,000.00

Total: $84,000.00

Amount remaining 32,329.96
Amount still required $51,670.04"
You will note Bishop Routhier feels that some $51,000.00 more will be required for the completion of this school. Our Order in Council concerning this project reads as follows:

"That including materials, transportation, building costs and unforeseen contingencies, the estimated amount required for this building will be approximately $175,000.00."

It would seem evident from the statement left by Bishop Routhier that the cost of this building will now be $225,000.00.

Bishop Routhier advised that the main item of increased expenditure was the high cost of transportation. Their bill for this item alone will come close to $50,000.00. The initial estimate was about $15,000.00.

Every attempt has been made to pare expenses and Brothers are being employed wherever possible instead of hiring outside labour. For example, when it was found that the installation of the plumbing by Edmonton contractors would cost about $35,000.00, a Brother was brought from Eastern Canada to do this work instead. Naturally, there will be a great saving on this item.

I would make the following recommendations with regard to this school:

(a) That the Lands and Development Services Branch be requested to despatch an engineer to this school immediately and submit a complete report on the project.

(b) That when this engineer's report is received, further consideration be given to providing the extra funds required to complete the school.

Director.

With reference to your memorandum of November 12th enclosing tenders secured for the above, the tenders were submitted to the Lands & Development Services Branch.

Enclosed for your information is a copy of their memorandum dated December 9th recommending acceptance of the tender of Medland Machinery, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, in an amount of $5,469.00. Attached hereto is a copy of the specification forwarded to the Departmental Purchasing Agent by the Indian Affairs Branch and used as a basis upon which the bids listed below in answer to "Request for Quotation" Requisition No. 99242 dated October 24th last were made.

Dear Sir:

Re: Hay Lakes Residential School,
Electoral District of Peace River,
Province of Alberta.

The following report is the result of an inspection made by myself of the above-noted project.

On arriving at this project I was able to acquire a set of blue prints for the school. Specifications and detail sheets were not available.

Construction of school throughout was found very satisfactory, and can be classed as better than general construction found today.

There have been some changes made according to the plan. These changes were made to create more room in some sectors, and less in others. The general outline of the plan however, has not been changed except for the tunnel connecting the boiler room to the chapel. The tunnel has been omitted and the boiler room built adjoining the chapel. Other alterations are as follows:

Extra wall erected in dormitories. This to create a space to serve as cloak rooms. Two rooms added for staff, these are not shown in plan. Some window changes made. Plans call for interior finish of Gyproc or Gypsum Board. This has been changed to 3/8 Plywood.

Not being in possession of specifications I could not say if other materials in the building were in accordance with plan or not. The construction of the building is completed with the exception of some cupboards, and inside trim. I was informed by Father Rainville, who is in charge of construction, that he expected to have the school ready for occupation by the 15th of November.

I inquired as to the amount of materials ordered for this project. I could get no satisfaction concerning this. I was told that all the invoices were kept in McLennan's hands. Apparently plenty of materials were ordered as there is surplus left over. This surplus inventory is attached to this report. I took inventory of all tools and equipment found on the site. This also is attached.

I might add there is still some plumbing and heating installation yet to be completed. This work is awaiting the arrival of plumbers from Edmonton.

Furniture and school supplies are on the site ready for the opening.

I did not make up a material list for the school. This can be done any time if I have the plans and details. As things stand now I cannot discern between materials used in the school and in the Father's residence. The same kind of materials have been used in both. I was informed by Father Rainville that materials for the Rectory were ordered separately. There are no invoices on the site to rectify this. These are also kept in McLennan's hands.

There are other added units not mentioned on the plans. These consist of a pump house, lighting plant house, and a dam across the river. Details of these units are attached to this report. There are temporary buildings on the site. These will be used for storage purposes during this winter. Details and dimensions of these attached.

continued.
While at Hay Lakes, I was shown a progress claim just submitted for payment. One item on this claim was headed, Landscaping. The claim stated Landscaping completed. As I could see no evidence of any Landscaping on the site I asked Father Rainville about this matter. I was informed that Landscaping meant the removing of surplus earth off the site and levelling same. This in my experience does not come under the heading of Landscaping.

I made a survey of the site while there, for drainage purposes. This proved favorable. The instrument showing a good fall from the centre to lower ground level and to the river. I will be drawing a plan of the site and plotting all buildings for future reference.

On observing the contract price for this school, I see that this price has been exceeded. This I was told by Father Rainville was partially due to the high freight rate to this point. As I stated previously, I did not have detail sheets and specifications or invoices covering materials, without these I cannot state anything in regards to whether uncalled for materials has been used, or quality or price. I am satisfied however, that all materials purchased have been used.

The barn to be erected has not been started and will not be until spring. As far as I know materials have not been ordered as yet.

May I suggest that some surplus materials which will not be used or be needed at this project any more, could be used for future construction at other points for example:

Fox Lake School. This would mean a saving of freight rates to the amount of $1400 per cwt. from this point compared to $250 from Edmonton.

A full report of staff residence including material list is attached to this report.
Re: Staff Residence,
Hay Lakes Indian Residential School.

I am given to understand that this building was to be built for a cost of $10,000.00. Attached to this report you will find a complete list of materials used in this building. This list was not prepared by the contractor.

There was no list available so checking the plans I prepared myself. The amounts were verified by Father Rainville who constructed the building. The prices I quote are taken from standard supply houses in Edmonton at that date. These figures are not meant to be taken as actual prices paid for materials for this building, but to be used as an approximate estimate for same.

These figures show that materials alone run over contract price. Labor costs of $7,500.00 are additional.

Dimensions of this building are 40' x 51' consisting of 13 rooms. This building is heated from the school boiler room. Materials used are same as in school. This includes interior and exterior finish. I might add that the construction of this building is as substantial as in the school. I feel quite justified in saying that all buildings will be warm in winter and cool in summer, as result of construction and insulation methods used. This should result in having minimum fuel costs.

I hope this report is satisfactory to you, and fills your expectations of an inspection. I would have liked to have made a more thorough report on the school itself but I was handicapped by not having all details and specifications at my disposal.

Respectfully submitted,

A. H. Albinson
Construction Supervisor.

Details of Dam

A dam has been built across the small river flowing by the project. The water from this river is used for all purposes by the school.

As the depth of the river is very shallow, a dam was constructed to increase this so as to make water pumping easier.

This dam extends from bank to bank. A distance of 43 feet. Height of dam is 8 feet at each bank diminishing to 7 feet in the centre of the river.

Width of dam as follows:

4' at the base diminishing to 16" at the top.

Footings: Width 10 feet. Thickness 2 feet.

Materials: 400 bags of cement 1 Ton of reinforcing steel.

At the present moment the water has backed up for three miles. This means a large reservoir of water at a depth of six feet and the width of the river. This river is fed by springs and runs continuously.

On the water side of the dam dirt has been pushed in by caterpillar to the height of the dam and fifty feet in front.

The first or bottom floor is where the pump is installed. Below this floor is the well which is fed by the river. Re: Hay Lakes Indian Residential School

I am in receipt of a copy of your letter of October 18th to the Director.

Father Rainville was in to see me a few days ago and showed me a wire he received instructing him to discharge all workmen except one carpenter and wait until Colonel Neary and Bishop Rother have a meeting with the Minister.

The last progress claim was $25,000.00 over the funds voted. There was an original allotment of $175,000.00. We then got an additional $50,000.00 - making a total of $225,000.00. Since that time, there has been another progress claim for approx. $25,000.00. This claim has now been sent on. Father Rainville informs me he will need a further $12,000.00, as a minimum, to complete the project. He also said that it was absolutely imperative that I put in a favorable report.

I have nothing further to add to my report except that on my last visit to Hay Lakes the Chief served notice to me that within two years he intends to put up a big fight for day schools. In other words, we are going to walk right into a problem.

The breakdown of the $12,000.00 needed by Father Rainville is as follows:

MEMORANDUM FOR THE CHIEF

HAY LAKES INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

The following is a report of my inspection trip to the above building at Hay Lakes, Alta., on the 30th of September and the 1st of October, 1950.

2. The main building has been completed with the exception of a very few minor details. The construction, workmanship and finish of the building in every way is very good and the general appearance both inside and outside would not be out of place in any community.

3. At one time it was proposed that the Boiler Room and electrical equipment be housed in a separate building 60 feet away from the main building. It was later decided to erect the Boiler Room adjacent to the rear wall of the Chapel portion of the main building. The construction of this was started early this summer and has been completed with the exception of a few minor details.

4. The exceptions to a completed building consist of the placing of several water closets and lavatory basins, the connecting up of a few radiators, the domestic hot water heater and tank to be connected together and the insulating covering to be applied to the two floor, domestic hot water heater and tank and piping in Boiler room. Arrangements have been made with the firm of Lockerbie and Hole, heating contractors, Edmonton, to fly two men to Hay Lakes to complete the remaining plumbing and heating work.

5. A small amount of wood base, and a few doors are yet to be installed and small odds of painting which could not be done properly with the gun method has yet to be attended to. Exterior concrete steps are under construction from Boiler Room to grade level. Large double doors are yet to be installed. Also doors between Boiler Room and Laundry.

6. All concrete walls of basement have been furred, insulated and plywood covered with exception of laundry and future steam room. All concrete floors in basement with the exception of the above mentioned two rooms have been covered with mastic tile flooring. The first and second floors are entirely covered with linoleum. The addition of a canopy with stairs to same has been added in the Chapel. The erection of a fair sized covered veranda has been added at front entrance to the building. Fire protection system of water supply and hose racks installed at strategic position has been installed. Also an electrical fire alarm system throughout the building. Galvanized iron gutters and rain water leaders have been installed. All the above mentioned work was not indicated on the plans furnished by this office.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6381, file 770-5, part 2)
7. In report of inspection trip during January 1950 it was noted that the two classroom ends of the main building had been increased in width to line with main walls of building. It was also noted that a few iron pipe posts had been substituted for wood posts as plan originally called for. It should be noted that during the period of inspection trips approximately thirty free standing wood posts had been removed and replaced by iron pipe posts.

8. The electrical generating equipment has been housed in a separate building one hundred feet to the rear of the main building. The building is 18 feet x 21 feet of frame construction corresponding to the main building. This was erected during the summer.

9. A small building 10 feet square has been built over the well and motorized pump for water supply to the buildings.

10. A small concrete dam has been erected across the stream of water so as to raise the water level a few feet to assure adequate water supply during the winter months.

11. A residence building for the Fathers and male help is now under construction and should be finished shortly. Most of the interior partition work is in, some of the plumbing and electrical work installed and all exterior painting and some of the interior painting is completed.

12. Photographs of the various buildings were taken and as soon as prints are available will be forwarded.

Robert Thornton.

Hay Lakes Project

I have just returned from a trip to the site of the project. The bursar of the Corporation had arranged for a trip of inspection and to arrange for final details, and I took advantage of the plane charter.

The trip was disappointing in one respect, in that the project is not as near completion as I had been led to believe. As you are, I think, aware, communication between the site and outside points is almost non-existent, particularly in the summer. What little news had trickled out gave the impression that the building was nearly completed some weeks ago, and should have been completed by this time.

I found that, although the main structure is up, there is a very considerable amount of finishing work to be done, the following being the main points yet to be carried out:

1. Practically all cupboard and shelf work, including the kitchen and pantries.

2. A good number of plumbing fixtures yet to be installed.

3. Ceiling and walls of boiler-room to be lined with Gyproc board.

4. Install a high pressure boiler for laundry — this includes "brick-laying" of boiler and is quite an extensive job.

5. Put finishing coat on outer walls of basement and fireproof stair wells.

6. Considerable levelling and moving of dirt on grounds.

7. Building a dam for water supply.

8. Install some doors.

Father Rainville, Superintendent on the project, expects to employ a full crew for two weeks or more and the services of three or four carpenters for about three months. It looks as though this work may drag out into 1951.

I was not, of course, able to take inventory of materials left over as much of the remaining part will be used. Also, small tools were scattered all over the project.
However, on the whole I believe the trip worthwhile, as I was able to check the payrolls for the separate contract for building a Rectory, examine the School payroll, and also able to examine the Rectory quite thoroughly, so that it may be possible to come at least very close to verifying what materials went into its construction and what, if any, came from the supplies purchased for the School.

I made quite a thorough examination of the School building, checked on major items of equipment, and discussed with officials of the Institution and the Indian Superintendent the final disposal of tools, materials and equipment. I have also now a very clear idea of what to expect regarding the building of the dam, boiler installation, etc.

As the claim had not been prepared as yet, and as the Bursar was visiting several church locations on his return journey and was not sure when he would arrive at McLennan, I returned directly to Edmonton. I expect to leave here tomorrow night for McLennan. Mr. Villeneuve will likely accompany me so that we can complete the liquidation audit as far as possible.

I expect to re-visit the site, probably early in November, when the road should be frozen sufficiently to allow car travel. Mr. Knapp, Indian Superintendent expects to go about that time. I should then be able to complete the necessary inventories.

W.R. Butchart,
Audit Supervisor.

Re: Indian Residential School - Bay Lakes

On the fifteenth of September Bishop Rothier, Father Benglet, Mr. W. H. Butchart and I flew into Bay Lakes with the intentions of taking inventory and having the school turned over to the Department. However, there was about three weeks' work to complete the school.

Everything inside was finished except for the cupboards and connecting the water supply system. A dam will have to be built across the river for the latter.

The Fathers' residence is 75% completed but I notice that a considerable amount of the materials left over from the school have been used on this building. As the Fathers' residence was a firm price contract, the school should be credited with these materials and the Corporation Bénéfique C.R. de Grouard should be debited with the materials they used.

The finishing of the concrete on the outside was discussed. This would cost a fair amount of money. As the contract has already gone over the allotted amount, do you approve of finishing the concrete wall on the outside with a cement plaster? I understand that Bishop Rothier will be visiting you in the near future and you may be able to discuss this point with him.
Barn:

Apparently, it will be physically impossible to complete the barn by December 31st. In fact, it will be impossible to pour the cement this fall if they are to complete the school and the Fathers' residence. I have therefore asked Father Beuglet to order all the necessary materials and have them freighted in so that we can ask for a re-vote of the balance that will be necessary for the labor in erecting the barn. Please advise us if this arrangement is satisfactory.

Staff:

Bishop Rothier hopes to get three or four Sisters in to get the school ready by the beginning of next month. I very much doubt whether the school will be operating before some time in November at the earliest.

Lighting Plant:

The Corporation has rented a small auxiliary lighting plant from Bruce Robinson Electric. This would be suitable for an emergency plant. At the present time there is only one plant in the school and as the heating system is completely dependent on electricity and if this plant became unserviceable, there would be no way of getting heat to the dormitories and classrooms. As Bay Lakes is such an isolated district, I believe the Department should purchase this plant (and change the generator at a cost of about $100.00) as a safety measure. Mr. Butchart, the auditor, took the details of the plant and we could contact him if you feel we should acquire this plant.

I may add that all the children are very anxious to go to school and I do not anticipate any problem in getting them to attend.

Mr. Butchart and I intend to go into Bay Lakes when the first snow falls and we can drive over the winter road. We will be going to take inventory and take over the school.

S. C. Knapp,
Superintendent.

Dear Father Beuglet:

In connection with the construction of the main building, P.C. 97/388 dated March 2nd, 1949, approved an expenditure of $175,000.00. In addition, we provided an extra of $50,000.00 for the additional costs that it was understood would be incurred. This makes a total of $225,000.00. The expenditure to date has been as follows:

1949-50 fiscal year - $161,124.53
1950-51 fiscal year - $23,568.90

$184,693.43

I bring this matter to your attention at the present time in order to point out that the amount provided must not be exceeded.

In addition to the above, we have also provided in the current year's appropriation $25,000.00. This amount covers the erection of the staff building at a cost of $10,000.00 and the barn at a cost of $15,000.00. Authority for this expenditure was contained in P.C. 21/1188 dated March 8th, 1950. The amount mentioned for these two buildings is the total that can be provided for them. No extras can be considered.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt., Indian Education

Dear Mr. Neary:

Hay Lakes Residential School

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd inst., File 770-5 (EL) re Application No. 4 for approval of certain expenditures in connection with the above school.

Item No. 1 requests approval for the salary of $350.00 a month with board for Rev. B. Rainville, who has succeeded Mr. Verret in charge of the completion of the school. I may say that Mr. Verret was paid $550.00 a month. At the expiration of his contract, it was thought advisable not to renew same and have Father Rainville in charge of the completion of the school, as the services of a qualified engineer were no longer required. By so doing, an amount of $200.00 per month would be saved. When the question came up to decide on a salary for Father Rainville, the matter was discussed with the two auditors. They suggested that a salary of $350.00 a month with board would be the minimum rate of wages in line with labour conditions.

Item No. 4 concerns the purchasing of a cement mixer at a cost of $739.26. Same was purchased and paid for by La Corporation Episcopale C.R. de Grouard. We wish to have this expense reimbursed by the Department as it will remain their property. No rental has been charged for this machine, it being considered as belonging to the Department.

Trusting that the foregoing explanations are satisfactory,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. L. Boulet, O.M.I.

Re: Indian Residential School -
Hay Lakes, Alberta.

Attached hereto is an invoice from the Associated Airways for freight flown into Hay Lakes. This invoice is under date of June 8th.

You will note that the freight consisted of stoves, sewing machines, food grinder, file cabinet, parts and teachers desks. Father Rainville said that the teachers' desks would have fallen to pieces if they were carried over the roads. Experience has proved that the Hudson's Bay Company and Mr. George Clarke of Hay Lakes have taken many types of fragile equipment over this road in wagons.

I do not believe there was any justification in freighting this equipment into Hay Lakes by plane. I believe that if the freighter had been given a slightly higher rate with the understanding he was to be very careful with the goods, the whole amount could have been shipped in by wagon for half the price.

Father Rainville did not request authority to fly this equipment into Hay Lakes. There is nothing we can do now but pay the bill but a letter to Father Rainville pointing out that air transportation should be used only in an emergency may be appropriate at this point.

S. C. Knapp,

Mr. Bernard F. Neary  
Supt. of Indian Education  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I am very sorry to be so late in replying to this letter, the reason is that we have no mail service in Hay Lakes and then we have to depend on occasions to receive and send letters. Moreover at the time of the break-up in the Spring there is nobody to move in this country, the trails are too bad.

The reason why I bought the window shades from Blowey-Henry is because this Firm was able to give an immediate delivery on these items. On the other hand Marshall Wells could not give any definite date on delivery; and as you remember at the time I was purchasing those goods, I was organizing the last winter shipment going North. Otherwise I would have had to ship these by plane which is very expensive.

Yours truly,

Rev. B. Rainville, O.M.I.

Re: Hay Lakes Indian Residential School,
Fort Vermilion Indian Agency.

At Treaty time I made an inspection of
the Residential School now under construction at Hay
Lakes.

All the partitions were up and the inside
walls painted. The carpenters were in the process of
putting on the window facings and baseboards.

The plumbing is installed with the exception
of the steel radiators which were taken outside to be
painted. The electric wiring is finished except for
the connection of the fixtures. Much of the equipment
is in place ready for use.

The house for the electric light plant has
not been built but the plant is on hand. The floor
of the boiler house has been poured and they are ready
to proceed with the erection of this building. The base-
ment of the house for the Fathers has been poured. As
far as I can ascertain, little work has been done on the
barn. However, I think we are safe in saying that the
school will be ready for the children on September 1st.

With regard to the final progress claim
payment: The account now stands at $214,953.29. The
total amount authorized is $225,000 for the school alone.
I understand from the contract that final payment will
not be made until the building is completed, examined by
an engineer and the contract closed. Therefore, I would recommend that a Government Engineer inspect the school to see that it meets the contract specifications before payment of the final progress claim is made. Mr. Walreth, an engineer of the Department of Public Works, is now stationed at Lower Hay River, N.W.T., and would be the engineer nearest to Hay Lakes.

I do not anticipate much trouble in getting the children to school.

S. C. Knapp,
Superintendent.

c.c. Mr. G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Calgary.

MEMORANDUM

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Hay Lakes Indian Residential School,
Electoral District of Peace River,
Province of Alberta.

We have now two separate contracts with the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Grouard in connection with the erection of a residential school at Hay Lakes, Alberta. These are:

(1) A Cost Contract for the erection of the Residential School.

(2) A Flat Price Contract in the amount of $25,000.00 for the erection of a staff residence and a barn.

I previously recommended to the Minister of Mines and Resources that a Clerk of Works be appointed to supervise the use of materials in the building referred to in Item No. 2, and to report to the Department on the progress being made in its erection. No action was taken at that time but I feel that this matter should be again reviewed.

The Regional Treasury Officer has strongly recommended the appointment of a Clerk of Works and the Chief Treasury Officer of this Branch has concurred in this recommendation. I also feel that it is unfair to request our Indian Superintendent at Fort Vermilion to certify the progress payments now that two separate contracts are involved.
I would, therefore, again recommend that action be taken immediately to appoint a Clerk of Works for this project for the months of May, June, July, August and September, at least. We would require a man who has had considerable experience in frame building and who understands the uses of various building materials. Normally, the Department of Public Works secures the services of retired contractors or foremen-carpenters. It should be possible to hire such a man in the federal constituency involved. The suggested wage would be $150.00 per month, chargeable to the contract.

PP/ST

Director.

The audit of Progress Claim No. 5, submitted by the above contractors has been completed by the undersigned and the report thereon follows:

Payroll and Payroll Charges

All payrolls submitted have been checked in detail and have been found correct and in agreement with original time records and rates of pay received by employees.

Vacation Pay charges have been adjusted in order to give effect to a straight 4% rate for all employees, as prescribed by the Alberta Board of Industrial Relations for the Construction Industry, the said rate being effective from September 15, 1949.

An overcharge on account of W.C.B. charges on behalf of C.E. Varret's earnings in excess of $2500.00, has been audited on the present claim.

On payroll No. 1 for the period ending November 5, 1949, retroactive pay to P.E. Plouffe from Oct. 3rd to October 29th has been claimed with no details shown. It was explained that this employee is a missionary member of the Oblate Order and that the charges for his services were deleted from previous claims. The Corporation now wishes to claim for these services. The writer has verified the original payrolls covering this employee and has found the number of hours claimed as well as the rate to be in accordance with the time-records.

Materials and Expenses

All invoices for materials and expenses have been examined in detail and have been passed for payment subject to possible adjustments that may be required in respect of the following invoices:

- Item 7 - $47.26 - $46.15

The above discrepancies will be investigated and the necessary adjustments will be effected on a future claim. Other minor discrepancies have also been noted but have not been listed as the accounts involved were for a few cents only.

Invoice #167 from Maple Leaf Petroleum includes the purchase of one 2000 gallon storage tank for gasoline. It was necessary to purchase this bulk container to store gasoline as the Oil Companies would not sell the fuel required unless the containers or drums are replaced by empty drums. As it is essential to get supplies to the project during winter months when transportation is cheaper, the bulk storage tank was purchased with the view that it will also be required even after construction has been completed.

Transportation charges submitted in the present claim represent a substantial amount. The pressure of the fiscal year end business has not permitted the writer to check all materials transported to the suppliers invoices. However, a spot check has been done into a few accounts and the charges that have been allowed appeared in order. The rate of $2.25 per c.w.t. from Palmer to Hay Lakes, a distance of 380 miles, is considered as a very fair rate.

Discrepancies noted on Claim 4 Inv. 25 and 40 have been adjusted on Invoice 5/185 in the present claim.

Invoice 4/44 - Army & Navy Department Store for $1,600.79 represented equipment and supplies required for the employees on the project. These will be taken on inventory and will be retained by the Department at the conclusion of the project.

General

According to reports presented by the Indian Agent, Mr. S.G. Knapp at Fort Vermilion, the Corporation has progressed very efficiently with this project and has been performing a satisfactory quality of work.

The Corporation has dispensed with the services of Mr. G.E. Verret since the beginning of December. Father Rainville, a member of the Order has been acting as superintendent of the work, although no claim has to date, been submitted in compensation for his services.
Other members of the Order have also been employed on the project for whom no remuneration has been claimed.

The Corporation has informed the writer that steps have been taken with the Indian Affairs Branch to increase the appropriation for the project by $50,000.

The present claim brings the total expenditure submitted to the amount of $214,965.29 which is in excess of the original appropriation of $175,000. The claim has been approved subject to further funds being provided by the Department.

The above discrepancies will be investigated and necessary adjustments will be effected on a future claim. Other minor discrepancies have also been noted but have not been listed as the accounts involved were for a few cents only.

Invoice #167 from Maple Leaf Petroleum includes the purchase of one 2000 gallon storage tank for gasoline. It was necessary to purchase this bulk container to store gasoline as the Oil Companies would not sell the fuel required unless the containers or drums are replaced by empty drums. As it is essential to get supplies to the project during winter months when transportation is cheaper, the bulk storage tank was purchased with the view that it will also be required even after construction has been completed.

Transportation charges submitted in the present claim represent a substantial amount. The pressure of the fiscal year end business has not permitted the writer to check all materials transported to the suppliers invoices. However, a spot check has been done into a few accounts and the charges that have been allowed appeared in order. The rate of $8.25 per c.w.t. from Father to Hay Lakes, a distance of 350 miles, is considered as a very fair rate.

Discrepancies noted on Claim 4 Inv. 25 and 40 have been adjusted on Invoice 5/185 in the present claim.

Invoice 4/44 - Army & Navy Department Store for $1,600.79 represented equipment and supplies required for the employees on the project. These will be taken on inventory and will be retained by the Department at the conclusion of the project.

General

According to reports presented by the Indian Agent, Mr. S.G. Knapp at Fort Vermilion, the Corporation has progressed very efficiently with the project and has been performing a satisfactory quality of work.

The Corporation has dispensed with the services of Mr. G.E. Verrett since the beginning of December. Father Rainville, a member of the Order has been acting as superintendent of the work, although no claim has to date, been submitted in compensation for his services.
Other members of the Order have also been employed on the project for whom no remuneration has been claimed.

The Corporation has informed the writer that steps have been taken with the Indian Affairs Branch to increase the appropriation for the project by $50,000.

The present claim brings the total expenditure submitted to the amount of $814,985.89 which is in excess of the original appropriation of $750,000. The claim has been approved subject to further funds being provided by the Department.

Subject to the foregoing remarks, Progress Claim No. 5 has been certified.

Construction of Indian Residential School,
Hay Lakes, Alberta - La Corporation Episcopale Catholique Romaine de Grouard - Contractors.

Herewith, copy of a letter received from Mr. Charlton, Regional Administrator, Cost Inspection and Audit Division, with reference to the above. The gist of it is that, with the introduction of a firm price contract for the construction of the staff residence and barn at a cost of $25,000.00, as authorized by P.C. 21/1938, it will be difficult to determine the items which properly belong to the building of the residential school on a cost plus basis.

It has always been obvious to us here in Ottawa that, in the absence of a branch representative on the job, the "Certificate of Engineer" on applications for progress payments indicated the fact only that claims has been handled through the regular channel, i.e., the Indian Superintendent at Fort Vermilion.

Considering the distance and location of the residential school, a great deal more reliance must be placed on the "Certificate of Contractor" than would ordinarily be the case. Of course I am not overlooking the "Certificate of the Treasury Auditor", following his examination of the records of the Corporation maintained at McLennan, Alta.

I should like very much to discuss this matter with you immediately on your return from Toronto. In the meantime I have written Mr. Charlton advising him that final payment will not be made by this office without the assurance that the costs for the residential school have been segregated from the costs of the other buildings to the satisfaction of the auditor, Mr. Villeneuve.

Dear Mr. Lauchlan:

Re: Hay Lakes Indian School
La Corp. Episcopale C.R. deGrouard.

Please refer to your file 3-4-1 in connection with the above. The last progress claim No. 4 went forward on January 18th, 1950, and I am informed by the Auditor, Mr. Villeneuve, that claim No. 5 may be expected shortly and it should be forwarded in time for payment from old year funds.

There is one aspect of this contract which is not too satisfactory and that is the matter of proper inspection or a clerk of works at the site. It has not been possible to secure the usual breakdown of costs and your attention has been drawn to this in the previous audit reports.

I now attach a copy of a report by Mr. Villeneuve in which he mentions that the Department has provided a grant of $10,000.00 for the construction of a staff residence and a further grant of $15,000.00 for the construction of a stable and that according to his information these grants will be payable on the basis of invoices being submitted directly to the Department without the auditor's approval.

It is definitely bad business to have a mixture of cost plus and firm price contracts together or even in the same area and only difficulties will result. If the Auditor's information is correct then it should be arranged that the cost of construction of the two additional items will be handled as an addition to the cost plus contract regardless of the grant that may be ultimately payable as it creates a very difficult situation for the auditor on a project like this where materials and labour are not accurately controlled by a Departmental Superintendent or Clerk of Works.

As you know claims are being certified by the Superintendent of Indian Agency at Fort Vermillion and he is signing without any real knowledge of what is taking place.

Will you kindly give consideration to this report of the auditor and advise me in due course.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) H.G. Charlton,
Regional Administrator.

Re: Hay Lakes Indian School
La Corp., Episcopale C.R. deGrouard

I have just returned from McLennan where I have audited the accounts of the above contractors to be submitted shortly under Claim No.5.

As the claim documents and accounts have to be sent to Fort Vermillion for the Indian Agent's certification, it may not be possible to have it reach your office before April 15th.

The Indian Affairs Branch are very anxious to have this claim paid out of the old appropriation. In view of the unavoidable delays that may take place, it is probably advisable to inform the Department at this time that the claim submitted covers expenditures in excess of $65,000, which I have verified. I am prepared to certify providing the Department has approved the additional funds. The Corporation informed me that the Department is to authorize an additional $50,000 for the completion of the residential school.

The Department has also provided for a grant of $10,000 for the construction of a staff residence and a further grant of $15,000 for the construction of a stable. According to the information received, the only requirements necessary to obtain payments under these two grants will be to submit invoices directly to the Department without the auditor's approval.

It is apparent that arrangements of this kind will lead to a good deal of confusion in establishing which expenditures have gone into the school and which have gone into the other two buildings. If the contract is to be carried out on this basis, I can only suggest that a resident clerk of works be appointed at the earliest possible date; otherwise, I feel, in the light of the difficulties that have come up on the Wabasca project, that it is unfair to expect an auditor situated on hundreds of miles away to be able to exercise the proper controls of the expenditures being incurred.

The other alternative would be to amalgamate the grants into the one contract and have the accounts submitted in the regular manner after audit, with a breakdown of expenditures among the three buildings proposed.

It is essential that a procedure be established without delay in order to avoid the confusion which will inevitably result if two systems of payments are to be followed.

Kindly give the matter your immediate consideration and inform the Indian Affairs Branch accordingly.

(Sgd.) J.L. Villeneuve
Treasury Auditor.

Dear Mr. Neary:

This is only to inform you that we are doing all that is humanly possible to hasten expedition of Progress Payment accounts. The auditor arrived only yesterday, but expects to have completed his work here by Friday. I had wired Mr. Knapp of Fort Vermilion to come down here by plane so as to speed things still more, but in his reply received this morning he states that he has too much to do to get away at this season. This may therefore delay the expedition of papers, as from Mr. Knapp they must again go back to the auditor in Edmonton before being forwarded to Ottawa.

I received this morning from Mr. Knapp the contract to be signed for the staff residence and the barn at Hay Lakes. This will be sent to immediately. We shall forward account for all the lumber required. The companies cannot send iron material before some months, but could they draw up invoices for required iron, cement, etc as prepayment even though same could only be shipped later? Please wire answer to this required information.

I believe, from what Father Rainville tells me, that practically all furniture, etc have arrived and are on their way to Hay Lakes except the electrical unit which was shipped from Winnipeg by freight last Friday. A ban on the Grimshaw road has been placed this morning and may delay expedition unless police grants special permit to travel at night. I hope this may be done, as we never know how the roads may break up and retard until summer transportation.

I am grateful to you for the haste with which last expedition has been made. As soon as the auditor shall have made the total of this fifth Progress Payment claim, I shall forward same to you.

Yours Cordially,

Henri Routhier O.M.I.,
Coadjutor Bishop of Grouard.
April 5, 1950.

Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Father Plourde:

Hay Lakes Residential School

We are in receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo with reference to the expenditures incurred in connection with the erection of the above school.

With special reference to the second paragraph of your letter, it will be necessary for us to obtain a supplementary appropriation for additional funds that will be required according to information previously received from His Excellency Bishop Routhier.

Unfortunately, we have no funds in our Main Estimates for this project and as I have indicated above, a supplementary vote will be required. It is difficult to say when the Supplementary will be brought down before the House but this will very likely be some time in June. In the meantime it is doubtful whether any further funds can be made immediately available for the completion of this project, especially when it involves a sum of nearly $50,000.00.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. McKay:

I am in receipt of a letter from His Excellency Bishop Routhier in which he states that the amount first allotted for the construction of the Hay Lakes School may be completely expended at the end of the present month after the winter purchases of material and equipment plus the payment of wages have been taken care of.

As it is very important, according to His Excellency, that no interruption be made in the construction of the school, he has asked me to write to you in the hope that you will be able to supply the necessary funds either out of residue moneys in the 1949-50 estimates or provide these funds in the 1950-51 supplementary estimates.

He wishes to thank you very kindly for authorizing the construction of the staff residence of the Hay Lakes School. He also wants me to tell you how much he appreciates your having permitted the immediate building of the school barn.

His Excellency has also asked me to thank you for what you have done in making possible the construction of the Hay Lakes School in such a prompt manner. He hopes that next September the Indian children of the district will be able to profit by the generous cooperation of your Department.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Hay Lakes Indian Residential School.

In response to your memorandum of the 9th March and as forecast in our memorandum of the 14th January, hereunder is a summary of the report of the representative from this office, Mr. Thornton, who visited the above school in January.

Mr. Thornton found that there have been many deviations from our design for this building. Each end of the main portion of the building has been widened, and the roof has been raised, obviating the dormer windows. These alterations increase the volume of the building by approximately 51,630 cu.ft. This Service concurred in raising the roof to permit elimination of dormer windows at the request of the church authorities.

Steel beams have been used over the central portion of the basement, eliminating wood construction with columns shown in our design. Concrete foundation walls have been lined with 1/4" plywood over shiplap and building paper on studding, which was not indicated on our drawings. Electrical work is being done.

Some partitions have been changed, no exterior stairs have been built, and the boiler room will be constructed adjacent to the end chapel wall.

Piping and plumbing fixtures have arrived on site, most of the basement drainage is installed and some plumbing stacks run up through the first floor. Most of the heating equipment is on the site and steam mains are being installed. The two boilers, at that date, were en route to the site.

All of this plumbing and heating is being done in accordance with drawings prepared by Messrs Lockerbie and Hole, Edmonton, Alberta.

With plumbing and heating services so far advanced no purpose can be served in having designs and layouts prepared by this Service.

Chief.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

HAY LAKES RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Please find attached a Submission to Council covering the provision of a staff residence and barn at the Hay Lakes Residential School.

This school is now under construction by the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Grouard (under authority of P.C. 97/388 of March 2nd, 1949). I also attach the tender received from Father Plourde covering the residence and barn.

Re: Hay Lake Indian Residential School

A copy of a letter from Mr. Huestis, Director of Forestry, is attached. There was a great deal of discussion over these logs. The Mission went ahead and cut 3,000 logs, amounting to at least 100,000 feet of timber, without the sanction of either the Province or this Agency. The Indians were not consulted.

I think it would be advisable at this time for someone with higher authority than mine to point out to the Mission at Hay Lake that as they are on an Indian Reserve, they should conform to the regulations governing an Indian Reserve and respect the Indian rights pertaining to that Reserve. (Ref. Para. 44 and Sec. 120 of the Indian Act.)

Last year, on the same Reserve, Father Arbay grew potatoes and then waited until there was a shortage and the Indians were then compelled to buy them at $6.00 per sack. The price for local grown potatoes should be between $2.00 and $2.50 per sack and I might add that the Indians are very resentful about this matter.

We will need the cooperation of the Indians to get them into the School this summer and any acts of this nature will make the work more difficult. I quite understand that the Mission is doing excellent work and that the timber would be granted to the Mission, but I believe it should be done properly. As the timber has already been cut, I would appreciate your advice on how to proceed with this matter.

S.G. Knapp
Superintendent.

March 4th, 1950.

Dear Mr. Neary,

May I thank you very sincerely for being so expedient in replying to my two telegrams, and while this exchange may not hasten all those who must furnish supplies, I hope that it will help press the sending of the weightier objects. The oven has not yet arrived.

The snow has been thawing here for the last three or four days, and if this warm weather keeps up we may have no snow left at the end of next week. This does not worry me too much yet as we usually get a good deal of cold before the end of March. Later than March, the weather is unpredictable; in fact, last year transportation became impossible after the first week of April, although this was sooner than usual. The cost is already high enough as it is, and I would not like to have to make use of extraordinary means of locomotion for any large amount of freight. One has very little idea of the condition of the roads when one has not gone over them by wagon.

I have wired Medland's to expedite the sending of Elect. Machinery. They still give March 27th as date of expedition, and sooner if possible. This would then have to be sent by express, as it will arrive too late otherwise, and it must arrive before heating can be put on, etc.

Yours very truly,

Encl. 1
Excerpt from report of Superintendent S.C. Knapp on trip to Hay Lake - Report dated 12th Jan/50.

I inspected the new Indian Residential School. Good progress is being made on this building. The outside is between 90% and 95% completed and the inside is insulated and shiplapped. Fifty per cent of the electric wiring is done. Two brothers, experienced plumbers - arrived at the same time to install the plumbing.

Their present plans are to get in as much freight as possible before the road becomes too drifted; then they plan to stop hauling freight and will open the road again by bulldozer in the Spring to enable them to bring in the remainder of the freight.

I am of the opinion that they will need additional funds to finish the school. $50,000.00 of the grant will have gone towards freight before they get all their supplies in. The freighting of materials to Hay Lake for the construction of this school has been a difficult undertaking and if it had not been for the free labor given by the Brothers it would have cost the Department a great deal more to build this school than had to be given out by contract. I feel very satisfied with the progress of the work. They have a very competent man in charge in the person of Father Rainville who built the Fort Vermilion hospital.

There is no doubt that this school is one of the best things that has happened for the Hay Lake Indians. As they are still a Band of primitive bush Indians and essentially trappers I feel that the first generation will reap the benefits of this residential school.
January 23, 1950.

Progress Claim No. 4 - $37,167.67

The audit of Progress Claim No. 4 submitted on the above project has been completed at the contractors' office at McLennan, Alberta, and the report thereon follows:

Payroll and Payroll charges:

The salary rate received by Superintendent A. Verret has been approved by the Department.

Wages rates are in compliance with minimum wage rates prescribed by the Board of Industrial Relations for Alberta. Carpenters have been paid at the rate of $1.25 per hour and helpers at $1.00 per hour. These employees have all been recruited in the district, and the wages paid are in line with labor rates in that area.

Indian laborers have been paid at rates complying with the Provincial minimum wages and have been considered reasonable by the Supervising Indian Agent.

Provision has been made for the payment of Holiday Pay at the conclusion of the project. In the meantime these charges have been set up as accrued and withheld from the claim.

A detailed check of the Payroll calculations and extensions revealed the following discrepancies:

1. Payroll - Aug. 13/49 - Leopold Sasseville Overpaid $1.40
2. " - Sept. 10/49 - Joachim Clareau " $1.10
3. " - Sept. 17/49 - Indian laborers " $.20
   No adjustment considered necessary.
4. " - Sept. 24/49 - Henry Meroredi charges were omitted in transcription and have been verified and written in.
Payroll Oct. 1/49 - Joachim Claveau - Overpaid $2.10
- George Mercadi - $ .20 recovery doubtful.

With the exception of item 3 and 20 cents in item 5, the overpayments have been borne by the contractor and no overcharge has resulted in the claim.

Board:

The value of free board has been taken into account in the calculation of Holiday Pay, Workmen's Compensation and Public Liability Insurance.

The value of free board charged on payrolls together with board deductions have been credited to materials and supplies.

Materials:

Invoices covering materials and expenses have been checked in detail and the following discrepancies have been noted:

Inv. 4/25 - Marshall Wells - $12.62 appears to be a duplication of Inv. 4/41. The contractor will have to secure the corresponding credit and apply same in future claim.

Inv. 4/40 - Marshall Wells - $8.37 Item for $4.98 has been omitted resulting in undercharge of $4.98.

Inv. 4/44 - Army & Navy Dept. Store - $1,600.79 - This appears to be equipment and supplies for the operation of the school and should not have been charged to the cost of construction. The account will be investigated.

Small Tools:

An inventory of small tools has been retained and kept up to date.

A number of deductions have been made from Indian laborers for tools which they retained and have been credited on the Summary of invoices for materials.

Insurance on Buildings:

The Corporation has secured additional Fire Insurance coverage on the building and materials. The following policies registered in the joint names of La Corporation Episcopale, C.R. de Grouard, and the Department of Mines and Resources. Copies have been forwarded to the Department at Ottawa.
The Bee Fire Ins. Co. #154167 expiring Oct. 17, 1950 $5000.00
Patriotic Assurance Co. #1511004 Oct. 17, 1950 $10,000.00
The British Canadian Co. #F38172 Oct. 17, 1950 $10,000.00
London Guarantee & Accident #584669 Oct. 17, 1950 $10,000.00
Niagara Fire Ins. Co. #21356 Oct. 17, 1950 $15,000.00

The Corporation now carries coverage for a total value of $110,000.00.

Plant Rentals:

The charges for plant rentals are in accordance with rates approved and represent equipment owned by members of the Corporations in charge of other missions. Although no time records have been maintained on the rental of the teams supplied by Father Arbet, the Superintendent did confirm that the time charged was reasonably accurate and not excessive.

Sub-Contracts:

Hauling of gravel and the Cutting and Hauling of firewood for heating the building while under construction, has been carried out by Indians on a unit price basis. These rates were arrived at after negotiations with the Indians. These rates appear reasonable and have not been questioned by the Indian Superintendent. Supporting schedules of quantities supplied have been appended to the claim. Deductions from payments for meals and supplies taken by the Indians have been credited to the summary of materials.

General:

The present Progress Claim No. 4 has been certified by the Indian Superintendent, S.C. Knapp at Fort Vermilion who has visited the project during recent months. The Department has requested that all claims on the project should be approved by the Agent at Fort Vermilion rather than by the Agent at High Prairie as it had heretofore been done.

According to reports received and photographs examined the work had progressed relatively well up to the end of November. At that time, the main shell had been erected and work was to begin on utilities and interior finishing.

The total expenditure to the end of November amounted to $146,372.64 which is still within the authorized estimate of $175,000.00. It is evident, in the light of the existing conditions, that the cost of the building will be considerably higher than the original estimate. The Corporation is negotiating with the Department in order to secure the necessary authority to exceed the original appropriation.

Kyuquot Indian Day School

The Department is prepared to approve the transfer of Mrs. C. Green from the Kyuquot Indian Day School to the primary room at the Chehalis Indian Day School effective 1 September, 1950.

The Department has reviewed the application of Miss E.H. Langdale as a replacement for Mrs. Green and notes that she has had no elementary teaching experience in Canada. We have had considerable difficulty in the past with teachers holding English certificates in that they do not seem able to adapt themselves to teaching Indians. I would hesitate to recommend that Miss Langdale be classified as a Grade 3 teacher but would suggest that she only be classified as a Grade 2 teacher until she has met the following qualifications:

(a) Attended the British Columbia Department of Education Summer School and taken at least two courses there preferably in primary and elementary teaching techniques

(b) Had one satisfactory inspection report from Major Davey.

Our experience has been that it is very difficult to down-grade a teacher from Grade 3 to Grade 2.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Extract from Superintendent Garrard's Quarterly Report dated March 31, 1950.

The attendance at the Kyuquot School has been affected by the weather as one family live across a piece of open water and these have remained away when weather conditions were unfavourable. Mrs. Green, the teacher there appears very capable and is an asset to the place.

She desires that a dwelling be erected for her as she finds the food where she is boarding (an Indian home) lacking in variety and monotonous, from what I can gather Pork and Beans continuously. At any rate she appreciated a ham sandwich which she got on the Departmental Launch "Duncan Scott" immensely.
School supplies have been ordered from PP&G on May 18th. I am writing Mr. Brixwell to reach this order.

Mr. Arnold has been authorized to purchase desks and janitor supplies.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Kyuquot Indian Day School.

Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil has recommended the establishment of a school in temporary quarters on the Kyuquot Indian Reserve No. 1. The Church authorities have indicated that they are prepared to allow the present Church building to be used for school purposes. It can be adopted readily for this purpose.

Mr. Indian Superintendent Garrard has previously sought unsuccessfully to have these Indian children admitted to the nearby provincial school. In view of the fact that his request was refused, we have no alternative other than to establish our own school.

Director.

BFN/HM
April 23, 1949.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are twenty (20) Indian children of school age on the Kyuquot Indian Reserve No. 1 in the West Coast Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom educational facilities are required;

THAT funds are available in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a day school for these children.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that a day school be established on the Kyuquot Indian Reserve No. 1 in the West Coast Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 98, 1927, to be known as the "Kyuquot Indian Day School".

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

I have been informed by Mr. Superintendent Garrard that there are approximately 20 children of school age who could attend a day school if one were established on the Kyuquot Reserve No. 1.

The church authorities have indicated that we could use temporarily the church building for school purposes. This could be adapted readily.

Mr. Garrard previously sought admission of the Indian children to the Provincial school nearby, however this request was refused and there would appear to be no alternative but to establish our own school. It is requested therefore that the necessary steps be taken to establish a school on the Kyuquot Reserve No. 1, to be named the Kyuquot Indian Day School.

It is anticipated that if permission is granted for the establishment of this school it will commence operation at the beginning of the new academic year.

W.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum:

Doctor McGill,
Inspection Trip, August 23 - October 22.

In discussion with the officers there all were of the opinion that a day school should be built at Fort St James. After reviewing the situation and hearing of the number of children who were not attending school, I believe this should be done. At present some of the children from this area are being taken to Lejac school. There are approximately 240 Indians at Fort St James.

P.E. Moore, M.D.,
Asst. Supt. of Medical Services.
Ottawa,
November 24, 1939.

EXD.

A.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his recent visit to British Columbia Dr. P.E. Moore, Assistant Superintendent of Medical Services, writes as follows:

"In discussion with the officers there all were of the opinion that a day school should be built at Fort St. James. After reviewing the situation and hearing of the number of children who were not attending school, I believe this should be done. At present some of the children from this area are being taken to Lejac school. There are approximately 240 Indians at Fort St. James."

In view of present conditions I do not see any prospect of establishing a day school at this point during the fiscal year 1940-41 but in order that our file may be complete and the matter may not be lost sight of it would be appreciated if you would let me have your comments regarding Dr. Moore's suggestion.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner,

From the above analysis of the lists of children submitted by the Acting Indian Agent it appears that there are at the moment 54 children of school age at Fort St. James, 26 with either good or at least fair homes and 28 who are either orphans and must go to a residential school numbering 8, who live in fair homes 4, or in poor homes 16.

Leaving out of the picture the orphans there are some 46 children of school age who live in either good, fair, or poor homes in this village.

There are also some the following children of under school age, with good homes 10, with fair homes 22, and with poor homes 16, or in all 48.

With under school age children we divide by say 6 to find the average number available yearly as Beginners should a new Indian day school be established here. In this case there would be some 8 pupils for the Beginners class yearly.

With over forty children available for a day school now and an average of some 8 per annum for the next five or six years at least and a similar number yearly after that, I have no hesitation in recommending the establishment of a one room Indian day school at Fort St. James.

The school would be situated in a very cold part of the Province and must be of very good construction. It should have a teacher's residence attached as we should require a married man or woman as teacher here.

The type of school erected at Pemberton would be very suitable. Owing to the difficulty of transportation the total cost of such a school furnished at Fort St. James might be from 50% to 50% more than at Pemberton. I have no means of giving a more exact figure.

I would recommend that provision be made for such a school as I have mentioned above in the 1940-41 estimates.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
P.O.Box 444,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested I have given considerable thought to the letter N-1-255 dated December 22nd and list of Indian children at Fort St. James as forwarded to you by the Acting Indian Agent, Mr. J.H.F. Lacey.

Mr. Lacey does not show how many of these children are at the moment pupils of the Le Jac Indian Residential School.

I must assume from the correspondence that all these children are members of an Indian Band. I consider that it would be well for you to satisfy yourself on this point, as I may say at once that I had no idea there were so many Indian children of school age at Fort St. James.

The Reverend M. Marie O.M.I. in his letter of the 18th instant speaks of a number of halfbreed children and his efforts to have a Provincial day school started for them. In my reply to the Reverend Father Marie I suggested that if and when the Province started a school at Fort St. James I had no doubt that the Department would give consideration to the possible attendance of any Ladysmith children at that place who for one reason or another could not go to Le Jac Residential School. It would be of course to the Department's interest to have the Indian children educated in any such Provincial school at the usual fee of only $2.00 per month depending on the attendance for each Indian child.

The report now received from Mr. Lacey, if correct, throws a different light on the matter. I have for your information made an analysis of the Fort St. James Survey. The figures are tabulated for convenience.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

On November 18, 1946, The Most Reverend A. Jordan, O.M.I., D.D., Bishop of Prince Rupert, visited the office and brought the following matters to our attention:

1. That there is a need for an Indian Day School on a permanent basis at Fort McLeod.

2. That if the British Columbia Government puts a road through to the Peace River, there will eventually be need of an Indian Residential School at Fort St. John.

3. That next to the need for a school at Fort McLeod, there is a school required on a permanent basis at Fort St. James.

4. That the school at Rocher Deboule (at present closed) is in bad condition and in urgent need of repair.

Proposed Indian Day School at Fort St. James.

During a recent visit to this office the Most Reverend A. Jordan, O.M.I., D.D., discussed the need for a school for Indians at Fort St. James. This matter had been previously brought to the attention of the Department by you in your letter of March 29, 1940, on file 15-13-4824. A study of Captain Barry's report of December 29, 1939, which you attached, indicates the possibility of the Province starting a day school at Fort St. James. VANCOUVER, B.C.

Re: your file No. 15-13-3012

I wish to refer to your letter of December 10th, 1946, with respect to the proposal of the Right Reverend A. Jordan, O.S.T., D.D., to establish a Day School for the Indians at Fort St. James.

In addition to the existing Provincial Day School at Fort St. James, the province established a School for half-breed children of non-Indian status in 1941, and on an average, about 8 Indian children attended the School. The School was closed in 1946, and the half-breed children are now attending the white School. The Secretary of the Board advises that the white School is overcrowded, and it is impossible to accommodate additional pupils; consequently, we cannot obtain educational facilities for the Indians from this source.

There are approximately 69 children of school age in this Band. 39 of this number are attending Lejac Indian Residential School, leaving 30 children at home not receiving an education.

There are no buildings suitable for School purposes available on this reserve, nor adjacent to the reserve. I would recommend that the Department call for Tenders for construction of a two-roomed School at Fort St. James, in the coming fiscal year.

In event that a Day School is established at Fort St. James, I would point out that with the exception of one or two orphans, the pupils now attending Lejac Indian Residential School, would not return to Lejac. The parents would insist on their attendance at the Day School, which would necessitate engaging two teachers.

It would not be necessary to build quarters for the teachers. Lodging can be obtained at Fort St. James, either in the Hotel or private homes.

R. Howe,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum

To: Indian Commissioner
From: Inspector of Indian Schools.

Re: Proposed School at Fort St. James.

Mr. Indian Agent Howe has indicated that the Provincial school building at this point is unsuited for school purposes.

In December 1939 Captain Barry made a school survey at this point and recommended the erection of a one room school. Since that time the school age population has increased by fifteen and the pre-school age by the same amount. This indicates that the present requirement is a two room school which would take care of the expected increase for the next six years. If the population continues to increase at the same rate a three room school would be needed in from six to ten years.

In view of the limited amount of money available for schools for the 1947-48 fiscal year it is recommended that the erection of this building be delayed until it is possible to make a survey of the whole Province with respect to school requirements.

R.F. Devey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

Dear Major MacKay,

You will, no doubt, readily recall the visit I paid to your office last November. On that occasion, while talking about my own duties among the Indians, I had occasion to ask you if it were the policy of your Department to seek cooperation of the Church when formulating plans for the welfare of the natives. Your instant reply was to the effect that you were anxious at all times to have the views of the clergymen representing the various denominations.

It is this known attitude of yours that prompts me to write this letter on the subject of education among the Catholic Indians of the Vicariate of Prince Rupert with special reference to Fort St. James.

Recently I learned that plans were afoot to erect this year a day school in Fort St. James. While I am myself very much in favour of day schools as long as proper teachers can be obtained and there is some prospect of carrying out a successful scholastic program, I am wondering if all the implications of this particular move, in so far as it may affect Lejac, have been studied. The enrolment at Lejac just now is 180. The number of pupils from Stuart Lake district of which Fort St. James is the central mission is over 80 and this number includes boys and girls from the Fort itself (52), from Tachi (10), Portage (15), Trembleur Lake (4), Pinchi (1). It is only natural to suppose that parents from the other places will expect to send their children to Fort St. James as they have to go through there on their way to the school at Lejac and would probably violently object to sending them the extra 80 miles when there is a day school at the south end of the lake on which they reside.

Lejac is just emerging from a long period of deficits which in some years reached several thousand dollars. Is it reasonable to suppose that the residential school can be successfully operated with a greatly reduced number of pupils? If it be answered that steps would be taken to make up for the withdrawal of the other children by bringing them in from places like Cheslatta, Akila, Fort Graham, etc., it seems pertinent to remark that the whole policy of the Department in recent years has been to avoid sending children hundreds of miles from home. It seems to me that if the problem of Indian education is adequately to be solved, a start might be made with outlying areas such as those mentioned where so many children are not getting schooling at all. To open a day school at Fort St. James is hardly fundamental to the problem; rather it seems to be the easiest of all possible steps that could have been taken - and that, on behalf of children who are getting adequate schooling as it is. Let me site especially the case of the Babine Indians. They are in and out of Burns Lake continually to the detriment of the education of their children. One hears talk of the "wild Indians" from Babine and the priest at Burns Lake.
said to me the other day that he wondered why the department did not do something about them, either provide for them including a day school at Burns Lake or insist that their children attend school in Babine.

In what I have said, there is no lack of appreciation here of the difficulty of the problem of education among the Indians.

Now, if plans go through to begin a day school at Fort St. James, may I take the liberty of mentioning that the church plans to build a new church and priests' residence there. It would seem opportune to suggest that we get together on the matter of a site and come to some agreement about the sharing of services such as light and water. Then too in the matter of teachers, since all these Indians are Catholics, it would be much easier to obtain a competent staff if we were notified well in advance as to the number of teachers required. If a hospital as well as a school is contemplated, it seems to me that for continuity of the work, you might give me an opportunity of securing the services of Sisters who could supply both teachers and nurses (when and as required).

There are one or two other points I should like to mention in connection with Indian education, but I shall write about them at a later date.

I hope that you are enjoying good health after the mild winter in the East.

And personal regards and best wishes.

Sincerely yours,

Fort St. James Indian Day School,

I have searched in vain through our files for any specific facts which I could provide you concerning the points raised in Bishop Jordan's letter. I do not know this area and feel that the school will primarily be for the Indian children at Fort St. James and that Inspector Davey has no plans for Burns Lake this year. I think we can advise the Bishop that we are prepared to have Catholic teachers but I am rather concerned over these "joint building programmes". Our experience to date is that the Education Division bears the major portion of the costs and I would much rather build my own building. We could of course consider the sharing of electrical and water supplies.

I do not feel that we can provide any dormitory accommodation at Fort St. James for the Indian children at the far end of the lake and they will have to go to Lejac, as they do at present.

I regret that I cannot provide you with any other information. The material on our files, as you can see hereunder, is only fairly complete. Fort St. James Indian Day School.

Dear Mr. Arnell:

A long discussion was held in my office this morning with regard to the construction of a two-room Indian day school at Fort St. James. Present for this meeting were Bishop Jordan of Prince Rupert, Father Birtch, O.M.I., and the Superintendent of Education.

The following points of agreement were reached:

(1) That the Department be responsible for the erection of a two-room Indian day school at Fort St. James, to be ready for school opening by September, 1950. This school would be identical with that at Anaham and would provide for electricity and running water.

(2) That Bishop Jordan would endeavour to locate two qualified and experienced teachers for this school by that time. I believe Bishop Jordan will be approaching various teaching Orders of Nuns and with the assurance of a modern school he believes he will be successful in securing properly certificated teachers.

(3) That children of school age on the Fort St. James reserve would attend this new day school and only those children requiring institutional care would be sent to the Lejac Residential School.

I believe that the appointment of qualified Sisters will ensure a continuity in our educational program on the Fort St. James reserve which could not be obtained in any other way. I feel certain that the Bishop will endeavour to obtain an
English speaking Order of Nuns. We mentioned to him the work being done on Christian Island and in the Maritimes and hope that he will obtain as high calibre of teachers.

Knowing your views on the employment of Sisters in Indian day schools, and your experiences in Ontario and the Maritimes with such teachers, I feel confident that you will agree with the above proposals. I would appreciate your comments at an early date so that arrangements can be made to consolidate the plans and specifications for this new building. We intend to advertise for tenders in March 1950, if this meets with your approval.

Yours sincerely,

Director.
