Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear sir:

I have just returned from what I consider a very satisfactory and informative trip to Fort St. James with Mr. Davey, Inspector of Indian Schools, as approved by your Department and beg to submit report on same...

Mr. Davey took us out to St. James from Vanderhoof and together with Mr. Davey, Chief Felix Antoine and the resident priest, the Rev. A.R. Simpson, C.M.I., we definitely decided upon a splendid location of about five acres on the Reserve,- the proposed new school facing the lake.

I also obtained much information in regard to the site such as drainage, excavation, bearing qualities of the sub-soil, also the availability of material, gravel, sand, etc., and the most economical methods of transporting materials that will have to be taken in to Fort St. James from Vancouver or other points...

As the Department approved the cost of my trip up there I presume that it is their definite intention to go on with the building as soon as it is possible next year to do so.

With that in mind I intend to revise the Anahim School plans to suit local conditions at Fort St. James and to make up full quantity estimates and the specifications required for sub-contracts. These I will take to your office in Vancouver as soon as ready.

I might say that there is a very good quality of common lumber suitable for framing and shiplap sawn and sized within a few yards of the Reserve. I have no doubt we can obtain this lumber at a considerable saving over the cost of that procured for Anahim. However,-on account of the distance,-other costs will probably be a little higher.

At the present time my foreman,-Iver Holtlien,-(now building a District school at Alexis Creek) is definitely banking upon building the school at Fort St. James next year.

In conclusion I would be pleased to have you convey to Mr. Davey my very sincere thanks for a pleasant trip to the north country.

Yours very truly,

Edmund J. Bougheu.

Memorandum to: Indian Commissioner

From: Inspector of Indian Schools

Re: Fort St. James Indian Day School

On September 29th I visited the Necoslie Reserve No. 1 at Fort St. James with Mr. Superintendent, Howe, and Mr. E. J. Boughen with the purpose of selecting a site for the proposed day school on the afore-mentioned reserve. We met the Rev. A. R. Simpson, C.M.I., and Chief Felix Antcine, who accompanied us while making our survey.

The Chief informed us that the band was prepared to surrender a lot of approximately four or five acres, located in the centre of the reserve. This lot is level with about three acres cleared. The remaining portion being very lightly overgrown with small poplars. The distances from this site to the farthest house at the south end of the reserve is .4 miles; and .8 miles to the northern most house on the reserve, as measured by car speedometer. This latter distance is greater than the distance the pupils will have to walk as they will be able to make use of a short-cut. The lot proposed by the Chief has a north-western exposure to the lake from a bench some 15 or 20 feet above the trail running along the lake shore. Drainage, therefore, should not present any problem. There will also be ample space for playing fields. I feel that this is the most suitable of the school sites as to distribution of the population, the proximity to a good road, the exposure for classroom light, and the availability to an area suitable for playground purposes. One factor must be determined before this location is definitely selected and that is the provision of a water supply. There is no running
water within reasonable distance and it will be necessary to provide a well. Unfortunately, the local residents, both white and Indian, have not had success in the digging of shallow wells. There are, however, several artesian wells in the area which have been brought in through drilling to depths of between 250 and 300 feet. If a school is to be built in the spring, it is imperative that the location of a well on this site be definitely established this winter.

A second location was considered at the northern end of the reserve. This is not a very suitable site because of the distance which the population from the southern section would have to walk in the severe winter weather when temperatures frequently fall below 40 degrees below zero. The area available is also very small, and it would be necessary to secure a lot or lots, owned by individual Indians, upon which they have established buildings. The only factor in its favour is that we would undoubtedly be able to secure water by pumping from a small stream which runs close by. There is also some doubt as to the purity of this supply.

In considering possible sites, consideration was given to the fact that a small group of the band is presently resident on mission property less than a half mile to the north of the northern boundary of the reserve. In this group there are only four children of school age who might attend the day school. It was felt that if the school were located in the centre of the reserve, it would have the desirable effect of attracting these people to reserve land where assistance might be given to them in the matter of housing. Also, the Church is apparently considering the disposal of their mission property which would undoubtedly result in the eviction of the Indians. I feel that the school must be located without reference to these people due to the uncertainty of their continued residence on mission property, and because of the desirability of having them re-located on the reserve. In any case, the number of school age children living off the reserve is not large enough to warrant our placing the building in such a way as to increase the distance which the children living on the south portion of the reserve would have to walk.
It seemed obvious that the logical selection was on that portion of the reserve first mentioned which the band is apparently prepared to surrender. Accordingly, the exact location of this site and exposure was set out with Mr. Boughen, who, it is understood, will supervise the construction. The exposure of the classrooms would be in a south-easterly direction. This will provide the best available light.

R. F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools for B. C.

Re: Fort St. James Day School

When inspecting the site of the above school with Major Davey, September 29th last, the matter of water for the proposed school was discussed and it was considered advisable to proceed with well drilling operations at the earliest possible date.

In this connection, I am enclosing herewith, a requisition for the well casing and valve, with a tender attached from Gordon & Belyea, who advise that it may take eight weeks to obtain the material, possibly longer, depending on the present steel strike. Therefore, I would urge that the order be placed at an early date.

It is only by drilling what suitable water can be obtained in this district. There are several good artesian wells at Fort St. James, about one to two miles from the proposed school site, and the operator of the well drilling outfit is reasonably certain that he can obtain a good flow of water at 250' to 300', not only sufficient for the school and teachers, but enough for the requirements of 25 or 30 Indian families on this Reserve.

There is only one well drilling outfit in the entire district, owned and operated by Mr. Alec Nicholson, a well to do farmer, who, after a good deal of persuasion has consented to drill the well for the Department during the latter part of March next, which is the only time he is available.

A tender will be submitted in the near future from Mr. Nicholson giving a price on the drilling by the foot with all material to be supplied by the Department.

I am sure that Major Davey and Mr. Bowen will agree with me that this is the only solution to the water problem at Fort St. James.

With reference to Mr. Neary's Army Signal's messages of January 26th and 28th, Supt. Howe, in his letter of November 15th, a copy of which was sent to you, intimates that the possibility of obtaining a good flow of water at from 250 to 300 feet is reasonably certain. This assumption is based on the fact that there are a number of artesian wells in the vicinity producing water in volume and at least one of these supplies the requirements of a number of householders. The possibility of Mr. Nicholson not striking water is remote but in such an event I have no doubt the casing could be recovered.

We have had considerable correspondence with Mr. Howe in connection with this well and it is quite apparent from the letters on file that Mr. Nicholson, who has the only well drilling outfit in the vicinity, is not at all anxious to drill for the Department and I feel that any suggestion to him with regard to a reduction in cost if he does not strike water would not be favourably received and might jeopardize his acceptance of the contract. Re: Fort St. James Indian Day School

Further to my letter of October 22nd, Mr. Bouchen has supplied us with complete details of the materials required for the erection of the above-mentioned school and bills of material in duplicate and requisitions in triplicate for the following are enclosed:

(1) **Common Lumber** - This can be secured in the locality from either Ft. St. James Sawmills, Fort St. James, B.C., or Vanderhoof Lumber Co., Fort St. James, B.C.

(2) **Millwork** - It is suggested that this be purchased in Vancouver from either Sigurdson's Millwork Ltd., 1275 West 6th Ave., or the Mohawk Lumber Co. Ltd., New Westminster.

(3) **Cement, brick, etc.** - This material is available from Bowman Lumber Yards, Vanderhoof; or may be purchased from McCleery and Weston Ltd., or Evans, Coleman and Evans, Vancouver, B.C. The sand and gravel listed on the same requisition will be purchased from the best available source at Fort St. James.

(4) **Shingles, Shakes, Galv. Iron, etc.** - The asphalt shingles can be purchased from Sidney Roofing and Paper Company, Vancouver, and the shakes from Canadian Forest Products Limited., Vancouver (9110 Milton Street).

The galvanized iron can be purchased from Marshall Wells or McLennan, McFeely and Prior, Vancouver.
(5) Finish Lumber - Plywood, etc.: Reliance Lumber Co., Valley Lumber Yards, Simpson's Millwork or Mohawk Lumber Company.

(6) Building paper, hardware, etc.: McLennan, McFeely and Prior Ltd., Gordon Belyea Ltd., or Marshall-Wells Ltd.

(7) Insulation, tile, wallboard, etc.: Reliance Lumber Company, Valley Lumber Yards, McLennan, McFeely and Prior Ltd., or Marshall Wells Ltd.

(8) Paints, etc.: Douglas Paint Company, General Paint Corporation of Canada, Ltd., Vancouver.

We also have bills of materials and specifications on plumbing, heating and electrical installations but feel that it would be advisable to have these checked by our engineering staff and for us to call for tenders locally.

Under separate cover I am forwarding you four sets of revised plans of this building which will be required for the Purchasing Agent when calling for tenders on millwork as the locations of the various items are indicated on the plans by number.

In connection with transportation of materials purchased in Vancouver, Lee's Transport Ltd., 1140 Kingsway, Vancouver, operates a regular trucking service from Vancouver to Fort St. James and it would be far cheaper to ship by truck to the site rather than by rail to Vanderhoof and thence by truck.

W. S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

For a very considerable time there has been a great agitation on the part of the Indians of the Fountain Reserve to get a day school started for this Band.

I have been advocating an industrial or boarding school for the whole district, but pending this I beg to take this opportunity of applying for a day school for this one reserve in the meantime.

I am enclosing a list, signed by the Indians, which shows that there are thirty-seven children who would attend the school, and who will be sent if there is one available.

The Indians are willing to erect log buildings for this purpose provided the Department will furnish the same, and supply a teacher.

They are most anxious to get this started by the first of January, and I will be glad if the Department will give this matter their very favorable and early attention.

Ottawa, December 5, 1921.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of yours of the 28th ultimo, in which you refer to the request of the band at Fountain Reserve for a day school. I have noted that the Indians are willing to erect log buildings for this purpose, provided the Department will furnish the same and supply a teacher.

In reply I beg to state that, in view of your favourable recommendation, the Department will be glad to provide desks, blackboards, texts and any other classroom equipment that is necessary, if the band of the Fountain Reserve will erect buildings suitable for school purposes. You may inform the Indians at this point that the Department will give them this assistance and will secure the services of a teacher.

When you are prepared to assure the Department that the building, or buildings, that the Indians are erecting are satisfactory, you will kindly requisition for the supplies that you believe to be necessary, and you will make efforts to secure the services of a properly qualified teacher. The salary allowed will be $750.00 per annum and whatever bonus is allowed by law.

When you have informed the Department of the willingness of the Indians of the Fountain reserve to go ahead with this project, the Department will do what we can to assist in the securing of the services of a qualified teacher and will write to Mr. Inspector Cairns with a view to enlisting his assistance in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Having further reference to the Fountain Indians' application for a day school on their reserve, I beg to state that the Indians advised me that they would go ahead with the building, and practically assured me that they would be ready for occupation by the first of January; but for some unknown reason, these were never started, so I went up to see why they had not done as they promised. I held a meeting of the band on the reserve yesterday, and found that there was some hidden motive that I could not get at. It appeared to me that some of the principal men had no children of school age, whereas the chief, were opposed to this school. They had all sorts of excuses. First of all they said they could not understand why the Department did not build an industrial school, which was so badly needed for all the Lillooet speaking Indians. It ended up in them stating that they had not the money to erect the necessary buildings, and offering a new council house which is only half erected. The shell is up, but it needs shingling, lining and flooring. This is a nice big building, which would make an excellent school room. They also offered a piece of ground on which to have a teacher's residence erected.

It has now come down to a matter for the Department to practically erect two buildings, if we wish to start this school. The school is certainly very badly needed for the number of children that belong to this band. In fact an industrial school for the whole district is what we really need, as there are not enough schools in the Province within easy access to take these children. There must be at least one hundred and fifty children from Pemberton to Clinton that have no school to go to, nearer than Mission, which is now full.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, January 27, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 19th instant, referring to the proposed opening of the day school on the Fountain reserve of the Lytton agency. I have noted that the Indian band has not undertaken the preparation of a school building, that they are urging an industrial school and that they are offering a new council house which is only half erected. Your remarks concerning the need for a residential school on the line between Pemberton and Clinton have been noted.

In reply I beg to state that it will not be possible, in the immediate future, to provide funds for the erection of a boarding school. This matter, however, will be placed on file and will receive due consideration. I have to inform you that the Vote for Indian Education will not permit of an expenditure necessary for a day school on the Fountain reserve and a teacher's residence. In view of the fact that the band has failed to erect a log building for school purposes, as promised in your communication of November 28th, and because of their present uncertainty as to their wishes, I have to intimate that the Department is prepared to wait for more definite information. You may assure the Indians of the Fountain reserve that, if they wish educational facilities for their children in the immediate future, they had better rely on the day school plan and had better offer again to the Department some definite assistance.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. Chene:

The matter of a residential school for the northern portion of the Lytton agency has been under discussion for some time. It will not be possible, however, in the immediate future, to provide funds for the erection of such institution. We are at present trying to start one day school (Fountain) in this area. Without going into this matter fully with the Deputy Superintendent General, I cannot recommend that this property be purchased with a view to providing a site for a school at some indefinite future date.

Ottawa, January 10, 1906.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

I wish to call your attention to the grant made to the Halfway River White school of $100 per annum for the education of Indian children there.

In 1897 the Board of School Commissioners for the district of Parrsboro, in which this school is situated, applied for this grant through Mr. Logan, member for that constituency. At that time there were said to be 15 children in attendance. The grant has been paid quarterly up to the present, while the attendance has steadily diminished until the average has decreased to one; in fact during the past four years it has never been higher than three, while the average for that time has been less than two. Many of the Indians have moved away from this locality, and as there appears to be no prospect of the attendance ever improving, the Department is, I consider, paying a great deal too much to this school, and I think the existing arrangement should be modified to suit the present conditions, but before doing so it might be well to write to Mr. Rand, the Agent, to report as to whether there is any prospect of an increased attendance being obtained. The fair way would be to pay a per capita grant on the average attendance.

The Indians promise to send the children and the children promise to go but do not. The attendance during recent weeks, I am afraid, shows no improvement.

Proposed Port Douglas Indian Day School.

I have just finished discussing thoroughly the situation at Port Douglas with the Director. We are agreed that the proposals made by Mr. Gillett and yourself should be acceptable to the Department and are prepared to so recommend.

I am, therefore, preparing immediately a Submission to Council for the establishment of the Douglas Indian Day School. As you are aware, this step is necessary before funds can be expended on any project.

I have also the assurance from the Director that $2700 will be forthcoming from Indian housing funds for the purchase of the two additional buildings included in the five recommended for purchase.

There is now but one final point requiring clarification and that is, the problem of how the buildings will be set up on the proposed school site. Will they merely be left on the skids or will they be set up on cement blocks. This question is certain to be asked by the Minister's office, and we would appreciate your full comments on the problem.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are twenty (20) Indian children of school age on the Douglas Indian Reserve in the New Westminster Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom educational facilities are required;

THAT funds are available in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a day school for these children.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that a day school be established on the Douglas Indian Reserve in the New Westminster Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 98, 1927, to be known as the "Douglas Indian Day School".

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Re: New School - Douglas Reserve

Further to my letter of May 26th, I am enclosing Supt. Gillett's letter of the same date with questionnaire relative to the proposed school on the Douglas Reserve, a sketch showing the location of the school site and a resolution of the Band setting aside the area for school use.

Mr. Gillett informed me that the Indians of the Band would be leaving the Reserve shortly for berry picking and it would be desirable to have the school site and access thereto cleared before they left, and further that they were badly in need of employment and that work in connection with this clearing would tide them over until berry picking started. Under the circumstances I have authorized him to incur an expenditure of $150 to pay the Indians on a ration basis and a further expenditure of $150 for the hire of a bulldozer which is available for removing stumps.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

May 10th, 1949.

We, the undersigned, Chief and Councillors of the Douglas Band of Indians owning the Reserve situated at Port Douglas, in the New Westminster Indian Agency, in the Province of British Columbia, at a council summoned for the purpose, according to the rules of the Band, and held on the said Reserve, this Tenth day of May, A.D. 1949, in the presence of the Indian Agent for the said Reserve, representing thereat the Minister of Mines and Resources for the Dominion of Canada;

Do hereby for ourselves, and on behalf of the Indian owners of the said Reserve, request that a sum not exceeding $250 be paid out of money standing to the credit of this Band; for the purpose of setting aside approximately two acres for the Indian Day School proposed on said Reserve, commencing at a post planted 52.14 chains in a southerly direction following the road along the shore line from the North-West corner post of the most northerly part of the said Reserve; thence six chains in an Easterly direction to No. 1 post of the selected lot; thence North or northerly 4 chains; thence East or Easterly 5 chains; thence South or Southerly 4 chains; thence West or Westerly 5 chains to point of commencement, as shown on the attached plan.

And we hereby certify that this resolution was approved by a majority of the male voting members of the Band.

With reference to Mr. Burn's letter of July 13, regarding the desire of this Department to purchase the above-mentioned townsite, our Superintendent in New Westminster has recommended that we purchase the entire 68.4 acres of the townsite or whatever lesser area is available.

The two prints received with your letter are returned herewith and we have indicated thereon the lots in which we are particularly interested for the reason that we are presently negotiating with the Tretheway Creek Timber Company Limited for purchase of their camp buildings situated on these lots which we proposed to use for Indian homes, a Day School, and teacher's residence. Re: Proposed Port Douglas Indian Day School - #790

With reference to Mr. Henry's letter of June 13, regarding the acquisition of buildings from the Tretheway Creek Timber Company Limited for school use and for Indian housing, Mr. Gillett was recently advised that the company had additional buildings for disposal and, although we hesitated to confuse the matter at this late date, having in mind that steps were being taken by the Department to acquire the buildings referred to in my letter of May 26, nevertheless, District School Inspector Davey and Mr. Gillett visited the Reserve and secured the information detailed in Mr. Gillett's letter of July 29 attached.

Mr. Gillett's submission is very complete and there is no need to enlarge further on it here, but I would point out that we have here an opportunity of securing a number of buildings for school use and for Indian homes at considerably less than their original value. I do not wish to delay arrangements for opening the new Douglas School in September, but in the absence of information with regard to progress made by the Department in securing authority for acquisition of the buildings referred to in my first communication, I feel that the Department should be advised that these additional buildings are now available, and, if at all possible, we should endeavour to make funds available to the extent
of $8,950.00 from the Education Vote for the purpose of school use, and $7,200.00 from the Welfare Vote for the purchase of buildings for Indian homes. You will note that the expenditure recommended from the Education Vote includes purchase of the lighting plant and a water system. I should add, at this time, that we are presently corresponding with the Provincial Department of Lands with a view to acquiring the land on which these buildings are situated, comprising 68 odd acres, known as the Douglas Town site. Acquisition will obviate the necessity of moving the buildings and will provide additional lands for the Skookum Chuk Band who, as a matter of fact, live at Douglas a good part of the year.

I regret that our negotiations with the Province have not proceeded to the extent that we can go into any detail with regard to the purchase of this land. But the matter should be clarified within the next week or two. We feel confident that we will be able to acquire the land, but even if we do not, the removal of the buildings will not present any great obstacle.

W.S. Arneil

Re: New School - Fort Douglas Reserve

I am forwarding Superintendent Gillett's letter of May 19th, from which you will note that the Trethewey Creek Timber Company Ltd. have for disposal five buildings in the vicinity of the Douglas Reserve, two or three of which might provide adequate school facilities for several years.

The four-room cabin which apparently is Mr. Trethewey's personal property, 44 ft. long by 14 ft. wide, will provide suitable accommodation for the teacher and according to Mr. Gillett, is well worth the $4500.00 asked, which amount is considerably less than it would cost the Department to erect a residence. The other building which goes with the house, 12 ft. by 16 ft., could be used for fuel storage and one of the other three camp buildings, 14 ft. by 32 ft., the property of the Logging Company, although somewhat narrow for classroom use, will, according to District School Inspector Devey with whom I discussed the matter, provide adequately for the available pupilage at Douglas, which apparently, at the moment, is seventeen.

The total price asked for the five buildings is $8500.00, this price to include their removal onto the Reserve to selected sites.

The two buildings 14 ft. by 32 ft., not required for school use, can be used for Indian homes which are sorely needed on the Douglas Reserve and having in mind that our appropriation for new school construction will be seriously depleted by expenditures necessary for the completion of school buildings, the erection of which was started last year, it appears to me that
the opportunity to purchase these buildings should not be overlooked, as it will enable us to provide adequate school facilities for considerably less than half the cost which would otherwise be incurred. A portion of the cost would of course be chargeable to the Housing Division of the Welfare Vote and the balance could be met from the appropriation for new school construction at Douglas.

May I please have the Department's views with regard to this proposal at an early date, as I do not anticipate that the buildings will be held for our disposal for very long.

Re: Water for Douglas School

There is a creek situated approximately 800 feet from the site. The creek comes down the mountain almost perpendicularly. We would recommend a 1000 gallon tank placed 100 feet up and 3" stave pipe.

The tank can be purchased from Canadian Wood Pipe and Tanks Limited, Vancouver, for $85.00. The 3" wood pipe would cost $61.50 per 100 feet. Labor for installation of the pipe, digging the ditch and erecting the tank should not exceed $100.00. Twenty dollars should be allowed for extra galvanized pipe and elbows, etc., making a total cost of approximately $700.00.

Re: Water System
Douglas Indian Day School #790

Attached are requisitions covering the materials required to install a water system for the Douglas Indian Day School, Port Douglas.

It is our plan to install a 1000 gallon water tank at an elevation of about 75 feet and from that position run 3 inch pipe for a distance of 575 feet to the school, at which point we will have half inch galvanized pipe connecting with the school and the teachersage. The source of water is from a mountain water fall which is constant throughout the year.

We have discussed this installation with Mr. Robertson at the Water Power Bureau who advises us that these materials would be satisfactory.

We have contacted both Wood Pipes & Tanks Ltd. and Marshall-Wells (Westminster) Ltd. and obtained the necessary quotations, copies of which are attached to the requisitions. It is recommended that purchase be made as soon as possible as we would like to install the units before the severe weather sets in. It will be done by day labor - not contract.

It is estimated that it will take about $250.00 for labor costs in digging the ditches and installing the pipe and we, therefore, request an accountable advance for this amount be forwarded. Herewith in duplicate please find a requisition for water pipe and water line materials for completing the connection of waterworks into the teacher's residence at Douglas Indian Reserve. The materials can be purchased from Marshall-Wells (Westminster) Ltd., at the prices indicated which are wholesale.

In our original order for water line materials we were not aware that the house fixtures (bathroom and sink) were connected to drains by means of rubber hose pipes and since this is the case it is essential that sink traps and extra piping be supplied.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are thirty-seven (37) Indian children of school age on the Neskainilith (Aniskamillith) Indian Reserve, in the Kamloops Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom educational facilities are required;

THAT funds are available in Vote 218, 1948-49, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a day school for these children.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that a day school be established on the Neskainilith (Aniskamillith) Indian Reserve, in the Kamloops Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 96, 1927, to be known as the "Neskainilith Indian Day School".

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

Re: Neskainlith Indian Day School
Your File 0-11-3 (154)

This Office was very surprised to note the contents of your letter dated October 12th, concerning the enrolment at the above-mentioned School.

You are undoubtedly aware that there are a number of children in your Agency at present not attending school and for whom the only possible solution for providing an education is enrolment in a Residential school. For example, I was informed last June that there were 32 children of school age in the Hat Creek area of whom only 12 were enrolled in any school. You are also aware that the Kamloops Residential School serves not only your own Agency but also parts of the Okanagan, Nicola, Lytton and Williams Lake agencies. In these areas there are a number of children who should be in attendance at the Kamloops Residential School, either because of home conditions or the lack of educational facilities close to their homes.

It is the responsibility of the Superintendent to see that the best possible use is made of the school facilities in his Agency. He should not permit the enrolment of pupils in a Residential school when there are adequate Day school facilities provided for them, particularly when there are a number of children denied admission to a Residential school who have no other means of receiving an education. I therefore request that you secure the immediate discharge of pupils now enrolled at the Kamloops Residential School who should attend the Neskainlith Indian Day School and secure the admission of an equivalent number of pupils who should be enrolled at the Kamloops Residential School, either...
because of the lack of Day school facilities on their reserves or whose home conditions make their admission desirable.

Kindly inform us as to what action you have taken, including the number of discharges from the Kamloops School and the number of pupils on the roll at the Neskonlith School when these discharges are effected.

Big Sister to the Indians

By ALIXE CARTER

Twenty-eight years alone among northern Manitoba Indians in a work of service has developed behind Sister Patricia, now at the Indian school opposite Chase, east of Kenora.

Sister Patricia belongs to the third working secular order. She had been engaged in service, and it was only her circumstances that brought her to a milder climate where she could apply for work among the Indians. After three months at Vancouver, she spent two years at the school in Vernon. Then to Chase where she was engaged last year in the care of patients and their parents.

Yet her eyes shine with old memories at mention of Beers River, where she worked among the Sioux tribes near Lake Winnipegosis. Sister Patricia has taught seven years, laboring sometimes day and night as a nurse and doctor, among two hundred Indians.

Due to their poverty and primitive houses, pneumonia was the Indian's most formidable and most worrying experience was to nurse and keep the disease from spreading. Once the patient was taken to the Indian Department would arrive and check. Sister Patricia would seek his advice and learn much from her experiences.

Indian children usually left school when they were too young for them to continue.

She has made a unique contribution by translating religious texts to the form of a Santeux-English primer. It is divided one to six. She started teaching English to children arrived at school speaking only Sioux. She taught them for years to teach them the language and to enable English subjects.

The Indian children usually left school when they were too young for them to continue.

Besides being an expert with traps and search for the scent or paddle, she was a tireless rider of a Canadian pony and an adequate handler of a dog team. One of her greatest adventures was to ride twenty-three miles on horseback with a pack of timber wolves. The raven was the wisest bird of all.

When winter would come earlier than usual in northern Manitoba the supply boat from Selkirk would not be able to reach her and she would live all winter without meat, potatoes, cabbage, hard tack and flour. She had no firewood except the timber corporations was a part husky, part collie dog called "Milo" who was very faithful and confided her troubles.

At her school Sister Patricia is assisted by natives from her Indian neighbors but she can look across the river to the town of Kenora and the Trans-Canada Highway. However, she must reach her pupils by canoe.

Few women could have survived the rigors of the climate she attributes her ability to cope with the difficulties of her training as a Girl Guide in England. She is a member of the Timber wolf and game country.

And as each passed he whispered, "You are of course the wisest bird of all, but you must not say so to anyone that I have said so...if you were to say so..."

When the birds talked together afterwards, the raven said, "I was wrong and that the raven was the wisest bird of them all."

Big Sister to the Indians

By ALIXE CARTER

Twenty-eight years alone among northern Manitoba Indians in a work of intense volunteer service. Sister Patricia, now at the Indian school opposite Chase, east of Kindersley.

Sister Patricia belongs to the third working secular order of the Sisters of St. Joseph. She entered the service, and it was only her rigorous outdoor life in the north which brought her to a milder climate when she became ill. After studying for work among the Indians of the Kindersley district, and spending two years at Vancouver, she went back to Kindersley. Then to Chase where she works entirely without pay, caring for the Indians and their parents.

The three wives shine with old memories at mention of Bevens River, the home of the Southern tribes near Lake Winnipegosis. Sister Patricia has been there seventeen years, laboring sometimes under very trying conditions. She has taught, nursed and doctor, among two hundred Indians, many of whom are now dead.

Due to their poverty and primitive houses, pneumonia was the Indians' greatest enemy. Her worst and most worrying experience was seeing six diphtheria cases and keeping the disease from spreading. The Indian Department would arrive only after the sickness had run its course. Sister Patricia would seek his advice and help, and carry him through another year of unforeseen illness among her people.

She has made a unique contribution to Canadian educational texts to the form of a School Textbook Dictionary for grades one to six. She discovered that the children during her teaching days, for the children could not read or speak English. It took three years of hard work to make a dictionary sufficiently well for them to tackle easily.

At the end of grade eight the Indian children usually attend school, but the family being too poor for them to continue.

Then came the hunters and trappers and search for the next spring's supply of meat in the winter months. Before the second World War, Sister Patricia bought a pony from China for this medical need, but during the war disappeared, this one and others.

When winter would come, the Indians would travel by canoe from Manitoba the supply boat from Selkirk would not be able to reach her and she would have to find a way to get her frozen potatoes, cabbage, hard tack and flour. Her best friend and most faithful companion was a horse named Mike. She spoke to Mike whom she talked and confided her troubles.

Besides being an expert with ears or paws she was also an expert of a strictly religious pony and an adequate guide and a good horse of her own. She rode Mike, followed by a pack of dogs, and her lover fathered, as though he understood the distance and the manner of travel through to their destination.

Patricia could have survived the life she had led, and she attributes much of her training as a Girl Guide to her experiences. She is an excellent shot, so necessary in timber wolf and game hunting.

A great reader, letter writer and conversationalist, she managed to combat loneliness through the years. Her only weakness is an inability to follow three-and-a-half-hour lectures.

Garbed in a brown monk's habit and a blue veil. Her hair is unshorn. Ordinarily she would wear a longer veil many years ago she found a long one got in her way while she was working and got her Archbishop's permission to shorten it. She wears rubber boots which she has specially made for her.

At her school Sister Patricia is several miles from her Indian neighbors. She lives in a house overlooking the river and sees Chase, the CFR and the Trans-Canada Highway. She lives in a house with a full basement, modern furnace, beauty, comfort and friendliness.

One of her treasures is a scrap book containing pictures sent by the Sioux, many of the herbs being extremely efficacious and easy to grow. She says she keeps a warm pair of mitts from the cold nights.

Sister Patricia's strong conviction is that Indians are the most most courteous people in the world. She says the Indians are more patient and persevering than the whites ever were. Only twice in her ten years experience has she had to reprimand an Indian child.

22 JUNE 1948

The Committee of the Privy Council, having before them a report dated 5th June, 1948, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Neskatinith (Aniskamith) Indian Reserve, Kootenay Indian Agency in the Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Neskatinith (Aniskamith) Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 142, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) or pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest";

NOW, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely, Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 409, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,350.00 F.O.B., Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses;

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above referred and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the erection of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that the work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the new school term commences.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Neskonlith (Aniskamllith) Indian Reserve, Kamloops Indian Agency in the Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Neskonlith (Aniskamllith) Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . . . .";

THAT due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,550.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses.

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exemption provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: New Day School - Neskainlith Reserve

Will you please forward as soon as possible an accountable advance of $3,000 to Mr. Bruce to enable him to meet labour costs and costs of other services, trucking, etc., in connection with the erection of the new day school on the Neskainlith Reserve.

W.S. Arneil,

AIR MAIL

June 16th, 1949.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

On receipt of your letter of June 9th, suggesting the transfer of Sister Patricia from the Okanagan Indian Day School to the Neskainlith Indian Day School, I reviewed our files and unless some mistake has been made in this office, there does not appear to be any correspondence indicating that the Neskainlith School has been completed.

The last correspondence we have in connection with the construction of the building, is a Credit Voucher from Indian Superintendent Bruce which reached us on March 29th, 1949. We do not appear to have received any requisition for furnishings for the teacher's living quarters.

In order that our file may be complete, we would appreciate it very much if you would arrange to have Superintendent Bruce submit a complete report at the earliest possible date.

Philip Phelan,
PP/ST Chief, Education Division

Re: Neskainlith Day School

I am enclosing herewith requisitions covering school desks, teacher's desk and chair, furnishings for the teacherage and janitor supplies for the above-mentioned school which is to be opened in September.

The desks, primary table and chairs and teacher's desk and chair can be purchased in Vancouver at a cost of approximately $488.00.

It is recommended that authority be granted to arrange for purchase of the items as requested on the requisitions.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Nesquinlith Indian Day School

In my letter to you of May 31st, regarding our school construction program, I suggested that an amount of $3,650.00 would be required to complete the above-mentioned school, but that the matter would be the subject of a further communication at a later date. Owing to difficulty encountered by Superintendent Bruce in securing what we considered to be a suitable heating installation, I have been unable until now to advise exactly what funds would be required. We now have for consideration the attached tender from Carr & Son, covering the installation of an adequate warm air heating system, at a cost of $775.00 which I would recommend for acceptance.

In addition to this amount, the following expenditures will be required to complete the school -

1. Plumbing fixtures, as per quotation from Carr & Son dated April 20th, attached.................. $360.00
2. Labour for installation of rough plumbing and fixtures................................. $345.00
3. Painting material and labour........................................... $445.60
4. Carpenter work...................................................... $2000.00
5. Deep well pump..................................................... $50.00

It will be apparent from the above that the cost of completing this School will be approximately $4090.00 and I would ask that funds to this extent be made available and that an accountable advance of $2000.00 be forwarded to
Mr. Bruce so that the building may be completed and ready for occupancy September 1st.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are twenty-eight (28) Indian children of school age on the North Thompson Indian Reserve, in the Kamloops Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom educational facilities are required;

THAT funds are available in Vote 216, 1948-49, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a day school for these children.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that a day school be established on the North Thompson Indian Reserve, Kamloops Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 98, 1927, to be known as the "North Thompson Indian Day School".

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1945-46 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the North Thompson Indian Reserve, Kamloops Indian Agency, in the Province of British Columbia.

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the North Thompson Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:-

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any department of the Government the minister having charge of such department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . . . .";

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box A89, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,550.00 f.o.b., Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses.

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE, 1945, ON KWAWEWLTH INDIAN AGENCY

Education

If some temporary arrangement can be worked out, it is my intention to request the Department to open a Day School at Gilford Island and another at Turnour Island. Many children reside at both these villages but are without an opportunity of receiving an education. It is hoped the Department will keep this constantly in mind as I am very much concerned over the lack of educational facilities for so many bright Indian youngsters.

M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.
QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945, ON KWAKWELTH AGENCY

Education

The work in all schools referred to in my last report is being carried on satisfactorily. The attendance is exceptionally good when the families are home. In some cases the families have been living at Imperial Cannery, Steveston, working for the B.C. Packers. While the families are there, the children attend the white school through an arrangement made by this office and company officials with the school board. It is hoped that a School Inspector for the Indian Affairs Branch will be appointed and instructed to visit this agency at an early date, as the planning for the erection of new schools is being held up pending the new School Inspector's report on same to the Department. Personally I can see no need in having our plans held up pending the arrival of a School Inspector, because his report can only be arrived at after obtaining the needed information from this office, which can be readily given by myself. If the appointment of a school Inspector is delayed too long it will mean that we will not have sufficient time to plan and make the necessary arrangements to have the schools built this year. Two new schools are desperately needed - one at Turnour Island and another at Gwayasdums Reserve. In these two villages there are many children without an opportunity to be educated. This matter has been kept before the Department for sometime past, and I plead with the Department to make every effort to see that these schools are provided during the coming summer so that they may open at the beginning of the fall term. A special report is being made in connection with Gwayasdums Reserve.

M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.

Re: Port Military Camp
Your file 568-E-2 (E.1)

I recently had an opportunity of discussing with Superintendent Todd utilization of the remaining buildings at the above mentioned camp and he has advanced a proposal involving demolition of the buildings and removal of the materials to Gilford Island for the erection of Indian homes and our proposed new Day School at this point. Mr. Todd proposes to employ Indian labour on a day basis for demolition of the buildings, to rent a barge and to utilize Indian seine boats for hauling the barge between Fort Hardy and Gilford Island when such boats are in port over the weekend. He estimates that it will cost $600.00 to salvage and deliver to Gilford Island sufficient material for one average Indian home. As erection costs will be taken care of by the Indians themselves in most cases, and if his estimate is reasonably close the proposal is certainly economically sound. We were unable during our discussion to go into any great detail regarding the school building, but salvage and use of the materials for this purpose should be equally economical.

With regard to financing the work, there is a balance of approximately $10,000 of the appropriation for new housing, Anawakwah Agency, and so that the work may be proceeded with while the weather is good and Indian labour available I would ask that an initial advance of $5,000 from Vote 515, Allotment 13 be forwarded to Mr. Todd.
With regard to the school construction part of the program, I note from Mr. Phelan's letter of June 27th that transfer of $20,000 for Gilford Island has been recommended to the Treasury Board. Will you please have an initial advance of $3,000 of this amount forwarded to Mr. Todd.

If at all possible, I should appreciate a communication from you by wire as to whether or not this proposal is approved so that work may be commenced immediately, and if necessary, prior to the receipt of the advances requested.

W.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Turnour Island Indian Day School

Superintendent Todd visited this office recently at which time I discussed with him the question of completing the various Indian Day School buildings in his Agency, construction of which was proceeded with to various stages in each case by the Lands and Development Services Branch prior to March 31st.

A copy of my letter of June 8th to Mr. Todd following our discussion is enclosed for your information together with his letter of June 16th regarding completion of the Turnour Island day school. We have yet to secure from Mr. Todd an estimate of the cost of completing the Alert Bay day school and although I had hoped to be able to advise you the total amount of funds which should be transferred from some other project for the completion of schools in the Kwawkewlth Agency, rather than delay the matter further I would recommend that an amount of $3000 be made available now for completion of the Campbell River and Turnour Island day schools, but in the absence of information with respect to the specific provisions made for school construction at various points this year cannot suggest from which proposed school the funds should be transferred.

Mr. Todd, in his letter attached, requests an accountable advance of $2500 for the Turnour Island School. It is thought that this amount will be in excess of his requirements as part of the estimated cost is for material. I would recommend that an advance of $2000 be forwarded to him as soon as possible. The completion of the Alert Bay Day school will be the subject of a separate communication at an early date.

RE: TURNOUR ISLAND DAY SCHOOL

As requested in your letter of June 8th last, file #6-13-3
and later during our conversation in Vancouver, I have now located
two White carpenters who will undertake the completion of this school
at an hourly rate of $1.40, plus living allowance allowed. These two
carpenters have just left Englewood where they have been working and
have offered to do this work for us before going to Vancouver providing
we can give them a reply within a week.

I have carefully perused Turnour Island project and am satisfied
it can be completed within the estimate of $2500.00. I made a trip to
Turnour Island yesterday to check on the material on the spot and find
that some is missing.

Although no orders or vouchers passed through this office; never-
theless, I am of the opinion that the blackboards and rails for same for
this school were purchased and shipped to Port Hardy. During my visit
yesterday I could not locate any blackboards and would therefore suggest
that you 'phone the Surveys and Engineering Branch and ascertain whether
these blackboards were purchased and if so, where they are stored. If
they have no knowledge of same, then order sufficient blackboards for the
school immediately.

I also found other materials short but will try and locate them
at the Army Camp. There is no galvanized pipe to install the plumbing.
There is none in storage any place and this will have to be purchased.
Please 'phone Col. Whyte and ask him to give you an estimate of how much
pipe and the size required and arrange to have it purchased in Vancouver
and shipped to me at Alert Bay. All other fittings can be procurred out
of stores here.

p.t.o.
I do not know if you have been advised what funds have been provided for schools as yet, but as this is our only chance of getting this school completed and have it ready for September 1st, I would kindly ask that you communicate with Ottawa, if necessary, and obtain approval for the expenditure of $2500.00, and have the accountable cheque for this amount forwarded this office. These men will wait for their money a short time but it is necessary to receive approval to proceed within a week, in which case I will start the men and the money can be forwarded thereafter.

The men I refer to above will finish all the carpentry work, install the electrical wiring and paint the building. I will have to get someone else to do the plumbing, but this can be done after the other work is completed.

I am writing at some length because it is necessary that we have immediate action on this and obtain the Department's approval to go ahead, otherwise I can hold out no hope of having the school ready for September 1st, and for this reason I am asking you to communicate with Ottawa by wire to obtain their approval so that we will not take any chance of not having the school ready.

Time sheets will be prepared and men paid from this office, so please arrange to have the accountable cheque forwarded as quickly as possible, and any unexpended balance would, of course, be returned to the Department.

(W. S. Todd)

RE: TURNOUR ISLAND SCHOOL

Since I have received a request to take charge and supervise the completion of the Turnour Island School and Teacherage, I have perused the concluding report of the Surveys and Engineering Branch which was submitted at the end of the fiscal year when they closed down work on this project. I have also inspected the work done and wish to make the following report.

When the Department approved of the construction of this school they requested School Inspector Davey and myself to visit the village and pick out a suitable site. This we did during 1947 prior to any construction being undertaken. A few years ago the Department, with the cooperation of the Indians, built a good domestic water system. At that time we located a natural spring up a ravine a short distance from the village. A dam was built and the water was piped to the village. This was done without the services of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, who were not called upon at that time. Since the site was particularly kept in mind having the school and teacherage located in a position whereby it would not be higher than our dam, so that the water could gravity feed into the school, the same as in the homes in the village. We also picked an alternative site in case the Engineers found the first choice was too high.

Before going on sick leave I went to Mr. McClure who was in charge of the construction for the Surveys and Engineering Branch and requested him to check on the height to see if such that the water could gravity feed into the new school. I also told him that the Chief and other principal members of the band assisted Inspector Davey and myself and knew the exact sites we had chosen, and to see them before starting construction if there was any doubt as to the location. It was particularly emphasized the importance of having the right site to that we could get water to the school.

When I returned to duty I found that Mr. McClure had never checked to see whether water could reach the school - in fact, he built the school in a different site entirely, further up on a hill and now it is impossible to get water into the school from our present water system unless the Department goes to some expense of installing a pump and tank or finding a new supply of water which could be gravity fed to the school.

In the Surveys and Engineering Branch final report they give the impression this school and teacherage is practically completed and that the work can be finished by Indians. The facts are four walls were built and the roof put on. The exterior carpentry work is not completed neither is the painting. Only a few panels on the interior were temporarily nailed up. These were done in such a manner that they will all have to be removed as none of them fit. The floor has not been finished. No interior panels, insulation, partitions or that portion of the teacherage or school room have been installed. In fact, most of the school has yet to be built. The engineers have suggested that the plumbing, wiring and finishing, which is always considered technical and skilled work, be done by Indians. This is their recommendation.

p.t.o.
The original plan of the school was to have the classroom facing south and the teacherage built in the north end of the building. For some unknown reason the whole plan of this school was changed so that the classroom was put on the north end of the building thus reducing maximum light in the classroom, and the teacherage built on the south end. The living-room and kitchen of the plan received a few days ago shows that they face the forest. These two rooms should face the sea.

If the Surveys and Engineering Branch did not intend to complete this project and were going to ask the Indian Affairs Branch to complete same, why did they not say so when they closed down construction work?

When the Indians learned the work on this school was discontinuing, they came to me and offered to work saying they would wait for their money, if necessary, and pointed out that they had time before going fishing to complete the work. I informed the Indians at that time that the work was slowing down only on account of it being the end of our fiscal year and that assurance had been given me through the Commissioner's Office that the work would be resumed in the new fiscal year and the school completed by the Surveys and Engineering Branch in time for opening on September 1st. The Indians are now going fishing and nothing has been done in regard to finishing the school, and I have been requested to take over the work and have it completed.

The Engineering Branch, if they have any plans, have not submitted them in respect to the plumbing and wiring. I also find we are short some materials which will have to be purchased.

If the Department will give me authority to go ahead and finish the school without referring it to the engineers, which would only delay completion, and provide sufficient money, I will undertake to complete it and have it ready for September 1st. This is going to be very difficult without necessary Agency staff, but I will do my best under the circumstances.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent

RE: TURNOUR ISLAND INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

As the Department is aware, this school was built in a location by the Surveys and Engineering Branch other than that arranged by School Inspector Davey and myself. The location chosen by the Surveys and Engineering Branch would not permit water reaching the school from the village domestic water system. It was, therefore, necessary to build a dam farther up the mountain in order to gravity feed water to the school.

This winter while the Indians were home they offered to do this work, and as this was the only opportunity we had, I arranged for them to do same. The work is now nearly completed and I attach hereto pay sheets covering wages for the month of March, 1949, together with vouchers #355-#364, and would kindly ask that the Department approve of this and forward individual cheques as per vouchers attached to this office for transmission to the Indians concerned.

Acknowledging your letter of April 21st last, file #794-5(E.1),
I beg to advise you as follows:

Turnour Island School was built by the Engineers in a location
other than determined by School Inspector Davey and myself, thus
depriving the school of a domestic water supply from the village
domestic water system. Last year the Department provided funds to
complete the school which included plumbing and wiring for electric
lights. Indians were asked to finish this project. We completed
the school with the exception of the plumbing and electric wiring,
as agreed; but when the school teacher arrived with his family and
found there was no water available and that it had to be carried in
a pail for some considerable distance, they refused to stay unless
a water system was put in.

I was, therefore, faced with taking some action, and the late
Col. Whyte of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, and Commissioner
Arneil visited the school during 1948 during construction. The late
Col. Whyte stated the only solution was to build another dam farther
up the mountain and connect it with the present system, thus giving
sufficient height for water to gravity feed into the school. Rather
than put in the electric lights and sewerage system out of the funds
made available, I used some of this money to build this new dam
employing Indians to carry out the work. As we had to do the work
when Indian labour was available, the work was proceeded with during
the month of March.

I informed the Indians I did not have sufficient funds to
complete the job, and they said rather than not see the water system
put into the school, they would continue working and wait for their
money, if necessary, so long as I guaranteed they would be paid
eventually. As it was near the end of the fiscal year, there was

p.t.o.
not sufficient time for me to place the matter before the Department and complete it, and as the Indians would not be available later, it was imperative that we proceed at once.

The whole project is now practically completed and in a few days we will have water in the school. On April 26th last Commissioner Arneil and School Inspector Davey visited Turnour Island Indian Day School, and Commissioner Arneil saw what we had accomplished, and I think was pleased with the work of the Indians and what we have accomplished for the expenditure.

During the end of our fiscal year I discussed this matter with the Commissioner's Office and they advised me to forward my accounts up to the end of the year and write a covering letter, which I did. I cannot give you exactly the amount still owing on this project as I have not received the payroll as yet. We have had to buy two hundred lineal feet of 1/2" galvanized pipe and a few fittings. This, together with the payroll will be the total cost of the balance due. I shall give you a further report in a few days when the project is finished.

In addition to this approximately $500.00 will have to be provided to put in our sewerage and plumbing in the school itself together with the wiring of the building for electric lights. This will complete Turnour Island School, and I believe will turn out to be one of the cheapest schools and teacherage the Department have built in the Province.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.

This will acknowledge receipt of Airmail letter dated May 11th last, file #794-5 (E.1) relative to Turnour Island Indian Day School, received from the Superintendent of Education.

In my letter dated May 3rd, 1949, sent direct to Ottawa, copy of which was forwarded your office, I stated it would take approximately $500.00 to complete the sewerage, plumbing and electrical installation. Since then I have had time to go into the cost more thoroughly and find it will take approximately $700.00 to complete the above work.

As this school has been built almost entirely by Indians who, incidently, have done a splendid job; I am now most anxious that it be completed before the fishing season starts. Yesterday Mr. Tom Smith, who has been our foreman on the construction work and is a very capable man, checked very carefully with me the small amount of materials required to be purchased that cannot be supplied from the Army Camp Stores, together with the cost of labour. As near as we can estimate the total expenditure to complete the school will be as above stated, and I am requesting the Department to give immediate approval for the expenditure of $700.00 to cover this work.

I am not asking for an accountable advance but rather authority to proceed with the work and submit vouchers covering the expenditure. Mr. Tom Smith and Oly Shaughnessy will be installing the plumbing and sewerage. These Indians have a short time available to do the work before starting fishing and it is imperative that we act quickly otherwise nothing can be done until next November when the fishing season is over. The teacher and his family will be remaining at the village all summer and I feel we owe it to them to make this installation at once, particularly when we have the water now in the school and there is nothing to prevent us from proceeding with the work.

April 4th, 1950

Following is a copy of a telegram received from Supt. Todd on April 3rd from which you will note that he has an opportunity of having additional playground space cleared by a bulldozer at the Turnour Island Day School at an approximate cost of $650.00:

"Caterpillar now available to clear site for Turner Island Day School playground which is essential. This school cost Six Hundred and Fifty Dollars recommend this expenditure and accountable advance for above amount be forwarded from next year's appropriation after April first caterpillar leaving district in few days only opportunity this year Wire reply."

This is one of several urgent requests for funds received from Mr. Todd since early in March and why these matters could not have been attended to prior to that time we do not know.

In the case of the Turnour Island Day School playground, we knew and Mr. Todd knew prior to March that there was a bulldozer in the vicinity but we were not aware that additional clearing at Turnour Island was necessary. The fact remains, however, that if we do not take advantage of the availability of the bulldozer it may be another year before an opportunity presents. I would recommend that if possible the Department approve the expenditure requested and I have no doubt that if funds cannot be made immediately available arrangements for payment of the cost later in the month could be made. If the expenditure is approved we will advise the Department of the name of the owner of the bulldozer and the operating cost when this information is received from Mr. Todd.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

In your letter dated March 8th, file 156/6-1-794 you informed this office the Department had approved an expenditure of $700.00 for clearing and levelling playgrounds in the above mentioned school.

It is regretted due to an oversight this work was not undertaken before the year end. I am now informed a caterpillar will be available later this spring, and I am recommending that approval be given for an expenditure of $700.00 for clearing and levelling these playgrounds and that this office be advised so that arrangements could be made to have the work done when the caterpillar is available.

(W. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Turnour Island Indian Day School.

I sent you an army signal message on April 13th regarding the clearing of playground space at the Turnour Island school and advised that the expenditure of $700.00 approved in your message of March 8th was sufficient and that a voucher would be submitted in time for payment from last year's funds.

This advice was based on information received by telephone from Mr. Todd, but his letter of April 17th, attached indicates that he was misinformed as apparently no clearing had been done and funds will be required to meet the cost of the work this year. Mr. Todd anticipates that a bulldozer will again be available in the vicinity of Turnour Island and in order that we may take advantage of this would ask that an accountable advance of $700.00 be forwarded to him.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Turnour Island Indian Day School, Your File 156/6-1-794

We have your letter of the 8th instant with reference to clearing playground space at the above school. It is noted that Superintendent Todd wishes to clear approximately 2 acres at a cost of over $600.00.

Why is it necessary to clear so much ground for the playground? A considerably smaller space should be sufficient. No funds were specifically provided for this purpose in the current year's appropriation. However, we are prepared to allow an amount not exceeding $176.00. This would mean that he could use the bulldozer and operator for two days during which time it should be possible to clear sufficient land for a playground for this school.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Turnour Island Day School

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of June 14th (file 794-5) regarding the clearing of playground space at the above mentioned school, the Provincial Dept. of Education ordinarily requires three to five acres of playground space for a two-room school. An addition to the proposed one room school at Turnour Island is contemplated within the next few years and it is considered that sufficient playground space might as well be cleared at this time.

If it is a matter of securing funds, we do not anticipate that the whole amount provided for the two-room school at Gilford Island will be expended and $600 could be transferred from this source.

W. S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Agent McAllan believes that there should be day schools under R.C. auspices at Stoney Creek and Stewart Lake. This would release more space in Fraser Lake Residential School for children from reserves not large enough to warrant day school activity.

Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: your file No. 163-1-1 (WT 1)

With reference to your letter of September 20th and further to my report of October 12th last in connection with the truancy situation at Lejac Indian Residential School. I wish to advise that Adanas Alexis of the Stony Creek Band, one of the parents who failed to return his children to School, and also influenced and prevented others from doing so, was prosecuted by Corporal L.F. Fielder of the local detachment of the R.C.M.P., and fined $2.00 and costs.

Following the prosecution, Corporal Fielder and Farming Instructor Andros made numerous patrols involving considerable time and expense, and apprehended and conveyed a number of absentees to the School. The School quota has now been reached, and the Reverend Principal advises that he can only accommodate about four more children.

May I suggest that the Department forward a letter to the Officer Commanding the R.C.M.P. at Vancouver, B.C., commending the services, tact and good judgement rendered by Corporal Fielder in carrying out a disagreeable and difficult task.

The majority of the Stony Creek Band are extremely bitter and resentful at having to return their children to the Residential School. I have had several meetings and many delegations from the Band in this connection, urging that a Day School be established on the reserve. In view of the attitude of the Stony Creek Band towards the local Indian residential School, and the fact that there are considerable number of children at home between the ages of 7 and 16 years who are not receiving an education, I would strongly urge the establishment of a Day School at the earliest possible date.

The Band are most anxious to cooperate and agree to turn over the Band recreation hall for School purposes, until such time as the Department is in the position to construct a new building. The hall was constructed last year, and with some minor alterations, it would be quite suitable for the purpose.

I would appreciate having the Department's attitude towards the proposal so that I may be in the position to advise the Band.

R. Howe,
Indian Agent.
