Ottawa, 26 November 1946.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have received a letter from Indian Agent Howe in connection with the truancy situation at Lejac Indian Residential School. We gave him authority to enforce the compulsory clause of the Act as a number of children from the Stony Creek Band did not return to the Lejac Residential School upon the expiry of their summer holidays.

The School has now reached its quota and Mr. Howe recommends that the Officer Commanding at Vancouver, B.C., be advised that we appreciated the services tact and good judgment rendered by Cpl. Fielder. Please convey our appreciation in this regard.

We wrote you recently regarding the situation that developed with the Stony Creek Indians. Evidently they are insistent that a day school be established on their reserve and Mr. Howe states they are prepared to turn over their recreation hall to be used for school purposes until such time as the Department is in a position to construct a new building. The Agent states that the hall, with some minor alterations would be quite suitable for school purposes.

Please let us have your comments on Mr. Howe's suggestion. Possibly it would be preferable to let the matter stand until the new inspector has an opportunity to visit the Stuart Lake Agency. The question of securing a teacher also arises. The 1944 census shows that all members of the Stony Creek Band are listed as Roman Catholics. Would it be possible to secure a Roman Catholic teacher in the event of this school being opened in the band's hall? Mr. Howe has not supplied any information
regarding living quarters for a teacher.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 163-1-1 (W.T.I.)

I have your letter of November 26th in which you refer to the truancy situation at the Lejac Indian Residential School, and the question of establishing a day school on the Stony Indian Reserve.

In regard to the first mentioned item it would appear that the situation has been composed to some extent, for the time being at any rate, the school having reached its quota.

With respect to the matter of establishing a day school at the Stony Reserve, it will be noted that in July last Mr. Indian Agent Howe reported some 249 children of school age in his Agency not attending any school, 21 of whom were from the Stony Creek Reserve. Mr. Howe also showed 41 children from this reserve enrolled at the Lejac Indian Residential school and 44 children under seven years of age at home in the village. It is clear from the information submitted by Mr. Howe that the Lejac Indian Residential School cannot meet the school needs of the Stuart Lake Agency and consequently consideration should be given to the establishment of day schools where indicated to provide the necessary accommodation.

Reverting to the proposed school at Stony Reserve, it is not seen, now that we have entered the second half of the school year, how a school can be organized and the services of a teacher secured and anything worthwhile accomplished before the term ends on June 30th. The writer feels, however, that in view of the situation and the difficulties in securing materials for new school buildings we should take advantage of the offer of the Stony Indians of their recreation hall and make the necessary arrangements for its use for school
purposes. With this in mind I am writing to Mr. Howe requesting the following information:

(1) An estimate of the cost of materials and labour required to make the building suitable for school purposes.

(2) The possibility of securing the services of a qualified Roman Catholic teacher in the area in the event of the school being opened.

(3) The possibility of the teacher securing board and lodging with nearby white settlers and if this is not possible what can be provided in the way of suitable quarters for the teacher on the Reserve.

(4) The number of children of the Stony Creek Band, excluding those in attendance at the Lejac School, available to attend the new school in the event of its being opened.

I will communicate again with the Department on this matter following receipt of Mr. Howe's report.

/EW

D. M. MacKay,

Re: your file No. 218-13-5936.

I wish to refer to your letter dated December 3rd, 1946, which relates to the establishment of a Day School on the Stony Creek I.R. As requested, an estimate of the cost of materials and labour required to make the recreational hall suitable for school purposes is submitted hereunder:

1. Insulated brick siding for sheeting exterior walls - material only ........................................... $447.00
2. 30' brick chimney @ $4.00 per foot including material and labour ........................................... $120.00
3. Heater and stove-pipes ........................................... $28.00

TOTAL ........................................... $692.00

Labour sheeting the buildings will be done by the Band without cost to the Department. The Band have also acquired 5,000 B.F. Shiplap and about $170.00 towards construction of a three room house for use of the teacher. Chief Antoine advises that construction of the house will proceed in the Spring. This project is being undertaken by the Indians on the Band without authority or advice from the Office. It is possible that the Department may have to provide some finishing materials and furnishings for the quarters. In addition to the above, desks and other school equipment will be required. The Department will no doubt have data on hand with respect to cost of desks and school equipment.

There are at present 66 children of school age in the Stony Creek Band. 33 of this number are in attendance at the Lejac Indian Residential School, leaving 33 at home who are not receiving the benefit of an education. Referring to paragraph 4 of your letter, may I point out that in event of the establishment of a Day School on this reserve, it would be very difficult indeed to enforce attendance at Lejac School for those who are now enrolled at Lejac. With the exception of a few orphan and underprivileged children, the parents would undoubtedly insist on the children attending the Day School.

There is no possibility of securing the services of a teacher in this district for the current term, but Mr. J. Wilson, a teacher at one of the local White Schools is interested, and his services can be available for the 1947-48 term, commencing September 1st next. Mr. Wilson is a Bachelor, aged about 50 years and a Roman Catholic. He holds a Grade Teacher's Certificate, and has taught school in the province for the past 20 years. In my opinion, he is a very suitable candidate for Indian School work. In this connection, will the Department please
advise as to salary and allowances payable to teachers in this category, and also, whether they come under the provisions of the Civil Service and Superannuation Acts.

In view of the opposition and antagonism displayed by the Stony Creek Band towards the Lejac Indian Residential School in recent years, and the extreme difficulty experienced in enforcing attendance at Lejac, I would strongly urge that authority be granted to proceed with the necessary improvements to the Recreation Hall and that a teacher be engaged to open the Bay School September 1st next.

ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

Establishment Stony Creek Indian Day School.

A report has been received from Indian Agent Howe and Commissioner MacKay, recommending the establishment of an Indian Day School on the Stony Creek Reserve, Stuart Lake Agency, British Columbia. It has been ascertained that there are thirty (30) Indian children on this reserve for whom educational facilities are required.

There will be no expense in connection with the erection of a building as the Indians are willing to provide classroom accommodation.

In view of the above, I recommend the establishment of this school, to be known as the "Stony Creek Indian Day School", and enclose Memorandum to Council, as required by Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act.

Director,

Memorandum
To: Indian Commissioner
From: School Inspector

Re: Application of Mr. J.A. Wilson
for the position of teacher,
Stony Creek I.R.

Mr. Wilson's application indicates that he is well qualified for this position, but it seems unlikely that the Department will be willing to pay a salary which will be acceptable to him.

At the present time the highest salary paid in an Indian Day School in this Province is $1450.00, plus living accommodation. I am not familiar with the salaries which are being paid in the area in which Mr. Wilson is now teaching but believe that it is in the neighbourhood of $1500.00 per year for a teacher without experience. This would indicate that Mr. Wilson will certainly be able to secure an appointment in which the salary is in the neighbourhood of $2000.00.

On the occasion of my recent visit to the Skeena River Agency where conditions are comparable I was informed by the Provincial Inspector that the lowest salary paid in his inspectorate is $170.00 per year, which applies to qualified teachers without experience. In addition to this, provision is made for annual increments of $100.00 up to $2400.00. In 50 of the 72 organized school districts in B.C. a salary scheme is now in operation under which teachers in elementary schools have a beginning salary of $1300.00, and a maximum of $2400.00 with annual increments of $100.00. This indicates that the Department will have to institute some similar scheme if it is to secure and retain qualified teachers for the Indian Day Schools. In view of this I would recommend that a schedule of teachers' salaries be drawn up along the lines of the one used in the majority of the Provincial schools. This schedule is known in British Columbia.
as the B.C. Teachers' Federation Schedule.

I am not prepared to recommend that Mr. Wilson be appointed at the salary of $2000.00 per annum as suggested by Mr. Howe. Under the "Basic Salary Schedule for Grant Purposes" as recommended in the Cameron Report and used by the Department in setting teachers' salaries in the past Mr. Wilson would receive a salary of $1650.00 per annum. This amount is lower than his present salary.

R.F. Davey
District Inspector of Indian Schools

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Stony Creek Indian Day School

I wrote you under date of June 20th recommending an expenditure of approximately $690.00 for the purchase of classroom furnishings and supplies in the above mentioned Indian Day School. Authority for this expenditure has not yet been received.

Mr. Indian Agent Howe has now submitted requisitions for finishing materials for the teacherage, furnishings, etc. which are briefly detailed as follows:

(1) The Indians are at present constructing a 20x20', 3 roomed teacherage and have supplied all rough material and labour so far. The Dept. intimated that they would be prepared to supply finishing materials for this teacherage and Mr. Howe has submitted the attached tender covering both material and labour as the finishing was apparently beyond the skill of the Indians.

Tender for material and labour for finishing residence..........................$628.73

(2) Construction of a chimney in the teacherage as per attached tender.............................$5.00

(3) Supply of a suitable heater for the classroom $74.60

Total.... $717.73
For your information I would advise that commitments made with respect to expenditures in connection with this school since April 1st, this year are:

(1) Purchase of Brick siding for classroom........$489.24
A voucher covering this item has already been submitted.

(2) Construction of a brick chimney in the classroom .... 110.00
An order has been placed covering this item.

(3) Purchase of classroom furnishings and supplies..690.00
This item was previously recommended to the Department.

In addition to the expenditures above mentioned the Department will be called upon to provide furniture for the teachers' residence, an estimate of the cost of which is not available yet.

I should appreciate being advised if it will be in order to proceed with the expenditures necessary to make this school and teachers' ready for use in September.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Major D.M. Mackay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
VANCOUVER, B.C.

Re: your file No. 14-11-3 - Sept. 16/47

I beg to enclose herewith, voucher No. 804 in favour of Chief J.J. Antoine, Stony Creek Band, for 10 days semi-skilled labour finishing the Teacher's residence at the Stony Creek I.R., at the rate of $3.00 per day, a total of $30.00.

You will recall on my recent visit to your office, that you authorized $100.00 to engage skilled labour to put the finishing touches to the Teacherage. I was unable to secure the service of a carpenter, so I engaged Chief Antoine, who is handy with tools and performed a fairly good job.

The Chief has given unstintingly of his time and labour towards the project, far more than any other Member of the Band, and if it were not for his efforts we would not have been able to open the School on October 1st.

I might add that Carpenters command $1.50 per hour in this district.

Antoine is urgently in need of funds. It will be appreciated if this voucher can be dealt with by Air Mail.

A. Howe,
Indian Agent.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 22 JUNE 1948

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 9th June, 1948, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Stony Creek Indian Reserve, Williams Lake Indian Agency, in the Province of British Columbia;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Stony Creek Indian Reserve;

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . . . . .";

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,550.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses;

That it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Stony Creek Indian Day School, Stuart Lake Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia.

Purchase of a prefabricated one room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence was approved by P.C. 2803 dated June 22, 1943.

Indian Commissioner Arnell has now submitted a tender which he has received from Bovill and Hann, Smithers, B.C., who offer to supply all labour and material for the excavation and construction of concrete footings and walls, erect chimney and paint building and haul prefabricated building to the site, for an amount of four thousand, three hundred and sixty-two dollars and fifty cents, ($4,362.50).

Indian Commissioner Arnell states that every possible effort has been made to secure other quotations but without avail.

The firm mentioned is prepared to do the work immediately and Indian Commissioner Arnell recommends immediate acceptance as it will not likely be possible to pour concrete after October 30th.

We are anxious to have this school completed at the earliest possible date and I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve acceptance of the tender of Bovill and Hann.

Acting Director.

I was out to the Stony Creek I.R. this morning and am pleased to report satisfactory progress is being made in the construction of the foundation for the new School.

Mr. Hann, the Contractor, advises that it is very necessary to proceed with the erection of the prefabricated section immediately on completion of the foundation, in order to protect the concrete walls, floors, etc., from the elements, which may result in severe damage by anticipated sub-zero temperatures.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence on the Stony Creek Indian Reserve, Williams Lake Indian Agency, in the Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Stony Creek Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest. . . . .";

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures Limited, Post Office Box 459, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,650.00 F.O.B. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses,

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only emergency possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Sir;

We are sending our accounts for both the Contract and Cost Plus account in full to date---with the exceptions herein noted.

We do not have the figures covering the cost of the prefabricated materials, and could not include them in the account, should you agree that they should be included. In that case we would ask you to send us the figures covering the cost, as well as to return the TOTAL statement, and the last copy of statement # X9, in order that we may make the entry thereon.

In our letter to you, dated Sept., 25th, 1948; we quoted you as follows: "we are prepared to erect same on a 10% cost plus basis of prefabricated portion of the building and labor involved."

In your letter to us dated Nov., 30th, 1948, you state "the Minister has accepted the offer of Bovill & Hann to erect the new school at Stony Creek, on a day labor basis, plus 10% for supervision.

Apparently we went ahead on this job with no other contract than the letter, and at this time they do not seem to be adequate as to details. On jobs of this kind we have received 10% on the cost of materials sold by ourselves, as well as any materials supplied by the owner. Where we do not make any selling profit on materials, and merely receive 10% on the labor, it means that we pay out the cash for labor and taxes, and that is all we would receive with the exception of the wage of the supervisor, and in this case the mileage and the cost of hotel room while away from home.

We trust that you will agree with us that we should have this percentage, and will send us the cost of the materials which we believe is in the neighborhood of $7600.00. The most of our account is merely for money paid out by us for labor, which is being returned to us, after we have been paying interest on it.

Mr. Hann has left for Francois Lake, and Mr. Bovill is at Telkwa on a job, therefore I am writing this in order to reach you with other matter. Yours truly, Bovill & Hann. Per (G)

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of Nov. 17th, I regret that we have been unable to write at an earlier date with regard to settlement of Bovil and Hann's account covering erection of the above-mentioned school but as intimated in my recent Army Signals message we have been awaiting information from Supt. Howe, which information is set out in his letter of December 6th attached.

We are greatly concerned at the Department's attitude with regard to this account as a careful review of our file indicates that on several occasions we emphatically stated that the estimated cost of erecting the prefabricated sections of the building, $3,800, was arrived at in this office and it is doubtful if Bovil and Hann, who quite rightly were under the impression that they were working on a cost plus 10% of labour basis, were even aware of our estimate. In this connection I would refer to Mr. Neary's Army Signals message of November 24th wherein we were advised that the Minister had approved acceptance of the contractor's quotation to supply all labour and materials for the excavation and construction of concrete footings, etc., at a total cost not exceeding $3,800, and to my reply thereto dated November 26th, 1948, wherein we presumed that the expenditure authorized, $3,800, referred to the erection of the prefabricated sections and completion of the building rather than to excavation and construction of the concrete foundations, etc., which work was previously authorized in Mr. Neary's Army Signals message.
of October 23rd. In the final paragraph of my letter I emphasized that the cost of the erection of the prefabricated sections was estimated in this office and nowhere in our file can I find any suggestion that payment to the contractors was to be confined to the amount of $3,800.

Vouchers Nos. 1046 and 658 referred to on Page 2 of Mr. Phelan's letter covered the amount of the contractor's firm bid for the concrete foundation, etc. Vouchers Nos. 99 in the amount of $1,466 and 245 in the amount of $1,382.29 covered part of the cost of erecting the prefabricated sections of the building and voucher 660 in the amount of $3,765.22 covers, in addition to labour costs in connection with the erection of the building, certain materials additional to those which the contractors undertook to provide in their contract.

As I see the matter, Bovil and Hann have completed that part of the work covered by their firm tender in the amount of $4,362.50 and have been paid this amount. They have, in addition completed the erection of the building to the satisfaction of Mr. Howe and are entitled to reimbursement of the expenditures they have made in this connection which are covered by vouchers 99, 245 and 660, plus 10%, which was the proposal they made to the Department and which apparently was acceptable at that time. The only adjustment which might be effected is a deduction of $71.30 from the amount claimed by them to cover the expenditure of which they were relieved when we arranged for trucking of the school from the factory to the site.

The confusion with regard to this construction project is regretted but you will recall that at that time, in the case of the Klemtu school funds were advanced by the Department for payment of labour costs and formal contracts were insisted on by the Department at Pemberton and elsewhere, whereas at Stony Creek, reference the final paragraph of my letter of December 18th, 1948, to you we were unable to find out just how the Department wished the matter handled.

I would recommend payment of $3,693.92 to Bovil and Hann, which is the amount of their outstanding account less the adjustment for cartage from the railroad to the school site.
which was not supplied by them but which was covered by their firm tender for the foundations, etc.

Proposed Horse Lake Indian Day School

I have discussed Major Clark's proposals and he recommends that this school be given prior consideration to schools at Doig River, Stoney Creek and Moberley. He feels that this school will have a better chance of success and is needed more than schools on these other reserves.

However, we do not have any money in our next year's estimates for this school but have included $8,000 each for Doig River and Stoney Creek schools.

It would seem that this project should be included in our supplementary estimates, but we, of course, do not know when these will be brought down in the House.

With regard to Stoney Creek and Doig River, we should try out log schools at both these places if you consider they will be successful. Major Clark places them in the "dubious class" and would prefer another visit at a different time of the year before making a final decision.

I understand that you may be visiting these reserves and you might keep the school question in mind.

Bernard Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir;

I believe that you are familiar with the details and circumstances connected with this account of $3765.22 which was rendered in July -- AND STILL UNPAID. There should now be added to this amount 6% for interest we have paid the bank for their advance.

Just to keep the record straight, and also find out what is wrong, and where we go from here, the writer will give you all the details, AND HOPE THAT WE MAY SECURE PAYMENT OF THIS LONG PAST ACCOUNT. If there is anything wrong with our account, we have not been advised, and if the delay is an account of the freight from Vanderhoof to Stony Creek, we have not had your account for it. You should have deducted the account from our account and sent the balance otherwise. The only information we have on that matter is in a letter from Mr. Howe, dated Dec., 30th, which says the rate was $2.30, but does not say if per cwt., or ton, and if from Vanderhoof, ONLY, which is what it should be. Not from Vancouver.

We have letter from Mr. Howe, dated Aug., 17th, saying he had forwarded the account to OTTAWA on July 13th. In the same letter he mentioned that you did not authorize the 10¢ on the material.

On Sept., 12th Mr. Howe wrote that "he had air.mailed the Department requesting them to expedite payment of $3765.22."

On Oct., 24th "I have again wired OTTAWA re this account."

On Dec., 30th. "I have done everything possible from this end to hasten payment of the account, and sincerely hope that a settlement will be made at an early date."

You will note the mention of Ottawa in all of these letters. Therefore the writer wrote a PERSONAL letter to our R.P., asking him what he could do about the matter. He wrote that he had been assured that payment would be made IMMEDIATELY.

Today I was talking with Mr. Boys at Hazelton, and he said that all of his accounts went through your office. We sincerely hope that we will not have the same trouble at Hazelton, on our job there; ALSO--THAT YOU MAY BE IN A POSITION TO DO SOMETHING ABOUT OUR STONY CREEK JOB. Please advise what we should do next to get our pay--WITH ADDED INTEREST.

Yours truly,

Bovill & Hann

Dear Doctor Galbraith:

Dr. Moore has handed me your letter of November 8 concerning the above matter. We are taking immediate steps to have an order in Council passed for the establishment of a school at your hospital. Dear Sir,

If you will allow me, my purpose in writing is to learn if there is an opportunity for me to teach English to the young adult Indian people next Sept. 1947, either among the curable tuberculosis cases in our Canadian Sanatorium or on the Indian Reserves.

You naturally will wonder what prompted my unexpected suggestion. About five years ago, I, as a certificated Ontario teacher and speech therapist, became interested in the Indian people while teaching the Indian children in the Fort William Sanatorium for four years. At that time the adult Indians begged me to teach them also. I arranged to do so on Saturday.
morning and the optimistic results well rewarded me for my voluntary efforts. This experiment also acted as a mental therapy for them and in addition we became sincere and mutual friends. I would do more of it but I am now on the city staff as a home relocation leader.

This summer my interest was again revived while attending a two weeks' course on the study of the Indian Problem at the Portage La Prairie Indian Residential School. Mr. Doucet was one of our outstanding lecturers. On account of the teacher shortage in the Indian schools, I was asked to volunteer, but on finding out that the salary was not even a necessary living wage, and that there was no pension scheme, I kept my present position in Fort William.

Next September 1947, however, I would still be interested in teaching Indian people, chiefly the adults. Would there be a possibility of being an itinerant teacher in Canadian Sanatoria, teaching enough English for the curable patients to return and help their own people? I can ask for leave of absence for one year. Perhaps my letter & suggestion can further a different scheme.

Yours sincerely,

(Miss) Ellen Thomas

Dear Mr. Neary:

re: Miller Bay Hospital School

I have your letter of June 30th, Your File No.168-41-1 (WT) regarding the above-noted.

I feel that we would be very well advised to accept Mrs. Hughes as a teacher for our Hospital here, and have her report for duty as soon as convenient. As indicated in your letter, this would be the 1st of August.

In view of the fact that our Hospital is some eight miles from Prince Rupert, it will probably be most satisfactory for Mrs. Hughes to live in the Hospital. In this case she will be charged $30.00 a month for room and board. However, should she prefer to live in Prince Rupert and go back and forth each day, we would be quite happy to have her do this, since our accommodation is limited at the Hospital. There are some employees who do go back and forth each day, and after a short period here she may well decided to take up residence in Prince Rupert. However this is a matter that I feel can be worked out after Mrs. Hughes reports for duty here.

Some two or three weeks ago I sent in a Requisition for some school supplies. This was made up by one of our employees here who has been trying to help us start some instruction for our children at the Hospital here. It might be well for you to go over the matter of what you consider suitable supplies for our Hospital here. I think that as a basis you might estimate for some fifty or sixty children, a great number of whom have had very little previous training in school. It should be kept in mind too that we are not going to be able to follow a very ambitious curriculum and necessarily the school classes will have to be simplified and will probably include more than the average amount of handicraft work. Certainly among the older patients we are anxious to promote as much handicraft work as possible, although I realize that this is not primarily the duty of a schoolteacher. I believe that we will be able to provide an additional employee, who will not be considered as a schoolteacher, but who will definitely sponsor...
the handicraft type of work, particularly among the older patients who are not considered eligible for school. This whole program of school and handicraft we feel is very important in the matter of keeping our patients occupied during the period of time which they have to remain in Hospital.

I might mention that we have a Moving Picture Projector with the usual sound attachments, and we are starting to collect some films of an educational nature. These are very well received by our patients, and I believe that it would be well to keep in mind even in connection with school work.

I trust that some time you will have an opportunity to visit our Hospital here. I am sure you would be able to offer some helpful suggestions in connection with our educational problems among patients.

Yours sincerely,

J. A. Macdonald, M.D.

Dear Sir;

At the end of this month I shall have completed my first year at the Miller Bay Hospital School. It has been a happy and interesting experience, presenting countless problems and trying my patience to the utmost.

Mrs. Hughes has organized the school—following the wishes of Dr. Keenleyside that we make the children literate, teach them to express themselves intelligently, and to make them conscious that they are Canadians. I trust Miss O'Connor and I shall be able to follow a similar programme this next year.

When Mrs. Hughes took me on my first tour of the wards, the curly heads of the little girls and the pink and white skins of many of the boys contradicted all my preconceived notions of Indian children. But I learned that Indian girls and white are alike in wanting to be "beautiful" — curl papers are regular night equipment. Fair complexions are very common but they subject the owner to taunts of "white" and nothing could carry a greater stigma. The children are very proud of being Indian.

All are bed patients. You can imagine the difficulty of keeping in bed small boys, who though ill, are bursting with pent-up mischief and curiosity. The novelty of hospital routine soon wears off and means of evading doctors', nurses', and teachers' orders bothers them not. Climbing up a water pipe, hanging on with one hand is a mere incident in the day of a little boy.

Dr. Galbraith has appointed the hours 9-11 a.m. and 3-4 p.m. as school hours. He has asked the doctors and nurses to interrupt these periods as little as possible. I should like to express my sincere appreciation of the co-operation all have given me.

Since the New Year Mrs. Hughes and I have been going over to the nursery children as well, from 2-2.30 p.m. Here is where we get a regular fusillade of questions, such as, How you make bacon? Why it rain? Where have sun gone? Jesus stand on mat? Here too, we have been hampered by lack of kindergarten equipment.
Each children's department consists of a large ward of eight beds and four smaller wards of four beds each. In my section—the boys—I have the youngest children in the big ward. But the personnel changes from time to time, as patients are discharged and new ones enter. When children are using the same books we like to group them together. But this is not possible always. The physical condition of the child determines his position in the wards. The doctors and nurses are as interested in the boys' schooling as I am, and a move to a child's advantage is made whenever possible.

I am very proud of the "beginners." They were very shy at first and hesitant about speaking in English. English is, of course, a foreign tongue to most of them. (What a terrifying experience for a child to be put in a room where he knows no one, where no one speaks his language, then to be "poked" and X-rayed and even put in a cast. No wonder they can't talk.) But after we had played games—a language all understand—they became vocal, and the adjective shy applies to them no longer.

The first accomplishment toward which the children is to send their first letter home. It consists of one or two sentences, printed with very wobbly letters, and with many sighs of satisfaction as each letter is made and each word finished. And the acme of happiness is reached when I ask, "May I give this letter to Dr. Galbraith to read?"

The small boys take pride in hearing one another spell. We have a champion in each ward but have not found the Champion champion yet.

I have been trying to interest the older boys in tales, pictures and designs of their own tribes. Judith Morgan's display of her own pictures in the National Gallery at Ottawa has aroused their interest. I am hoping it may be an incentive to her brother, Howard, who is a patient here.

You can understand how little we accomplish in a day. Three hours shared with twenty-four boys is less than ten minutes for each. Our teaching is from bed to bed and from ward to ward. It is unwise to remain longer than ten minutes in a room if an orderly calm is to pervade "Ward E."

Rest is such an essential in the cure of the children that we must watch them very carefully lest they become weary or overexcited.

This is difficult work, difficult physically, mentally and emotionally. But the results are gratifying. I am happy in teaching the children and interested in helping some of the men who have not had school experience.

I am enclosing pictures of the boys of Ward E, taken for me by Mr. Wrathall, photographer of Prince Rupert. Little Earl used to say when I went over to the ward at three o'clock, "Aren't we the handsome Boys, Miss Starratt?" I am sure you will agree.

Sincerely,

Dear Sir—

Grading is a very difficult matter. We receive no statement of the child's school grading when he or she is admitted as a patient and pupil in our wards. Re: Indian Hospital Schools

I have been requested by Dr. Campbell of the Nanaimo Indian Hospital to secure a ruling on the holidays which teachers in our Hospital Schools may be granted. The attached copy of a circular sent to all Indian Hospitals in B.C. will indicate the policy being observed with regard to the daily hours of work and the length of the teaching week. A statement of policy with regard to the normal school holidays, such as Thanksgiving Day, Christmas and Easter is requested.

As the Department is aware some of our hospital teachers are giving instruction in handicrafts of an occupational therapy nature. This is normally done in addition to the time spent in the wards on academic instruction. One of the questions raised by Dr. Campbell is whether or not teachers should be completely free on Provincial school holidays which are not normally Civil Service holidays, or whether they should be expected to carry on as if these were regular school days or whether the academic work should be dropped on these occasions and the teacher devote her time to handicraft work.

My own feeling in the matter is that teachers in hospital schools should be granted only Civil Service holidays and that all other days should be considered as normal teaching days, and that the teaching week which conforms with the hours of Civil Servants employed in other capacities on the hospital staff remain as indicated in the attached circular.

W.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
1. Actual teaching time on wards should average five hours daily. Preferably, this should be between 9 a.m. and 6 p.m. Minimum time required on duty to be seven hours daily (Monday to Friday).

2. Opportunity for uninterrupted class or individual teaching periods is to be arranged by the Medical Superintendent as far as disposition of patients in the wards will allow. Routine ward work in these particular areas is to be completed before the teaching period or deferred until after.

3. For purposes of general supervision of work, hours of work, discipline, attendance, and leave, teachers will be responsible directly to the Medical Superintendent.

4. Guidance and advice on academic matters is to be provided by or requested from the Inspector of Indian Schools.

5. Teachers should be required to sign the daily attendance register. Monthly attendance report to be sent by office to Mr. Arneil.

6. Teachers to confer once a month with the Medical Superintendent for the purpose of discussing routine, amount of individual patient participation, and any other relevant matters.

Please find attached a self-explanatory letter sent to Dr. Burgess, Acting Medical Superintendent of the Miller Bay Indian Hospital. Your attention is kindly directed to the following change in policy:

(1) All future appointments of new teachers at Indian hospitals will be on a 10 month basis rather than on a 12 month basis. In other words they will be classified as day school teachers and not as welfare teachers.

(2) All present hospital teachers classified as welfare teachers will retain this classification for the time being. There is no guarantee that their classification will not be changed at a future date.

(3) Hospital teachers will be expected to teach at least 30 hours during the week. This applies to future appointments as present appointments under the welfare teacher classification are expected to teach at least 36 hours. This is exclusive of time spent in lesson preparation, correction of exercises, etc., which should take at least 10 or 15 hours per week.
If any clarification is required of this change in policy, we would appreciate specific questions being raised. All hospital teachers will be advised of this change in the September 1950 issue of the Indian School Bulletin.

Dear Doctor Williamson:

I have for answer your letter of June 6 concerning your welfare teachers.

We have a number of applicants for hospital schools and intend to write to you and to Inspector Davey concerning them at a later date.

It is not our intention to appoint new hospital teachers as welfare teachers (on a 12 month basis) but only as day school teachers (on a 10 month basis).

Therefore, these teachers will be required to teach during the week approximately the same number of hours as required of teachers in our Indian day schools, namely 30 hours. This means hours of actual teaching and does not include lesson preparation, travelling to classes, etc. We expect that each teacher will spend at least 10 to 15 hours in lesson preparation, marking of exercises, etc.

The Medical Superintendent of the Hospital is the one who decides on the actual hours during which instruction can be given on various wards. I hope that the above will guide Dr. Burgess in preparing a schedule for next September.

Where there are two teachers at a school, it is recommended that the two months' holiday period be staggered, in other words that one teacher be permitted holidays during June.
and July and the other teacher during July and August. During these months no salary is provided for the teacher concerned.

The above applies only to newly appointed teachers at Indian hospitals. Those now in the service will continue to be classified as welfare teachers but, as stated above, all new appointments will be day school teachers.

Dear Col. Neary:

We now have fifty-two children in our school and four have just come in around five and six years of age who should be in it, but until the supplies (invoice has arrived) come, it seems best to defer their start. These supplies are coming by freight, which seems a painfully slow process, and will hold up our work. Is there no arrangement by which sorely needed school supplies could be hastened in a special case such as ours?

I wish to ask if we may have a record player and radio for the school, in order to provide Christmas (and other) music, and also to take advantage of the school broadcasts of the P.C. Dept. of Education such as the Prince Rupert schools enjoy. Such a machine (General Electric) would play ten to twelve records as a concert and also enable us to tune in on the provincial broadcasts. The bulletin supplied to schools by Indian Affairs clearly state that in this province we must follow the course of studies of B.C. May we not also enjoy some of the more luxurious features of the British Columbia program? This machine which I have priced in P.R. costs $165 and I believe that is about the price of any standard make. The record player without the radio plays only record at a time and may be had for about twenty dollars, but that would eliminate the opportunity of the broadcasts which are a daily feature.

We have children of Roman Catholic and Protestant faiths, and it seems to me that the opportunity to present to them the old story of Christmas in the great music which belongs to both should not be disregarded. We would need some provision to purchase records, which would of course be only those acceptable to both faiths. These children are confined to the small world of the hospital, some of them in rigid casts and flat on their backs, and while some of them have bedside radios and small musical instruments, their choice is poor and untrained. I feel that part of their education should be to love and know good music, the music of the masters, and for that reason I ask you to
let me have an early reply.

The condition of the children's lungs in a t.b. hospital makes it impossible for them to sing, so I have had them learn to recite O Canada and God Save the King, but that is dull for them, and I feel that the Department should consider these helpless children as a special case and must see the opportunity we have here to inculcate a love of good music, which is so much a part of the ordinary school program to-day.

Under separate cover I am forwarding some pictures of our children, that you may see for yourself what manner of child we have at Miller Bay. They are alert, intelligent and possessed of incredible patience, working, many of them, under stringent physical handicaps. I also enclose an article from the Prince Rupert News of yesterday's date, written by myself for Education Week, which will tell you in a little more detail of our school.

Hoping for the best,

Sincerely yours,

(Mrs. A.C. Hughes)

Dear Col. Neary:

The cheque dated Nov. 28th to cover my travelling expenses to Prince Rupert has come to hand, for which I thank you. It was for a full month.

We now have fifty-eight children of school age, and I have asked Dr. Galbraith for a second teacher. While our original order for supplies has not yet been filled in toto, and I shall shortly be sending another order, the number has grown to such an extent that it is impossible to do justice to any of them under present conditions.

As a teacher I have recommended a young woman who is now in Vancouver and has a B.C. teacher's license as well as a B.A. from Acadia University. She worked with me in Press Censorship and before that in the Air Force Pay Office, I think. She was with the government for about four years, and left our office there in order to return to B.C. She has also had a summer school session in B.C. in the last two or three years, and is well qualified in kindergarten work, as well as that of the higher grades. She would be a distinct acquisition to the Indian Affairs branch. Since she is about my own age I realize I can hardly call her a young woman, that was unpremeditated! Dr. Galbraith said he would ask Major Davey to call on her for an interview.

We have many young children of pre-school age and several who are more likely to respond to manual work than to ordinary teaching. The disposition of the wards here requires quite a lot of rapid "foot-work," which eats up time for teaching which is all too limited on account of the rest periods.

We had a Christmas tree for the children and many gifts came in from friends in Prince Rupert and even Vancouver; some mentioned the article in the "News" as the reason for their interest, which pleased the writer.
are to publish a monthly magazine in the new year, on the order of the Camsell Arrow. Dr. Galbraith is very keen on this project and I hope it will be a success. The hospital has a new Gestetner machine and when our first issue appears we shall put you on our mailing list.

The record player and phonograph which I asked for may or may not have arrived; yesterday a very handsome machine came in and was placed in the nurses' residence. It is a General Electric cabinet, and I heard a rumour that it came as a Christmas present from the Dept. of Mines & Resources. However it did not come to the school nor to the hospital and is therefore of no use to our children, who did not have any Christmas music. As a teacher in this atmosphere is considerably lower than the angels, I have hesitated to ask if this is our machine, but I should appreciate it if you will enquire of the Purchasing Agent and advise me. There is considerable hidden antagonism to the work of the school on the part of some employees of the hospital, and the situation is delicate. It appears that the residence has long wanted such a record player and radio.

The Christmas parcels which came in as a response to my articles in the News were addressed to me, as was also at least one letter addressed to me. None of these were handed to me, nor was I permitted to handle them, they were whisked through the front office to a locked room and disposed of by hospital employees. The Prince Rupert friends who sent these articles are quite disturbed over this situation, and as it concerns public relations I feel I must bring it to your attention. The hospital got a grant of One Hundred Dollars from National Health and Welfare for Christmas presents for the hospital, but none of this came my way for the school. A blanket order was sent to T. Eaton's who sent ready wrapped gifts, among them a croquet set.

We cannot expect the Prince Rupert to take a sympathetic interest in our work if we do not patronise them. I mention this especially because Mr. McCrae who owns McCrae's book-store called me on the telephone and said that he had read my article in the News and wished to send me some gifts to distribute. He sent about Fifty dollars worth of gifts, and this I was told by the clerk in the front office to hand over to the matron. It would seem to me that a school teacher whose relationship to her pupils is always close should at least be permitted to apportion the gifts that she is given by a friend of the school. Mr. McCrae had just arrived home from the Liberal Convention to which he was a delegate, and perhaps wished to show his public spirit. I feel he would be annoyed to know the disposition of his gift. Since I had no money to spend on my school at Christmas, I feel that those gifts which came to me as a result of my articles in the News should have been mine to distribute.
This plaint is not because I wish to show my importance, but my position as a teacher ought to be recognized, as otherwise I do not feel I can carry on. I have never been of the opinion that a teacher in a hospital school is just an employee of the hospital who passes books instead of bedpans. I am sure the Medical Supt. is not aware of this situation, but I do not feel adequate to bring it to his attention, as in addition to his work he has had a sick child at home. However, the atmosphere is depressing and inimical to my work as a teacher and certainly needs clearing up.

I do not wish to add to your troubles, either, but while I resolved not to interfere with the good-will of this season, now that Christmas is over, I would like to have a little help in this problem.

I enclose the second article I wrote for the News for your examination. The two articles stirred up a lot of public interest and I was invited to two of the city schools and asked to tell something of the school here. It seems to me that that is a good thing in organizing a school such as this, and I believe Dr. Galbraith was pleased. He told me he had been trying to get the editor of the News out here for a year to give the hospital some publicity, but he never seemed willing to come. A taxi-cab company also called up the Dr. and offered to transport free any gifts to the hospital, but they could not understand why parcels addressed to the teacher could not be delivered to the teacher.

Our Christmas passed off happily despite the heartburnings of the teacher, I may say, but I repeat I think the situation is one that should be changed if my work is to prosper.

With kind regards and best wishes for the New Year, and with many thanks for your past kindness,

Yours sincerely,

Sometimes a book is the only pleasure possible when a child is in bed with the flu, or his back or his stomach. While school books in use are pleasant, they are often dull, and simple stories, well told and illustrated with attractive pictures, are very welcome. The cards are made using old cards which have been sent in by kind friends of the school, and are colored with crayons or paints. Some of the cards are well executed although some are bound to be described as “boring,” but they are given to their parents and grandparents with pride.

Ottawa, 14 December 1946.

Mr. H.J. Calibois, Indian Agent,
FORT ST. JOHN, B.C.

We have your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the Prophet River Indian Day School. Local purchase of the supplies mentioned on your requisition is approved.

It is noted that the cost of labour will be approximately $200.00.

The Department was pleased to learn that you are satisfied with the manner in which this school is being operated.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Fort St. John, B.C.,
December 9th, 1946.

Mr. B. F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I have inspected the Prophet River (R.C.) Indian Day School recently established at Prophet River, on the 4th and 5th instant. His Lordship Bishop Coudert accompanied me. Although that school has been in operation five weeks, I have been agreeably surprised to find already a noticeable change in the Indian children and adults attending classes; they are neater and clean. Precision drill and P.T. exercises were remarkably good. Posture is only fair and will improve once we can do away with the Mess Hall tables we use as desks and seats; they are of a local pattern and suitable for tall persons. Scabies, scrofulas, ringworms and other skin infections have been treated efficiently by the teacher, Rev. Father Tanguay. Clothing is scant on some of the pupils but what they wear is much cleaner than it used to. I am asking the Hudson's Bay Company at Fort Nelson, to send more children's clothing when they pay the next Family Allowance.

As your letter of October 28th, file 143-5-1 WT, reverses a previous decision as to ownership of the building used as classroom and places upon us instead of upon the Church, the responsibility of making that building fit for its use as a classroom and teacherage, I have agreed to accept an account from Father Levasque, of Fort Nelson, for the cost of the alterations made under his supervision before your letter was received. As I have to take over for the completion of the necessary alterations, I wish to inform you of the arrangements I have made or will make within the next few days, urgency due to lateness of the season and severity of the weather making it imperative that I proceed with that work without delay.
your sanction.

I am attempting to hire a carpenter at the going wage of $1.00 per hour to go to Prophet River to do the following work:

1. To build porches for the front and rear doors

2. Window sashes to be windproofed and cracked panes replaced.

3. The interior of the building is lined with pieces of Ten/Test of odd sizes and shapes. It will be necessary to cover this Ten/Test with building paper, glued on, sized and painted with kalsomine. Walls and ceiling to be done.

4. Install Yukon type chimneys (2), roof jacks, asbestos sheeting, and two Co² Fire Extinguishers.

The cost of labour is estimated to run up to $200.00. Form 37 herewith lists the material required for which I have already placed order with local firms. I will be unable to haul the material myself, there being two tons of it, and will send it by British Yukon Navigation Freighth trucks or by other freighters as can best accommodate me.

The local Indians are not ready to undertake to supply the fuel for the school. Rev. Father Levaque will see to it that it is supplied and has agreed to hire for that purpose all the Indian labour that is available. Later on this will be entrusted to Indians exclusively.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

E.J. Galibois,
Indian Agent.

G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alberta.

Re: Fuel, Prophet River Day School.

Dear Sir:

In your letter of May 28th, your file 143-6-3, you authorize the procuring of the cordwood required for next winter for the above mentioned school.

I have been after the Indians of Prophet River since last March for them to undertake to supply this wood, but so far they have not made a move. I have therefore made arrangements with an Indian of Moberley Lake, Harry Desjarlais, of the Saulteau Band, who has undertaken to cut, haul and pile in the school yard, thirty cords of dry wood and 10 cords of green wood @ $15.00 per cord.

The nearest stand of dry wood is at Milepost 219, about 14 miles from the school, and the green wood can be cut at Milepost 234 about two miles distant from the school.

Harry Desjarlais, nor any of the Prophet River Indians, have the equipment for hauling and it will be necessary to sublet to a white for the trucking job. At my request the Hudson's Bay Company have consented to advance to Desjarlais, provisions and supplies to the extent of $100.00.

Would it be possible therefore that you obtain an accountable advance of $600.00 to cover the cost of supplying this fuel, to enable payments to be made from this office as needed, instead of waiting for the submission of number of accounts.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
N. Galibois,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

(Attention: B. F. Neary, Esq., Supt., Welfare & Training)

Re: Fuel - Prophet River Day School, Ft. St. John Indian Agency

It was noted from Indian Agent Galibois' Diary for the month of April, that an early arrangement for the supply of fuel for the above day school had been requested by Bishop Coudert. I therefore wrote Mr. Galibois on May 28th, asking him to make the necessary arrangements to obtain fuel.

Mr. Galibois, in the letter attached, has requested that an accountable advance of $600.00 be provided to cover the cost of laying in the wood required for fuel. It is most important that provision for the coming winter be made now, and it is my request that this grant be made available as soon as possible.

C. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Mr. B. F. Neary,
Supt., Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I have been unable until yesterday to find a carpenter willing to go to Prophet River to complete the repairs to the building of the Prophet River (R.C.) Indian Day School at Milepost 232.5.

Mr. A. Lambert who did the work last January, is now available and I have hired him at the going rate of $1.25 per hour; also Mr. J. Norman, his partner, also a carpenter, at $1.00 per hour. Both have been supplied with transportation and will leave on Monday the 30th instant. In addition I am providing them with a helper, Indian Harry Desjarlais, who will dig a root cellar under the school and bank the building with earth in readiness for the winter. I have agreed to pay him $5 per hour.

The following work is to be done:

1° Completing front and rear porches; installing two Yukon chimneys; change front and rear doors; find ways and means of improving ventilation of the building; repair school seats and adjust them to improve posture of pupils;

2° Big Root Cellar 6'x 8'x 5' and shore same; cut and hinge trap door in floor.

3° Repair leaky roof and coat all old seams with pitch.

4° Erect fence along highway side of school grounds, using 8" dia. swamp spruce posts supplied by Indians and 2" x 4" and 2" x 6" planks salvaged from dismantled building; Whitewash same. Exact location of fence to be as instructed by Major Ackerley, Sr Highway Supt., N.W.H.S.C., Whitehorse.

5° Cleaning school ground and burning slashes, bank building with earth for winter.
In addition, these men will supervise the construction of two houses for Indians Jumbie, No. 28 Sikkani Band, and Frank Jackson, No. 11 Halfway Band, coaching them in the laying out of frame construction and in the use of tools.

I enclose herewith requisition in duplicate for material purchased today from the K. J. Dodds Lumber Yard of Fort St. John.

I trust you will approve of the action taken and that the vouchers for these expenditures will be accepted.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

E. J. Galibois,
Indian Agent.

Your file 143-5-5 (WT 1).

Last January 27 you wrote me asking for explanation as to the supervision given Messrs. Lambert and Norman while they were repairing the Prophet River Day School Building, and expressing your surprise as to the time taken. I have been able to see Mr. Lambert only lately as he has been away during the winter, and upon checking with him his time sheets and the items of work done I find that I did not report on the voucher, the replacement of a large part of the foundations of that building.

As you may be aware the North West Highway Command had agreed to clear and level off an area contiguous to the building as a playground for the pupils. While their bulldozers were at work they uncovered the foundations of the building and it was found that all the timbers at one end had rotted and had to be replaced. Subsidence of the building started shortly thereafter and after the week had passed conditions had become so bad as to cause a large crack to appear in the newly repaired roof. Lambert took it upon himself to make the necessary repairs. Jacks and other equipment he borrowed from N.W.H.S. of Mile 245; 6" x 6" timbers could only be had from another building which Lambert and Normand themselves had to dismantle from the roof down, none of the Indians being there to lend assistance as they had left to hunt in the mountains. Lambert has no definite figures to show for this work but he estimates that no less than 200 hours were spent on repairs to the foundation out of which 180 hours were for retrieving five 6" x 6" x 20' timbers. About five thousand feet of lumber were salvaged at the same time and this was later used by the Indians in building new homes.

I called at Prophet River School only once while the work was in progress, on July 10th, and felt satisfied of the work being done properly and speedily. Other occupations did not permit me to make more frequent visits at that time.

I trust these explanations will be found satisfactory.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES  
CANADA
Fort St. John, B.C.,
March 31st, 1949.

Mr. B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Replying to your letter 797-5 (E.1) dated the 23rd instant.

I am returning herewith the requisition sent you direct by Father Tanguay, teacher at Prophet River Indian Day School. I also enclose his order for various school supplies and books received here. Shipments from both requisitions should be addressed to Dawson Creek, B.C., which is the rail terminal for this district.

Regarding the supply of an electric light plant as requested by Father Tanguay, I would like you to explore every avenue within your command to make the supply of same feasible. The school is very poorly lighted by natural light which makes it necessary to have the best and most economical artificial light. If you would supply that plant, it could be run the first year on gasolene, but afterward I would press more strongly to have the land the school is built on, properly surveyed and the title acquired from the Province. The moment the land is ours, we can tap a first class gas well which lies on the property and will fill the school and the Indians' needs for some generations. This well is at present capped. It could be made usable at slight cost.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

H. L. Gailbois,
Superintendent,
Fort St. John Indian Agency.

August 26, 1949.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Re: Lighting Plant for Prophet River Day School

We have just received a letter from Mr. F.J. Galibois, Superintendent of the Fort St. John Indian Agency which is self-explanatory. We would appreciate your comments on his proposition.

Director.

AJD:MKW
Fort St. John, B.C.,
August 19, 1949.

The Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Lighting plant for Prophet River Day School

Now that the school site is to be included in an Indian Reserve for the Sikkenni Bend of Prophet River which is about to be surveyed, I would like you to reconsider my requisition of March 31st last for an electric lighting plant to operate on natural gas.

There is a gas well on the property, which I desire to uncap to provide heat and light for the school. Light can be produced at no expense other than wear and tear of the plant. Heating of the school by natural gas will enable us to make a saving of $600.00 per year.

The piping of the gas from the well to school will necessitate digging a trench across the Alaska Highway. Mr. C.W. Fox, Superintendent, Southern Division, North West Highway System, is anxious to have this work done early this fall as a mechanical trench digger will be available in the district in the near future. I anticipate that this work of pipeelaying and necessary trenching will cost no more than $200.00

Yours very truly,

(sgd) E.J. Galibois,
Superintendent,
Fort St. John Indian Agency.
MEMORANDUM:

Re: Lighting Plant for Prophet River Day School

Reference is made to letter from Indian Affairs dated August 26th and your notation thereon asking how soon we can give Major MacKay information on this matter.

I wish to point out that there is insufficient information given in connection with this matter for us to make any recommendation at the present time. It is noted from the letter of Mr. E.J. Galibois, Superintendent of the Fort St. John Indian Agency, that there is a gas well on the property which he proposes to use for the supply of natural gas for heating the school. He also proposes to install an electric lighting plant to operate on natural gas.

Before any recommendation can be made regarding the gas-driven electric lighting plant, it would be necessary for us to have one of our engineers make an examination to determine the quantity and pressure of natural gas available in the well. Arrangements can be made to have an engineer proceed to the school and make this investigation if it is considered desirable.

Mr. Galibois states that the piping of the gas from the well to the school will necessitate digging a trench across the Alaska Highway, and that a mechanical trench digger will be available in the district in the near future. He estimates that the cost of the necessary trenching and pipe laying would not exceed $200.

Under the circumstances we would recommend that the necessary trenching and pipe laying be carried out immediately to provide gas for heating purposes, if the Indian Affairs Branch is satisfied (without further investigation) that the supply of gas is adequate.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
OTTAWA.

Telegraph Creek, B.C.
December 21, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

The local Roman Catholic Mission proposes to start a seasonal school at Shesley Station, about 40 miles north-west of Telegraph Creek on the Telegraph Line at the junction of the Salmon and Eggell Creeks, and the Shesley River. This point is the site of an Indian winter camp which has existed for many years, and seven or eight Indian families who trap in that area live there.

The Church has no buildings at Shesley, and although any plans are tentative, it has been suggested to Father Carpentier that we might obtain use of the Dominion Government telegraph station at Shesley. This building has not been used since the closing of the telegraph line between Telegraph Creek and Atlin, but it is still equipped, and in fair condition.

It would be greatly appreciated if you could interview Superintendent R.G. Bishop of the Government Telegraph Service in Vancouver and enquire whether that Department has any objection to use being made of the building.

A previous enquiry directed to the Government Telegraph Service about obtaining 'line' cabins and equipment for the Indians resulted in the advice that the telegraph line had not yet been abandoned and permission could not be granted to use the cabins. However, if the Shealey Station cabin could be secured for use, it could be on the understanding that it would be relinquished if the G.T.S. needed it again.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Indian Agent.

Re Shealey Seasonal School

Dear Mr. Neary;

I have your communication of March 5th re Shealey School.

I beg to say that the report received from Father J. Forget O.M.I. was very encouraging for the first educational experiment made at that point.

There were 27 Indians in the Camp, of whom 11 children of school age; you may have seen at any rate from the School report directly sent to you by the Teacher that the attendance was not bad for this first attempt at giving some schooling to those children who never had any before.

The extreme difficulties of communication, and the delay of the Indians to arrive at their winter quarter prevented Father Forget from starting the School as early as anticipated. I think that with a little coaxing of the Indians to rush them to their trapping ground and the facilities of some local air transportation, the teacher could be able another year to give those Indians three full months of School, perhaps even four, viz., from September to Christmas.

I do not see, however, any possibility for Father Forget of teaching at Shealey after Christmas; he has to return to Telegraph Creek for Christmas to attend to the spiritual needs of the local white and half-breed population, to answer his Christmas Mail, make his yearly accounts and reports; this normally keeps him busy until the middle of January; by that time he has to visit Cariboo Hide, which is located some 200 miles away and where the missionary has to make at least this yearly visit. That trip keeps him busy at least two months, until the middle or the end of March. Meanwhile his companion is teaching four months of School at Iskut Lake or Klappan, from January to end of April. In the summer months, one priest has to stay at Telegraph Creek, which is a very busy place during the summer, whilst the other is employed in one of our other summer schools, such as Lower Post. That's all those two priests can possibly cover in the educational field, if we take into account their other obligations as priests and missionaries, viz., their religious exercises, the unexpected sick calls, their buildings and repairs, woodcutting, care of the dogs, cooking, washing, studying etc., etc.

I do not see how they possibly can do more, until I will be able to give them a third companion; we are already doing our utmost for that district by providing two priests for a Catholic Population of 233 Indians.
Ottawa, March 24th, 1947.

Dear Bishop Coudert:

We have your letter of the 11th instant in connection with the situation at the Shesley Seasonal School. We realize the difficulties that both yourself and your missionaries are working under.

No doubt you will have an opportunity of visiting Ottawa some time during the current year and we can then discuss the matter more fully.

Possibly you could also discuss the situation at Shesley with Major Clark when he goes to your section of the country in connection with the proposed Teslin Lake Residential School.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Extract from letter from Rev. Father Turenne, dated September 13, 1948. Original on 158-6-1.

The school reports have been sent at the end of each month to our Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek, but in case you have not as yet received these reports, you will find a copy of them here enclosed.

His Excellency Bishop Jean-Louis Coudert, O.M.I., is telling me that you would like to have some information on our activities in Shesley last winter.

Father J.M. Mouchet, O.M.I., and I left Telegraph Creek by trail on January 22, 1948, for Shesley where we arrived on the 24th. Our plans were first to repair and readapt the B.C. Telegraph building to be suitable for a school, after which we wanted to teach school to the few children in the camp.

To repair the house, both of us had to work 24 days, from January 26 to February the 21st. This work, which, to my opinion, should have been done and paid by the Indian Department, was made at our own expenses; by our expenses here I mean especially our time since as for material we had to take what we had already on the spot. To note again that this extra work was done for the sole purpose of opening a convenient school during fall 1948.

In case you would like to have details on the work done, here are the major repairs involved: we had to take out the kitchen floor in order to renew the rotten joists; we took down a whole partition and made a smaller bedroom in order to have the main room bigger and brighter by the addition of another window; we then had to repair a very bad corner of the room as well as the ceiling.

After completion of the improvements, the Indians were so enthusiastic about them that they were anxious to come in good number the next fall for the opening of the school. They expected then to have from 12 to 15 children ready for school this fall. Though I had no contact with them since last spring, I am positive that there will be enough children at Shesley this fall for the opening of another school term.

As all this work left us free for only the last week of February, I then taught school to the only six children
children in the camp.

His Excellency Bishop Coudert, O.M.I., came to visit the population during the first week of March and we then went back to Telegraph Creek where other duties were calling us.

I went into rather long details, Sir, so that you could see by yourself what we are trying to do for our dear Indians often at the cost of many sacrifices and hardships.

Hoping that this letter will please you and help you in your co-operation with us, I remain

(Sgd.) F. Edmond Turenne, O.M.I.

I beg to submit herewith requisitions for Sheslay Seasonal School for items applied for by Rev. Forget:

**MATERIALS FOR CONSTRUCTION**

(1) Desks, seats, and shelves for class room  
(2) Materials for repairing class-room proper

(4) Equipment for class-room  
(5) Fuel for heating class-room (cut by Indians)  
(6) Manual training tools (will also be used in preparing school)

Authority is also requested for:

(1) Indian labour for desks, toilets and repairs $75.00  
(2) Hauling supplies by pack-horse and dog team (Indian) $50.00  
Total $125.00

It is suggested an accountable advance be supplied for this purpose.

Tenders are attached to requisitions for both local and outside purchase.

The Sheslay School operated from October 15th to December 15th in 1946, and had an average attendance of about 7. Rev. Forget plans to operate the school from October 1st to January 31st in future, and expects to have an attendance of about 15. However, it is not at all certain that an increase will actually take place. The habits of this group of Indians vary from year to year, and nothing definite can be stated about how many children will be available for school except that it is fairly certain that the attendance will be no less than last year.

In the event of establishing a first class day school near Telegraph Creek these children from Sheslay would attend here.

CANADA
The Department's telegram of October 7th approving operation of Indian day school at Telegraph Creek instead of Shesley, is acknowledged.

It became obvious early in October that the Indian children usually resident at the Indian camp of Shesley, 40 miles north of Telegraph Creek, were mostly remaining in town for at least the pre-new year period. As preparations had been completed for improving the Shesley School, including the provision of lumber and materials, and an advance for labour and carpentry had been made in connection with plans that these repairs would be useless this season if the children were not going to be available for school attendance. In addition to this there were a number of local Catholic children available for school if a school were operated in Telegraph Creek. In consultation with Rev. J. Forget, O.M.I., of the Roman Catholic Mission, it was decided to apply for authority to use the Shesley materials and supplies in preparing the local R.C. Church for a school room.

Assurance was given by Father Forget that he would operate this proposed school at least until Christmas, and upon receipt of the above-mentioned telegram from the Department the R.C. Mission undertook to make the necessary alterations in their Church to accommodate the school-room. This work was completed about October 15th, and school opened, the average attendance for the remainder of the month was 7.0, and the number of Indian children on the roll 10. There were 17 children then enrolled for school, but owing to the epidemic of mumps locally some were away sick. An improved attendance has been noted so far this month, but all parents are not co-operating fully and have been warned of probable loss of Family Allowances if children still fail to attend.
