Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6383, file 798-5, part 1)
I beg to acknowledge the Department's letter of December 20, 1947, file 158-11-5 (ST1), concerning operation of Indian day school at Telegraph Creek.

Attendance improved somewhat during November and December, and the average for the quarter was finally 10.2. The school closed on December 19 with no assurance that it would reopen at least until March, 1948. Unless an attendance of at least 10 is certain this school will not be opened again this term, either at Telegraph Creek, or Sheslay. If the Indian families do as they have in previous seasons there will be more children at Telegraph Creek than Sheslay; the men usually bring in their families in late March and leave them in town while they themselves go out beaver trapping.

The original opening of the Sheslay School was only recommended on the understanding that the attendance would be at least ten. During the 45 day term in the fall of 1946 the average attendance was near 7. Bishop Coudert of Whitehorse was advised early in 1947 that unless Rev. Forget, the teacher, would guarantee to extend the term to 4 months, and assure an attendance of at least 10, this office would not recommend reopening the school in 1947. As Rev. Forget realized he could not get that attendance at Sheslay his alternative was to open the school in town where it appeared he would have a good attendance. Owing to sickness the average was down for the first month, but was sufficient in November and December to warrant continuation of the school in town. However, the school only operated 45 days again this term, and this is not considered satisfactory for a continuation of the scheme in future years.

cont.
The opposition of local fur traders to an Indian day school operated in town is quite understandable. They feel that if the families remain in so that their children may benefit from schooling, they may lose business from decreased fur catches owing to the late start possibly made by trappers. Under the present hit and miss school system in effect in this agency I am inclined to feel that the Indians are indeed better off out on, or near their traplines even if the children are deprived of a few weeks school, but if a regular Indian day school were established here where the children could attend the full term and receive professional instruction I would not hesitate to state that the long-term benefits to be derived from schooling would far outweigh the immediate advantages of living out of town. The trader's interest is naturally selfish, and it seems to me that from past experience the trapper goes out to his line as soon as he realizes there is no chance of securing further supplies until he produces some fur. Many of the trappers already leave their families in early November and go out to their trap-lines alone, and if the others are not encouraged to remain in town by supplying them with relief assistance they too will get out.

In conclusion, the information requested by the Department is stated briefly here: In the event that the attendance in town is not sufficient to re-open the school in March it would not be practical to open the school at Sheslay either because the attendance there is likely to be lower even than in town, and the difficulty of transporting supplies to Sheslay, for the sake of a few weeks schooling, is not justified; neither is the expense.

R.H.C. Sampson,
Indian Agent.

I have to refer to your letter of September 10th regarding the establishment of an Indian Day school at Anahim Lake.

Although reference was made in your letter of October 14, 1943, to the establishment of schools at Alexis Creek and "Anahim Lake" Reserves, we have no school at Anahim Lake nor a school designated Anahim Lake. We have, however, a school at the Anaham Reserve established under Order in Council No. P.C.88, reference your 160-2-1 or January 15, 1943, in this connection.

The following Indian Day schools have already been established in the Cariboo district:

(1) Anaham Indian Day School on Anaham Indian Reserve approximately five miles south easterly from Alexis Creek Post Office.

(2) Alexis Creek Indian Day School on Charley Boy's Meadow I.R. No. 3, Redstone Meadows, twenty-two miles north westerly from Redstone Post Office.

(3) Ulkatcho Indian Day School on Ulkatcho Indian Reserve No. 2 some eighty-two miles north-westerly from Tatla Lake Post Office.

The Anaham and Alexis Creek schools are in the Williams Lake Agency, whereas the Ulkatcho school is in the Bella Coola Agency. The proposed new Indian Day School is on the Upper
Dean River at Anahim Lake, Bella Coola Agency, approximately forty-nine miles north-westerly from Tatla Lake Post Office. You will note the spelling Anahim in this case, whereas Anaham is used for the Reserve and school five miles south easterly of Alexis Creek Post Office. Should the Department approve of the establishment of a school at Anahim Lake, as recommended in my letter 2-11-3 dated September 7, 1945, it might be well to call it by some other name than the one suggested in order to avoid confusion with the school already established at the Anaham Reserve. Perhaps the name "Upper Dean River Indian Day School" would be more suitable under the circumstances.

I am enclosing a road map of the Province whereon I have marked the schools already established in the Cariboo district westerly from Williams Lake and the location of the proposed school on the Upper Dean River at the southerly end of Anahim Lake and trust the information marked thereon may prove of assistance to the Department in dealing with the proposed application and matters relating to the schools already established.

It is somewhat unfortunate that in drafting the covering Order in Council establishing the school at Redstone Meadows the school was designated Alexis Creek as it is actually over seventy miles by road to the west of Alexis Creek Post Office and continues to be confused with the Anaham school which, of course, is located close to the white community of that name. The school at Ulkatcho has been closed for some time owing to the difficulty in getting a teacher and I have no hope at the moment that a qualified teacher will be found for this term. Reverend Father Hennessy is to continue at the Alexis Creek (Redstone Meadows) school for this term, and it has been reported that if the Department approves of the establishment of a Day school at Anahim Lake that arrangements to secure the services of a qualified teacher for same can be made.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

A report has been received from Indian Agent Anfield and Indian Commissioner MacKay, recommending the establishment of an Indian day school on the Upper Dean River, Bella Coola Agency.

A survey has been made of the necessity for a school at this point and it is definitely stated that there are 26 children of school age and that there appears to be a fairly satisfactory list of prospective pupils for future years.

The Indians have shown their desire to cooperate by constructing a log building 30 ft. long, 20 ft. wide and 11 ft. high. The roof is shiplap with roofing paper. It is a strong, well constructed building. The Indians have given free labour on the school but have incurred an expenditure of approximately $800.00 for material, which they would like the Department to pay.

The Indians have also agreed to erect a log building, suitable for a teacher's residence. Apart from the logs and lumber, which will be free as far as the Department is concerned, there will be an expenditure of $150.00 on this unit.

In view of the above, I recommend the establishment of this school, to be known as "Upper Dean River Indian Day School", and enclose Memorandum to Council, as required by Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act.

In reply to your letter of the 25th instant regarding a teacher for the Upper Dean River Indian Day School, I went out to Rose Lake yesterday accompanied by Father Hennessy to interview Mrs. Lester Dorsey.

Father Hennessy and I were both favourably impressed with Mrs. Dorsey and she would like very much to teach at the Upper Dean River School so that she could at least go home for week-ends. However, Mrs. Dorsey would not leave her present position until the Christmas holidays and she does not wish to make any definite arrangement until she has seen Mr. Dyson, the Secretary for the school district. Mrs. Dorsey would also prefer that another teacher could be got for Rose Lake before she resigned but she will give me a definite answer on November 11th when she will be attending the teacher's convention at Williams Lake.

Since Mrs. Dorsey is not a Roman Catholic, I would however, like to be assured that when I see her on November 11th, I can make a definite arrangement with her since she would have to give notice to her present employer.

Mr. and Mrs. Dorsey are very favourably known to the Indians at Anaham Lake and from what I can gather they are not active members of any church, and would not be likely to prejudice the children one way or another. Father Hennessy, C.M.I. will be able to look after the religious instruction of the children and he is of the opinion that this arrangement should work out very well. AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

Education: During the past quarter the senior teacher at Bella Bella resigned and has been replaced. It has not been possible to secure a second teacher for Bella Coola. A new school has been established at Upper Dean River at Anahim Lake, but so far no appointment has been made. A second teacher was secured for the Kitamaat school. Attendance on the whole has improved but education in the broader sense of the word is the real weak link in the Indian programme. Right now in B.C., there is no inspector of Indian Schools, qualifications for teaching and calibre of appointments made is generally very low and most schools are seriously overcrowded. These conditions are not conducive of a good response by the pupils and a complete overhauling of the entire educational policy of the Department appears more and more urgent as time goes on. There is a great deal of criticism by the parents of the operation of the Residential Schools and some of this is undoubtedly based on real grievances, caused by unsuitable staffing of the schools in question.

A trip was made to Ansham Lake early in March, the roads having been ploughed and conditions quite favourable at the time and the Upper Dean River Indian Day School was visited in the Bella Cools Agency. Although there is no doubt that Mrs. Dorsey is an outstanding teacher only 8 Indian pupils were present. These pupils however, are with one or two exceptions, doing very well and attending quite regularly. The difficulty here, as elsewhere in this Agency, is that the parents are so widely scattered in isolated meadows, feeding cattle or on their traplines. There are other Indians of course, who are indifferent, but day schools are still in their infancy in this Agency and I think that wherever possible they should be continued if at all possible with the hope that the Indians will become more conscious of the benefits to be derived.

September 1st, 1949.

W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Upper Dean River Indian Day School.

In reply to your letter of the 29th August, regarding the opening of the Upper Dean River Indian Day School, I contacted Mrs Mc Kilvington by phone today. She advises that there are no Indians at Anahim Lake at present but that haying should be almost completed by the end of September. She suggested that school should open on October 3rd.

Personally I am of the opinion that the residents of Anahim Lake and surroundings will be haying up to freeze up this year and in my experience of that district I would consider the beginning of October in every year the earliest we can expect a satisfactory school attendance.

I shall be going into Anahim Lake in about a weeks time and can advise you further after getting more information but there is no doubt that opening of this school should be delayed at least one month.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Superintendent.

On my recent visit to the Upper Dean River Indian Day School it was noted that Mr. and Mrs. McKilvington had three Indian children boarding with her - Isabella Squinas, daughter of Louis Squinas, for whom they are receiving $20.00 from the parents plus Family Allowance, also Edward Canoose and Helen Zulin, children of Jimmy Zulin and Nellie Baptiste, for whom they are only receiving Family Allowance.

In this connection I would quote from a letter received from Mrs. McKilvington:

"When you and Mr. Lees were here a week ago, I spoke to you about the three youngsters who are staying with us. We asked you if there was any remuneration for anyone rooming and boarding youngsters so that they can attend school.

From Nellie (Canoose) and Fatty Zulin we are receiving nothing, except the Family Allowance, which amounts to seven dollars ($7.00) for each child or a total of fourteen dollars ($14.00) a month altogether. Louis Squinas is paying us twenty dollars ($20.00) a month plus the Family Allowance".

While Mr. and Mrs. McKilvington are taking very good care of these children and treat them like they were their own I doubt very much if the Department will consider
W. S. Arneil, Esq.

18/3/50

contributing anything on their behalf since this would only create a precedent, as there are many other children belonging to the Ulkatcho Band, who have just as much right to this assistance as these two children of Jimmy Zulin.

I would appreciate, however, receiving a letter from the Department giving an answer to Mrs. McKilvington's request so that I may reply to the letter received from Mrs. McKilvington.

Wm. Christie, Supt.,
Williams Lake Indian Agency.

One factor has not been mentioned by Mr. Christie. It is impossible in this area to provide transportation for the children in question due to the lack of roads and severe winter weather.

On February 7th, 1950 I visited the Upper Dean River Indian Day School.

I inspected fences and other repairs contracted for by Mr. McKilvington and found that he made a very good job of the work.

There were thirteen pupils present in class and fifteen on the school register.

The discipline and general atmosphere of the School were very good.

The pupils were clean and it was noted that there were several charts on the wall and stars given out for cleanliness.

Mrs. McKilvington requested certain supplies by letter, which I have made out requisitions for and enclose same herewith.

I believe the sewing machine should be supplied for the school so that the children could be taught how to use it. The basketball equipment would be used outside in the school yard, which has been levelled off.

In this school there are windows on both sides and when the sun shines in on one side it is distracting and therefore I recommend that window shades
W. S. Arneil, Esq.  
14/3/50.

are provided.

The other articles requisitioned for would all appear to be necessary.

I might add that both Mr. and Mrs. McKilvington are taking good care of everything connected with the school and teacherage and see to it that the Indian children do likewise.

Wm. Christie, Supt.,
Williams Lake Indian Agency.

Last week I contacted Mr. Lester Dorsey at Anaham Lake and he has definitely agreed to teach at the Upper Bear River Indian Day School next term commencing September 1947.

I might add that the white people have been agitating for a school for white children who have got tops out for same. They were waiting for the Inspector to go in and pretty well talked Mr. Dorsey into accepting the position as teacher. Mr. Dorsey realized however that the white school was only a possibility this year. I was talking to some of the whites and pointed out that the Department was not very particular who ran the school at Anaham Lake so long as Indian children were not locked up unfavorably. One party in particular felt that the Indian children were too dirty for her children to associate with so that I think that the Department should go ahead and give the living accommodation for Mr. Dorsey as comfortably as possible. Personally I think we are fortunate to get a teacher like Mr. Dorsey who is not too squeamish and knows and understands the Indians at Anaham Lake very well.

I looked over the buildings with Mr. L. M. Mathews, who I discovered building a frame house up there and also asked him to get together with Mrs. Dorsey regarding a few cupboards and shelves for the Teacherage and School.

You may recollect that we bought some Donnacoma from Mr. Kenney last fall. This has never put on and is only about half enough. It is not satisfactory to put Donnacoma on top of logs and I would suggest that the logs be stripped with "x" x 4" and lined with rough lumber of which there would seem to be sufficient here, before applying the Donnacoma. A second floor of shiplap 14" apart between will make the Teacherage much warmer. Mr. Dorsey would like to have the floor covered with linoleum but I do not recommend it.

It is important the Indians did not put on the Donnacoma last fall because they did not know how to do so and I think that it will be better to have a man who understands a little more about carpentry do the finishing work. In any case the Indians are all busy making new ceiling of the school was not lined. The lumber is only sufficient to tack Vancouver board on which is not satisfactory. Some of the board has fallen off the ceiling already. I would suggest that where the edges of the Vancouver board can they should be stripped and we might get along with this for a year or two. Eventually the school should be lined with lumber along the ceiling and inside the logs.

I could have supplied all of the lumber from the sawmill at Anaham but it is shut down for haymaking and I do not think we have any double dressed boards for shelving. We may still be able to get it there however as everything in the building shop is very scarce here.

I was unable to get any quotations on Donnacoma here but might be able to get it shipped up from Vancouver with material for the convent at Anaham once I receive authorization. I would appreciate authorization to get the material wherever I can get it as although Gardiner and Sons have sent a quotation there is no assurance that they will be able to supply this material when we require it which is right away.

Regarding labour, I talked the matter over with Mr. Fred Johnson who is very helpful and he figured the actual work to be done to approximately $350.00 without leaving any profits and thinks that the figure quoted by Mr. Mathews is fairly reasonable.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

AIRMAIL:

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re - Upper Dean River Indian Day School -

I have to refer to my letter of November 16th last wherein I mentioned that information would be provided at a later date with respect to furnishings and further improvements required at the Upper Dean River Indian Day School. As previously advised this school is much more accessible from the Williams Lake Agency than from the Bella Coola Agency, consequently I have had Mr. Christie look into the matter.

The Agent's letter of August 2nd and enclosures are forwarded herein, from which you will note that expenditures totalling approximately $1100.00 will be necessary. $679.00 only was provided in the Bella Coola Agency estimates, but now that we have been assured of the services of Mrs. Lester Dorsey as teacher, it is considered that we should take such action as may be necessary to make the buildings comfortable. I would appreciate being advised if the amount of $1100.00 can be made available for this school, and if it will be in order to purchase the furnishings and materials requested by Mr. Christie.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I am forwarding herewith Williams Lake Agency Vouchers Nos. 536 and 537 in favour of the Williams Lake Indian Agency Trust Account, the former covering the supply of lumber for the Upper Deen River Indian Day School and the latter material for cribbing wells on the Redstone Meadows Reserve.

Materials in both cases were provided from the output of the sawmill purchased from the housing division of the Welfare Vote for the Williams Lake Agency last year and it is anticipated that further vouchers covering the supply of lumber for various purposes payable to the Agency Trust Account will be forwarded from time to time.

The present arrangement with respect to the operation of the Williams Lake Agency sawmill is that the Indians provide the logs and receive one-half of the lumber cut. The other half of the cut is being disposed of to the Department or elsewhere and the proceeds, less a certain percentage reserved to meet unforeseen expenditures, is used to meet operating costs of the mill. Under this arrangement the Department is assured of a supply of lumber at prices which today are reasonable. The Indians are assured of a supply of lumber to meet their housing requirements and the Department is relieved of the cost of operating the mill.

The enclosed vouchers are recommended for payment and I would appreciate receiving confirmation from the Department that the proposal as set out above with respect to the operation of this mill is acceptable.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

In reply to your letter of July 13 regarding repairs and improvements required at Upper Dean River Indian Day School, I have looked over the requirements of this school and discussed them with Inspector Davey and also Mr. McKilvington, who is prepared to carry out this work. The improvements to be done, and for which quotations for material and labour have been received, are as follows:

- Fencing of teacherage and school grounds
- Digging of school well and installation of pump
- Painting of teacherage walls and ceiling
- Doors for cupboards in teacherage
- Shingle roof for teacherage
- Puttying windows
- Installation of window screens
- Chinking between logs of school and teacherage
- Construction of well house

Total repairs amount to:

| Material | $483.92 (plus freight) |
|----------|------------------------|
| Labour   | 352.50                 |

Even though considerable expense is indicated, this school and teacherage has not cost very much money and these improvements are all necessary for the comfort of the pupils and teacher, and also for the general appearance of the grounds.

Regarding the stock fence for which no quotation is submitted, I have quoted the prices given on similar fences supplied for Anaham and Redstone Schools. I would suggest that you verify these prices from Mac and Mac by telephone, which will expedite the carrying out of the repairs.

An early reply would be appreciated as Mr. McKilvington is prepared to go ahead immediately.

[Signature]

Wm. Christie, Supt.,
Williams Lake Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Following District School Inspector Davey's report of June 2nd in connection with the Upper Dean Indian Day School, Supt. Christie was asked to investigate and report with regard to repairs and improvements required. These are outlined in his letter of July 20th attached and you will note that the estimated cost is approximately $840.00.

No specific provision was made in the Estimates for any work at this school, possibly on account of the confusion between the Bella Coola and Williams Lake Agencies in connection with the administration of the school, but as stated by Mr. Christie this school was established at very little cost to the Department and if at all possible it is felt that the expenditure necessary to bring the school up to a reasonable standard should be made.

I would recommend that the Department endeavour to secure funds to the extent required and that an accountable advance of $352.50 be forwarded to Mr. Christie to meet labour costs. This office can arrange for purchase of the materials.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

She requires thirty yards of cheesecloth and thirty yards of crepe paper and thread in order to make costumes for her children.

The cheesecloth is quoted at five yards for 75¢ making a total of $4.50 and the crepe paper at 20¢ a package, each package containing eight feet, making a total of $3.00. The thread will amount to approximately 50¢.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge your letter 478-V-4, dated January 16th 1906, asking for information as to the manner in which Miss Rhodes School-teacher at Alert Bay attends to the duties devolving upon her in that capacity, and the reason why so few pupils attend the School.

First, Miss Emily Rhodes is a very clever person and well qualified. She taught in a private school on the continent nine years, and had private classes in "English Literature" in Vancouver for four years; and in London, England, she was Collegiate Science and Literature Lecturer.

She appeared to me to be attending to her duties well, and the girls at the school seemed delighted with her. Of course the Indian School work is new to her. She asked me a great many questions regarding the conducting of the school and I tried to assist her by suggestions.

On Tuesday, the 26th, I visited the Indian Day School and found Miss N. Clowes substituting for the regular teacher Mr. Moody, who is now sick. There are only eight children in attendance—three boys and five girls—all of tender ages. At the present writing it is difficult to say whether this day school will in the future serve the purpose for which it was intended, as I found that practically all the larger and elder pupils of the past have now been placed in the Girls Home, and now only the very smaller ones attend. None of those could speak English, and were only learning to make their letters on slates. The original intention was, I understand, that this building should be used as a class-room for the new Girls Home, the teaching staff to look after the education of the pupils of both the Day School and Girls Home, but it has been considered by the Church of England authorities that this plan would not be feasible or satisfactory and consequently the idea will not be carried out.

Sgd. W.E. Ditchburn,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Sir,

In your letter of Dec 17th No II7262/1 you make reference to Mr Greens report on the Alert Bay Day School.

Mr Green came to Alert Bay at an unfortunate time. Nearly all the Indians were away from home at the time and had not been at home for some time and the average as will be seen from last quarters report was only 8.5%. The school register shows that the latter part of the term that the attendance was often as high as 17.

Since the opening of the school term this quarter Miss Clowes informs me that the morning average is about 10 and the afternoon about 15. It seems to be very difficult to get the Indians to attend in the mornings. They sit up all hours of the night and never think of sending the children to bed until they go themselves, and it is quite a common thing to see the children playing round the street at night until midnight or later. The result is that they do not get up early. The parents are at the best apathetic on the educational question.

Mr G.H.Moody whose appointment as teacher was approved by the Department has been in the hospital with pneumonia and typhoid fever for nearly 12 weeks, and I am informed by the church authorities will be disconnected from the Mission. During the most of the time the school has been taken by Miss Margaret Clowes, who has had five years experience in teaching in England. I call at the school every few days to see how everything is going along and
have been very much impressed with the progress the pupils have been making. Miss Clowes had special training in Kindergarten work and uses that system largely and the pupils are much interested in the musical drills and calisthenic exercises which she mixes up with the other lessons. This helps to insure a better attendance.

It has not been definitely decided as to whether Miss Clowes will remain permanently but personally I hope that she may.

A number of the pupils who would ordinarily attend the Day School are now inmates of the Industrial School and Girls Home which of course decreases the average for the Day School.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

$900.00 per annum, with $50.00 per annum for janitor work.

No training or certificates. Experience in this school since 1917. Previous to the year 1917 the teacher states he was with Rev. Mr. Corker in the Indian Residential School, Alert Bay. I do not know just what kind of teaching he undertook there.

After my inspection was finished the teacher, Mr. Luther, informed me that he had been ill after the last inspection and towards the end of the school year. He stated that his heart was giving him trouble and that he felt the strain of trying to teach so many small children. I suggested that perhaps he would be better off in a small Church school but he would not consider transfer to any such school not under the Department of Indian Affairs. He told me that he could be willing to retire if the Department would give him some help during the remainder of his life. I said that I could not possibly say what the Department might or might not be willing to do, but that his best plan would be to WRITE TO HIS INDIAN AGENT STATING THAT THE SCHOOL WAS TOO MUCH FOR HIM AS HE WAS NOW AGEING AND THAT THE DEPARTMENT CONSIDER GIVING HIM A SMALL MONTHLY ALLOWANCE IF HE RETIRED FROM THE SCHOOL AT THE END OF THE PRESENT SCHOOL YEAR. I talked this over with Mr. Todd later, and impressed him with the necessity of having Mr. Luther, who is of course an Indian, state that he was unable to continue the charge of the school. I do not wish Mr. Luther to be dismissed on the result of this last inspection and report alone. If the Indian Agent wishes him notified that his services are no longer required, the Department will be free from this report as to how the school stands. There is no question that Mr. Luther is failing in his work, particularly with the younger children. I am perfectly willing to support the recommendation of the Indian Agent who has been keeping a very close watch on this school. I should like to suggest that it would be perfectly possible for me to obtain an experienced teacher with a First Class Certificate and years of successful teaching at a salary of $800.00 with $50.00 per annum extra for or even without this and allow the $300 or $150.00 thus saved to be applied as a shot of Relief to this Indian, Mr. Luther, as long as he lived. This has not been done in other cases but I suggest it here as this school certainly requires the services of an experienced teacher to pull it up to the required standard. I have recommended to the Indian Agent that two children from this day school be permitted to go into St. Michael's Indian Res. School owing to special circumstances of which he is aware. In conclusion I may state that the standing of this school is at present "Unsatisfactory" and the teacher's control "Weak".

Sir,

Replying to your letter dated April 11th,
No. 156-29-1 regarding Inspector Barry's report on the Indian Day School at Alert Bay, in which he reports unfavourably on the work being done by the present teacher, Mr. Luther, I beg to submit the following information.

The Alert Bay Indian Day School naturally has come under my close observation as it is located at the Agency headquarters, and I have felt during the past year that progress made was not as good as might have been expected. I have also felt the discipline and regular attendance could be improved on, and when Inspector Barry visited the Agency recently I spoke to him about these matters and asked him to make a very close inspection. He reported back to me that he was under the same impression as I was, and felt it would be in the best interests of all concerned if a change was made.

Mr. Luther advises me he has been teaching Indian Schools for thirty years, of which twelve years was in the old Residential School, and eighteen years in the present Day School. Inspector Barry informed me he discussed the matter of his retirement with Mr. Luther, but he stated he did not have sufficient money saved to retire on, and disliked the thought of having to accept relief or charity after having worked all these years. Personally I know Mr. Luther has been very liberal with his money in assisting Indians, and possibly this is the reason why he has not sufficient funds to retire on as his earnings would indicate. Mr. Luther's health is not very good and I feel under the circumstances he should retire, and he has expressed his willingness to do so in the enclosed letter, but has requested the Department to grant him a small remuneration each year.

I am of the opinion if the Department could arrange to do this it would be a very suitable gesture and a means of showing the Department's appreciation for his thirty years of service and at the same time retain the good will of all Mr. Luther's Indian friends. There is no doubt Mr. Luther's presence in the village has a good effect on the Indians as a whole as he lives a very clean and Christian life and we would always be in the position of having his services if needed.

As there is no provision for the superannuation of teachers of Indian Day Schools I realize it is going to be difficult for the Department to undertake anything along this line, but I would like to suggest some means be found in which the Department could grant Mr. Luther an amount of fifty dollars a year or if they felt they could increase this amount to one hundred dollars a year it would be most satisfactory to me. Possibly some special arrangement could be made to do this as I am anxious that a change be made and at the same time the Department show their appreciation for the long years of service Mr. Luther has rendered.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,-

During the time Capt. Barry, Department School Inspector made his recent inspection of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, I took up with him the matter of my health in the interests of this school.

There is, however, one thing which worries me and that is after all the years of service I have not been able to put aside sufficient funds through various reasons to care for me in my latter years, and I dislike to give up my position so long as my health will permit me to carry on with the possibility that I might find myself having to ask the Department for assistance later on. I talked the matter over thoroughly with Capt. Barry, and explained to him my financial position as well as the state of my health.

In view of the above, do you think the Department would favourably consider granting me a small sum each year in consideration of the many years service which I have given the Department as teacher. I realize there is no superannuation fund for teachers in the Indian Department the same as there is for those who teach under the Provincial Department of Education, but possibly the Department might find some way in which they could grant this to me.

If this could be done, I would be willing to tender my resignation to take effect at the end of the present term, and I would appreciate if you would take this up with the Department and advise me accordingly.

Sir,

Owing to several Day School teachers having resigned this year from their positions and the necessity of successors being appointed, some to positions where the school is held in buildings erected by the Church and others to schools erected by the Department, it is felt with a view to raising the standard of our teachers, some distinction should be made between the schools owned by the Department and those which are the property of the Church. In the past the Church have always nominated the teachers to all these positions, but to meet local conditions often teachers not very well qualified were appointed.

At the present time we have a new school to be opened at Uatsine which will be held in the Anglican Church which was erected there last year. The Village Island School is a similar case, as well as the Kingcome School and Smith Inlet School at Takush Harbour. At Alert Bay the Department built the school, and financially the Church are not interested in any way. I am not quite sure, but I feel the Cape Mudge School was also built by the Department.

There is a possibility of a vacancy occurring at the Alert Bay Day School, and we feel in this particular instance as the Church is not interested, the Department should make their own appointment. The new school which is to be built at Campbell River will also be purely a Department School, and in our opinion the school teacher should be appointed by the Department here as well.

Since taking over the Agency I have been closely watching the progress of our Day Schools, and in my opinion so long as the Department find it necessary to be more or less guided by the wishes of the Churches, it is going to be difficult to make the progress expected with the amount of money expended each year for salaries in these schools. I am trying to be quite frank with the Department in expressing only my own personal views, and I am bringing this matter to the attention of the Department after discussing it thoroughly with our Mr. Phelan who was privileged to visit the Alert Bay Indian Day School where an Indian teacher, Mr. George M. Luther, has been teaching for the past seventeen years.

My views are for the amount of money which the Department expends each year by employing qualified teachers, we are reaching the point in advancement where the education should be gradually placed more and more under the direct supervision of the Department rather than being expected to be guided more or less by recommendations from the Church. I feel if our Department could have more say in the education, more progress would be made.
I would also like to point out to the Department the Churches have in the past erected buildings on reservations with no Agreements from the Department, and look upon these buildings as belonging to them. On one of my visits to Victoria some time ago His Lordship Bishop Schofield raised this question with me, and said he felt the time was coming when our Department should take over the administration and all other responsibility in connection with the running of these schools. I would like to see, when funds are available, the Department take over any school which is considered an "established" one, as at present the situation is confusing. I believe if the Church was properly approached we would have no difficulty in coming to an understanding in which they would be willing to practically leave the education of the Indian children to the Department to look after entirely.

I am writing this letter to place my own personal views before you, and I would appreciate if after careful consideration you would write me giving me your views as to the future. I might add I am in close touch with His Lordship Bishop Schofield, and I have found him very willing to co-operate and work with me. I feel if the Department looked favourably upon my views, possibly His Lordship and myself might work out a solution more suitable to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

Dear Mr. Perry:

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Alert Bay Indian Day School, Kwawkewlth Agency, which I inspected on Thursday last, January 23rd.

Mr. Wickett has very greatly improved the condition of the school, though he has made mistakes with regard to demoting certain pupils, etc.

I have spent a considerable time with this young teacher. The main items of my report have been talked over with him, and this includes the recommendation for promotion in certain Grades. He is anxious to make a success of his work here, and responds very well to professional advice. I hope that he will have the support of the Department and its officials in B.C.

There is, as no doubt you are aware, a very awkward situation in Alert Bay just now. The local Indian teacher who taught here for many years was replaced by the present teacher last September, and while this Indian teacher has given no trouble, it is a fact that the present teacher has not received much support from the Anglican Missionary. The Anglican Missionary is opposed to the Indian Agent, and to a greater or less extent is creating trouble throughout the village. While Mr. Wickett has tried to keep clear of these local disputes he has to some extent been involved. On the whole I think that Mr. Wickett has handled the local situation very well. He has been informed by the Anglican Bishops of the Diocese that there will shortly be a change here and a new Anglican Missionary will be appointed. I am certainly very glad to hear this.

I should be glad to see new single desks in this school, and I may say that the Indian Agent has been offered the loan of the necessary desks which are spare at St. Michael's Indian Residential School. The local Anglican Church Group object to the old desks being changed, as the modern single school desks would not accommodate the old Indians attending the Friday night Bible Meetings HELD IN THE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL. There are several other places where the Bible Class might well be held, and it seems very foolish to me to deprive the children of the advantage of suitable desks which happen to be available to please some foolish old Indians. I believe the Indian Agent and the Teacher wish for these new desks but they do not wish to stir up any more friction in Alert Bay.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry,
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Name of teacher: William P. Wickett

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

Mr. Wickett was trained in the Victoria Normal School, 1933-34, and has taken the following courses in addition, English; Technique of Teaching; Choral Music; Primary Work; at the Provincial Summer School, Victoria, 1935, and Language Arts in 1936.

This teacher has been more of a success with the younger children in Grade 1, than he has with the older children. In my last report I stated that he had made a very good start in this his first school. The work since that inspection has been carried on in a successful manner on the whole, but Mr. Wickett has developed a very unfortunate manner in the schoolroom.

He has become abrupt with the pupils and while not perhaps shouting at them certainly snaps at them, using such foolish expressions as "Where you before giving an order." I have of course spoken to him about this very poor schoolroom manner and use of voice. His nerves are under a strain, thought from what actual cause I do not know. If he does not take things quietly he will have a breakdown. In fact if he is unable to modify his nasty manner with the children during the next year, I shall be forced to recommend his removal. I shall not recommend him for a permanent Provincial Certificate this next June, but shall suggest to the Provincial Department of Education that his present Interim Certificate be extended for another year.

Colonel G. S. Pragnell spoke to me about the untidy state of this schoolroom when he last visited here. I took this up with Mr. Wickett who tells me that no official has told him that his room is untidy. I am only doubtfully statement, as I feel certain that Mr. Indian Agent Todd has warned him be more tidy. The room is certainly untidy and needs to have books and papers, etc., not being used at the moment placed in cupboards or in the storeroom. The teacher was given instructions to tidy up the room.

While Mr. Indian Agent Todd has very greatly improved the physical conditions here, I am far from satisfied with the educational standing which has not kept pace with the improvement in the schoolroom.

I would ask that this teacher be warned that unless the work of the older children has very greatly improved by the time of the next inspection, and that the schoolroom can be described as tidy, his services will not be required.

Mr. Wickett is showing signs of a definite "Superiority Complex" which under the circumstances are quite usual. You will see from my report that while the actual school has been greatly improved during the past year, and new desks provided, the actual teacher has not kept pace with the material improvements.

Dear Major MacKay:

In accordance with Departmental letter 156-29-1, dated May 28, 1937, Very Rev. Cecil S. Quainton, Bishop's Commissary, has discussed with me the qualifications of candidates for the vacant position of teacher of the Alert Bay Indian Day School.

Dean Quainton, in the attached letter dated July 9th, has nominated two candidates as being the most suitable for the vacant position. These are:

Mrs. Sarah Covey 795 Nicola St., Vancouver, B.C.
and Mr. Noel Stewart 1269 Deman St., Victoria, B.C.,
the present teacher of the Hazelton Indian Day School.

As you will see from his letter, the Dean considers Mr. Stewart the better of the two candidates, and in this I fully agree with him, though I hope that Mrs. Sarah Covey will receive Bishop Rix's nomination for one of our Indian Day Schools in the North.

I have therefore to recommend the transfer of Mr. Noel Stewart from Hazelton to be teacher of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and would ask that, if you and the Indian Affairs Branch agree with me, the Indian Agents concerned be notified as soon as possible.

For the information of the Indian Affairs Branch I may say that Mr. Noel Stewart was trained in the Edmonton Normal School 1929-30, holds a Permanent First-Class Certificate in Alberta; attended the Summer School in Edmonton in 1933, 1934, and 1935 where he obtained the special Intermediate Grade Certificate; taught grades 6 to 12 in the St. Paul's Indian Residential at Cardston for 5 years, and has been the teacher of the Hazelton Indian Day School since January last. During the years 1926-29 Mr. Stewart attended the Ohio State University and there obtained his B.Com.Sc. degree. Mr. Stewart is at present, on my advice, taking a Primary course at the Provincial Summer School in Victoria. He appears most anxious to carry out the wishes of the Indian Affairs Branch as expressed through its officials in British Columbia, and I have every reason to believe that he will be able to make a great success of his work at Alert Bay should he be transferred, as he is very anxious to devote himself entirely to school work.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

In a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Todd, Kwawkwalth Agency, dated August 7th, a most important matter is raised and I would ask that you forward my recommendations together with your own remarks to the Department in Ottawa for a general ruling to cover the Province of British Columbia in addition to the more specific decision in the case of Alert Bay.

Mr. Todd writes in part as follows:

"Now that there are two teachers to this school, I presume Mr. Stewart will be considered the Principal, and nominally in charge of both rooms although they both will have their classrooms quite separately. I am writing you for a ruling on the matter, as I would like to consider Mr. Stewart the Principal, and responsible to the Department for the two rooms. My idea in writing you as I feel it is best to have one person responsible rather than two, particularly when ordering supplies, etc. I feel Mr. Stewart should be in charge of the two rooms as well in the matter of discipline.

Possibly you would be good enough to write me your views on these matters as I do not want any hitches as to authority when the two rooms get under way.

You might also advise me when there are two rooms if there is a possibility of any difference being made in the salaries."

The usual procedure in the case of Provincial schools of two or more divisions or rooms is to have the teacher of the senior division or room the Principal of the school, and in general responsible to the Provincial Department for the administration of the whole school, though all the subordinate teachers have certain rights in their own classes as laid down in the B.C. School Act.

I agree with Mr. Todd that in the case of the Alert Bay Indian Day School it is essential that the senior teacher, in this case Mr. Noel Stewart, should be the Principal and in general charge of the whole school, and I would so recommend.

May I request that a circular be issued by the Department to all Indian Agents and teachers of Indian Schools in B.C., to the effect that when there are two or more classrooms in a school the teacher of the senior room or division will be held by the Department responsible for the general discipline of the school, the prompt forwarding of all monthly or quarterly returns, the preparation of necessary requisitions, and that such teacher will be termed the Principal of the school as such a term is understood in British Columbia.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 22nd ultimo regarding teachers of the senior room in Indian Day Schools acting as principals, I am proposing to circularize the Agents as follows, but before doing so, would appreciate your comments, if any:

"It has been decided by the Department that in those Indian Day Schools where more than one teacher is employed, the teacher in charge of the senior room is to be recognized as the Principal of the school.

"The Principal of an Indian Day School in B.C. will be held responsible for the general discipline and administration of the whole school, the prompt forwarding of all necessary reports and returns to the Department through the local Indian Agent, the preparation and forwarding of annual and emergency requisitions, and all such other duties as are usual in the case of a Principal in a British Columbia school, or (which may be required by the officials of the Department of B.C.)

"While the control of junior classes will remain the responsibility of the teachers placed in charge of such rooms, the Principal of the school should be consulted in any serious cases of insubordination. The Department will hold Principals of Indian Day Schools responsible that their schools are conducted in accordance with the provisions of the Indian Act and Departmental regulations.

"In the case of any conflict of opinion between Principals and other teachers in Indian Day Schools, the matters in dispute should be referred to the Inspector of Indian Schools through the Indian Agent concerned."

AGENT'S REPORT ON KWAWEKWLTH AGENCY FOR AUGUST 1939.

The entire month of August has been spent at the Agency headquarters. Owing to a second classroom being established in connection with the Alert Bay Indian Day School, and the necessity of transferring children from the Residential school to the Day school and other places, it was necessary for me to remain here to supervise the repairs and changes which are taking place.

The second classroom which we are providing here will open on time, but we have had difficulty in completing same owing to the Department not approving of the full amount of money I estimated it would cost to put this building in repair. In this connection I should like to inform the Department Mr. Stewart, the Principal of the Alert Bay Indian Day School, returned earlier at my request in order that he could help us rearrange the equipment and supplies before school opened. Mr. Sharpe, who assisted with the carpenter work, has offered to donate some of his services to the department if necessary in order to complete the work, but in my opinion this should not be necessary and it is my intention to put in his full time even though it does exceed the total amount of $205.00 approved by the department, and I hope any small expenditure beyond the approved amount will be paid.

The Residential school opened on August 28th with a full attendance.

Dear Sir,

Last year this office requested the Department to establish a summer school at the Alert Bay Indian Day School but were advised by Departmental letter No. C-687 of June 25th, 1940, that owing to lack of funds this was not possible at that time, but requesting that I include an item in my Estimates for 1941-42 and if the same condition existed this year as did last, to take the matter up with the Department and it would receive favourable consideration.

Provision was made in our Estimates on page 9A for sufficient funds to operate a summer school, and as the need for same is even more this year than last, I am again recommending to the Department that a summer school be established at Alert Bay during the months of August and September.

My reasons for making this request are as follows:

The British Columbia Packers have practically doubled their capacity at their cannery here, which means that twice as many women will be employed this year, and in order to get these women they will have to be brought in with their families from outside villages. This will mean approximately one hundred small kiddies will be living in this village during the summer and fall. During the month of July, the women will not be so busy in the cannery and can take care of the children, but during August and September the heavy run of fish is on which will mean the children will be running the streets with no one to look after them, and as the Department is aware, Alert Bay has only one street and no children's playground. It would therefore be of great benefit to the children as well as the parents from the children's health and safety point of view, if a summer school were established during this period.

I have spoken to Miss Flick, the present Junior teacher, and she has promised to stay during August and September, and at the present time I believe Mrs. Massay, teacher of the Kingcome Inlet Day School has an application before the Klitsa Reserve E.Sexton for a transfer to the Senior Room of the Alert Bay Day School, and if this is arranged she would be available as from August 1st.

The situation in connection with children in Alert Bay during this summer is going to be very serious, and this is the only way I can see that we can possibly cope with it. I hope, therefore, that the Department will see their way clear to approve of this arrangement. As the teachers will no doubt wish to make plans for the summer, I would appreciate the Department's decision at as early a date as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant enclosing a letter from Indian Agent Todd dated May 29. The advisability of conducting a day school during the summer months at Alert Bay is extremely doubtful. It appears from the Agent's letter that what is really required is supervised play. It is quite possible that this would be much more beneficial to the children than classroom work during the months mentioned in the Indian Agent's letter. There is another point to consider; namely, that the efficiency of the teachers for the regular academic term starting on October 1 might be impaired by requiring them to teach during the summer months.

I hesitate to approve of this arrangement if it is intended to be a permanent one, although the inference might be taken from the Agent's letter that it is only due to the extra help required by the British Columbia Packers this year.

I feel that it would be advisable for you to again consider this whole matter very carefully and possibly correspond again with Indian Agent Todd. If, after reconsideration, you still think that the school should be operated during the months of August and September you may make the necessary arrangements to do so. In that event you can secure the services of Mrs. Massey and Miss Flick. Please let me have a further report from you regarding what action is being taken.

Mrs. Massey and Miss Flick have both informed me they would be free to start teaching on the first of August and continue for the balance of the term; in fact they are both very anxious to do so. They would have one month's holiday during July, and I am certain that teaching from August 1st would have no ill effects on their health, as they are both strong and healthy people.

It was my intention to ask that a permanent summer school be established here, as the same conditions will prevail year after year so long as the cannery operates.

Insofar as the routine to be followed, I was under the impression this was more or less arranged by Inspector Barrie as I thought they had a special course for this type of school. Dear Sir:

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of September 12th last, file 15-6-4131, I beg to give you my views as to the results obtained from the Summer School which was held at Alert Bay during the months of August and September this year. As this school was officially inspected by Inspector Barry on September 25th last, who will also be making a report, it is my intention not to comment on the academic side but rather, give my impressions in general on this experiment.

I should like first to state I was disappointed in the attendance in both rooms. In the junior room, there were 60 pupils on the register, but who attended irregularly, the average being 20.88 for the full two months. In the senior room, the enrollment was 34, and the average attendance 12 for the two month period.

In breaking down these figures, I find the reasons for the small attendance were as follows: First, the establishment of a Summer School was a new idea to the Indians, and the attendance was voluntary, which meant that the choice of attending was left to the children. I am under the opinion that had the Department left the matter of attendance in the Agent's hands, to decide who should go and who should not, our attendance would have been somewhat better. I feel there were some children in the village who should have gone but owing to their parents working and no one to check up on their attendance, they merely went when they felt like it. I feel because it was on the voluntary system that the attendance was somewhat poor, as previous to the Summer School commencing I had called a meeting of the parents, explaining the idea to them, and asked their cooperation, and they expressed their thanks to the Department and assured me they would do everything they could to cooperate.

This year, the Indians are experiencing one of the most profitable years in the fishing industry, and with shortage of labour a large number of boys from twelve years of age and upwards obtained fishing licences under Permit, and went fishing with their parents, and a great many of the girls from ten years of age and up were given employment at the local cannery by Stanley, and it from the Labour Department at the request of the management of the B.C. Packers to assist in putting up the pack owing to the Company being unable to get help. When the application was made for the Summer School I did not anticipate the situation such as developed this year, and it may never happen again; however, it has been responsible to a great extent for the irregular attendance and reducing the average.

I do feel, however, that on the whole, the Summer School has been a real success. From the health point of view, through the fact that the children were attending school

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Vancouver, B.C.
necessary for them to carry out personal cleanliness as supervised by the teachers, and their living habits were regular. The absence of the usual skin diseases which have always been prevalent after the prolonged holiday period is very noticeable, and this situation would have been aggravated this year owing to so many more families living here and the homes being overcrowded. The village has also been very free from accidents, through the supervised play, and we have had no hospital accounts to meet in this connection.

Each year during the summer holidays when there are so many children playing around the village, it gets into a deplorable state, and one of my requests to the teachers was to keep the village clean and tidy as an outdoor project. I arranged for the teachers to take the children one day per week and go through the village for this purpose, and this in itself has been of great benefit not only to the children but to the Indians as a whole in respect to health.

After taking everything into consideration, I feel the Summer School has been a success and worth while.

For consideration another year, I wish to make the following recommendations:

1. That the attendance be not altogether on the voluntary system, but left to the discretion of the Agent.

2. That the summer School at Alert Bay be conducted under the supervision of one teacher instead of two during the months of August and September.

3. That a similar project be established at Knight Inlet Cannery, Glendale Cove, under supervision of one teacher, where large numbers of children are congregated with not even sufficient playing space or anyone to supervise them while their parents are working in the cannery. This was brought to the attention of the Department early this summer.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

Dear Sir,

I have just finished writing a reply to your circular letter in respect to the closing of Indian Day Schools, and in view of this I hesitated to make the following recommendation, but after giving the matter very careful consideration I feel under the circumstances I am justified in doing so.

As you know, a Summer School was held at Alert Bay during the past year, and while in my opinion it was not the success I had hoped for, nevertheless it was an experiment and proved of untold value to the Indian children, particularly from a health point of view, which, I am sure, meant money well spent by the Department.

When the Day School reopened the children returned in a good state of health, which can be directly attributed to the supervision of the summer school, and I feel that consideration should be given to the operation of a summer school at Alert Bay this year, but with a more limited scope. I feel that one teacher instead of two could handle the load for the extra cost of one teacher's salary for three months it would be money well spent by the Department. I am therefore recommending that a Summer School be held during the months of August and September, employing only one teacher to supervise the same.

I am making this recommendation because I feel with the increased activities of this fishing centre and the demands now made by the war effort on Indian women in the fishing industry, we are going to face difficulty problems in respect to the children who have no place to play and no supervision of them.

I trust the Department will see their way clear to grant this request, even if we have to curtail expenses in some other way to provide funds for same. I might add the Village Island and Quatsino Day Schools have not been opened this term, and some of the funds provided for them in the next term could be utilized for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

EDUCATION

The Day Schools as well as the Residential School appear to be carrying on satisfactorily, with the exception of the Cape Mudge School, where the Department has notified the teacher that his services will not be required after the present term.

This year the usual Empire Day celebrations were held at Alert Bay, and owing to it coming during the time of the Red Cross Appeal, the citizens of this community arranged to make it a Red Cross Day entirely, with all financial receipts going to the Appeal. A varied programme was arranged, a parade taking place in which all schools participated. I am pleased to state that the senior pupils of the Alert Bay Indian Day School under the direction of Mrs. Massey received the first prize. M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.
AGENT'S REPORT ON KWAKWEWLTH AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JUNE 1942.

OCCUPATIONS

The fishing season has now started, and all of my Indians are busily engaged in this industry. There appears to be a shortage of labour, with the result that High School students are being absorbed into the industry to fill the vacancy created by the shortage of manpower. During the early part of the month, quite a number of Indians were engaged in halibut fishing previous to the sockeye season, and this industry has been very successful, as it has been a good season both for price and quantity of fish. Very few of the Indians have remained in the logging industry where they are receiving exceptionally high wages, some as much as ten dollars a day; they do not seem to be able to resist the call of fishing when the season opens.

Possibly I should again draw to the department's attention the closing of the B.C.Packers' Cannery at Alert Bay owing to War Regulations, and the Indian women and their families previously employed here have been transferred to the B.C.Packers Imperial Cannery at Steveston, just outside of Vancouver. I understand these women will be employed there for many months, and this may affect the children's return to the Day school at Alert Bay. However, this matter is being looked into and if its effect on the Alert Bay Day School is serious, a further report will be made at a later date.

M.S.Todd,
Indian Agent.

REPORT ON KNAWKELTH AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JANUARY, 1943.

Education - As no teacher was obtained for the Junior Room of the Alert Bay Day School, arrangements were tentatively made and later approved by the Department, that the school be held on a half-day system until a second teacher can be secured. On account of the severe weather, this school was closed for three days during the month. The Campbell River and Cape Mudge Day Schools were inspected during the month, and found in excellent order. It is noted however that the Cape Mudge School is overcrowded, and as the structure itself is very old, the Indians made application at their general meeting to have a new school provided. It was explained by Inspector Coleman that this would not be possible during the emergency, but that consideration would be given same at a later date, and I would support this as soon as funds are available.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Knowing the scarcity of teachers, for the Department's information I have communicated with the teachers in this Agency to ascertain from them whether it is their intention to remain in their present positions for the term starting on September 1st next, and have had the following replies.

Alert Bay Indian Day School: Mrs. Jane Massey has signified her willingness to remain with the Department here provided she can get suitable living accommodation, and I enclose herewith copy of her letter. This will leave one room vacant. Mrs. Massey's request to have the junior room was forwarded to your office on January 25th last. In my opinion there should be a teacher appointed to the senior room as I understand from Mrs. Massey that from a survey she has made there will be approximately twelve beginners next term; last fall when school started she had sixty pupils on the roll including both junior and senior rooms. Later it was found necessary to request the Department for permission to carry on the half-day system, but this was later found not very satisfactory and when a number of the pupils returned to their home villages Mrs. Massey carried all grades in the one room the full day. A further survey will be made and definite recommendations made to the Department before school closes this term insofar as the second room is concerned.

Cape Mudge Day School - Mrs. R. Wilson has advised she would like to remain at this school next term, and as her services have been very satisfactory so far as I can learn, I would recommend that she be retained in this position.

Campbell River Day School - Mrs. Yeatman has advised me owing to her health she is resigning at the end of the present term. In respect to this school I have received an application from Miss Jean Hill, at one time teacher of the Cape Mudge School, and who is now at Port Simpson, to be appointed to the Campbell River School. Miss Hill advises me the severe weather in the northern country is too much for her parents and as she makes her home with them it is necessary that she move south to a warmer climate and it is for this reason she is resigning from the Port Simpson at the end of the present term and requests a transfer to Campbell River. As Miss Hill's teaching ability is well known to the Department as well as the good influence of herself and family in the life of the Indian village, I would recommend that she be appointed to the Campbell River Day School.

Village Island Day School - This school has been closed for some time owing to our inability to obtain a teacher. The Indians of this village are most anxious that the school be reopened if at all possible, and as I have previously informed the Department, Miss Flora Hanuse has been carrying on this year without any remuneration from the Department. As stated previously, I will make a further report and definite recommendation at a later date as to whether I consider she should be employed or not for next term.
Kingcome Inlet Day School - In regard to this school, I reported after my last visit there that I was not satisfied with the services being rendered by Mr. Christmas, the teacher. While it is recognized an almost impossible situation was created by the Indians' custom activities there this winter, nevertheless I do not feel that Mr. Christmas has the ability to successfully carry on the work, and would strongly recommend that a new teacher be appointed to this school.

(M. S. Todd)

DIOCESAN OFFICE
912 VANCOUVER STREET
VICTORIA, B.C.

Dec. 30th, 1944.

My dear Major MacKay,

I have just had a telephone conversation with Mr. Todd, the Indian Agent at Alert Bay, regarding Miss Shatto who is apparently available as a Teacher in the Indian Bay School. I told Mr. Todd that I am quite agreeable to Miss Shatto's appointment, if you are in agreement with the suggestion... It is preferable to secure a Teacher who is a member of the Church of England but if Miss Shatto is from other lands or a Protestant she will, no doubt, let her understand that she must not escape in anything & the nature of proselytising. My chief reason for mentioning this is that there are a number of Pentecostals and other Fancy Religious Bodies who are keen to make use of such people,

and if we & our teachers were active in such a cause it would, of course, lead to trouble which we are anxious to avoid. I understand Miss Shotts will telephone you for an appointment on Monday when you can give her "the once over!"

With every good wish for your happiness & well-being in the New Year.

Yours sincerely,

Harold E. Sexton,
Bishop of British Columbia.

AIR MAIL

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, the Department approves the appointment of Miss Margaret Riddell Shotts as teacher of the Alert Bay Indian Day School. Salary will be allowed her at the rate of $100 a teaching month. I am forwarding, under separate cover, a supply of the forms required in connection with the appointment of teachers and one set of these should be completed by Miss Shotts as soon as she begins duties.

For Deputy Minister.
Education:

Approval has been given for the appointment of Mrs. M.M. Yeatman as teacher of the Campbell River Indian Day School and as Mrs. Yeatman is a very splendid teacher we are very fortunate in again obtaining her services. On December 30th, 1944, this office was advised by Mrs. M. Wilson, teacher of the Cape Mudge Indian Day School, that she had resigned, and it is presumed her resignation was sent to Rev. W.P. Hunt, Superintendent of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, Vancouver. Previous to receiving this notice from Mrs. Wilson I had been informed by her that Rev. T.F. Moore, United Church minister located at Cape Mudge, was interfering with her school work to such an extent that unless this ceased she would have no alternative but to resign. As Mrs. Wilson is one of our best teachers and I being personally familiar with the circumstances referred to by Mrs. Wilson, I reported the matter fully to Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, enclosing a statement made by Mrs. Wilson, and requested that the matter be taken up with Rev. Hunt, as I was sure Mrs. Wilson was not to blame in any way. I might state I have written to Mrs. Wilson requesting her to stay on until June 30th next, and informed her that Rev. Moore informed me he had resigned from the Church and was leaving Cape Mudge at the end of December, 1944, to study medicine in the United States. To date I have not had any further reply. As the department is aware, Miss M. McGill, teacher of the senior room in the Alert Bay Indian Day School, ceased her duties on December 31st, 1944. I am again drawing it to their attention with the hope that every effort will be made to re-open this classroom as soon as possible. I have forwarded one application to the Commissioner's Office, with a hope that we may be successful in obtaining the services of a teacher.

M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.

Dear Major MacKay,

Replying to your letter of June 9th last, file #215-6-956, I beg to advise you Miss Margaret R. Shotts, senior teacher of the Alert Bay Indian Day School has resigned, and I enclose you copy of her resignation which was forwarded to Bishop Sexton.

For your information, Miss Shotts has only a Wartime Emergency Certificate issued by the Provincial Government of the Province of Alberta, and desires to return there to try and obtain her permanent certificate.

I am very pleased that Miss Saunders is being nominated by Bishop Sexton as she is one of the most experienced senior teachers we have had in this Agency, and as the senior room in the Alert Bay Indian Day School requires a teacher of her type, it is hoped that she will be appointed to this position.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.
